This movie is a classic comedy, considered to be John Hughes's best work among his fans, fact in which I respectfully disagree because he stepped outside of his usual humor with this film, and most of the actors who worked with him in other films are not here, and there are moments when you think that this is not a Hughes film. It works? Yes, the movie is funny, the performances are great, the soundtrack is even better, and the technique of Matthew Broderick speaking to the viewer is excellent.What doesn't work quite well in this film is that Ferris (Broderick) is flawless. This guy skip classes, plays the good son tricking his parents, annoying his sister (Jennifer Grey), has lots of fun with his girlfriend (Mia Sara) and his friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) and so and so; nothing goes wrong to him, or his confusions always leaves him out of trouble and this kind of perfection left the film without laughs at some sequences, something should have gone bad so that us viewers have something to enjoy, laugh, or say something. He's not the only one with problems: his sister keeps complaining about his actions of fooling everyone and not get caught, she seeks revenge but doesn't do much, and she has the chance she saves him, so here the story became contradictory, no coherence at all.One of the things I enjoy in "Ferris Bueller Day Off" is Alan Ruck, who plays the rich and shy friend and that's something rare, I guess most people get identified with Ferris and his tactics of skipping school. Of course, people will get identified with Ferris rather than Cameron because they like to see something they're not (Ferris) instead of something that they might be (Cameron). But I enjoyed his persona, his nervous breakdown moments, and the most funny moment with him is trying to fool the school principal (Jeffrey Jones), pretending to be Mia Sara's dad. I'm not going to the same path as many other users walked by claiming that the film wasn't realistic and all, but I will expose some things that didn't work and could be better developed here. You might wonder what these three friends will do instead of going to school, and if you pay attention to where they go and what they do you'll notice that it wasn't so funny to be in a comedy. Do you skip school to go to a museum? I don't think so! And for people who doesn't attend classes these characters are too much nice, almost square figures that acquires cultural education by not going to school. At last but not least, the system made by Ferris to fool everybody, pretending he's at home and sick....that just doesn't work, because if you're sick parents will take you to the hospital and then you'll think that is better to go to school then to go to hospital. Believe me, I had better ways to skip classes and no one ever found out.For the ones who never saw it watch it fast because it is a good comedy from one of the most interesting decades ever for films. For the ones who give ten stars to this film make a good revaluation, and see how this film is not that funny as many claim to say, it only gets near. 8/10

Review title: An interesting and stylish take on the years of then-contemporary American teenagers, that carries on finding new audiences due to its study of individualism.
Review_body: Like Back to the Future, Ferris Bueller's Day Off seems to hold a pretty firm and entrenched place in whatever 1980s teen cannon that people hold in such high regard. Back to the Future was, perhaps famously, rejected by many-a studios on the basis of 'not being raunchy enough'; something other films of its ilk were at the time. I can imagine something similar happening to Ferris Bueller's Day Off, but like Back to the Future, it is the decidedly 'un-raunchy' films of the era that we now revisit the most often and just seem to hold in higher regard.I think what keeps this film resonating with past and current audiences alike is its clear distinction in paying close attention to young people, and their ever-ongoing battle for independence, for recognition and for individuality. The lead is Ferris Bueller (Broderick); a young and very confident, almost borderline sociopathic in his behaviour, male in then-contemporary America. Ferris is the sort of guy who can con his way into an expensive restaurant; hack his way into the school computer mainframe and shows total disregard to his friend's and certain respective situations when trying to haggle the use of a rare and classic car for the day. The film takes special care in introducing him as an individual whom lives in a large, detached house in a rich neighbourhood that comes complete with a white picket fence. He is literate in all the latest gadgets and pieces of technology, be it home computers used to hack or stereo systems to further the notion he is unwell.In direct opposition to Ferris is the principal of Ferris' school, named Ed Rooney (Jones). Rooney isn't just out to capture Bueller as he plays truant, he is out to destroy Bueller's life; this, Rooney outlines as his goal very early on in the piece. This seems to be the essence of what keeps audiences old and new consistently discovering the film; that study of 'old vs. young' as these cocky, smart and quite attractive bunch of confident oddball kids dare stand up to those of a high authority; those that are grey, suit-clad authoritarian figures such as Rooney.But I think Bueller is smarter-still than what he lets on. He talks very early on about how important it is to go to college and learn a trade and live the American Dream, but he does so in a very nonchalant manner, almost as if he is repeating what it is he's told to say, or think, or feel. What follows is a chain of events and total disregard to most things that suggest he isn't of this ideation at all. But the journey does have an ideation; an ideation Bueller himself cooks up to do with being able to notice life and enjoy life as best you can, otherwise it might seem like it's passing you by.But the film isn't preoccupied with just these studies. Its attention to young vs. old or independence vs. routine is similarly played about with through one of Bueller's two friends named Cameron Frye (Ruck), who is given a slight subplot to do with being able to stand up to his father. Ferris and Cameron's third friend is Sloane Peterson (Sara), Ferris' girlfriend. The three complete an unusual triangle of pals; they are one another's' friend as well as foil, forever getting into adventures and situations but hitting the odd wall when it comes to the finer things during the day out. Cameron is forever concerned with the car; Cameron and Sloane are forever worried they might get caught (particularly when Ferris partakes in a large musical number in the street) and Ferris seems forever pre-occupied that the three of them will not get the best out of their day off; a day off Ferris sees as a gift, as something they worked hard towards earning with their scheming, and thus; must embrace it as fully as possible.The film is a love story, a comedy that relies on slapstick, situation and screwball alike; the film is an odd beast of basic convention, surrealist humour and truancy glorification. But does it ever focus too much on one thing? Does it particularly care what you might think of it? I don't think it does, it just throws mostly everything at the screen, stirs it all up and allows it all to play out. It feels like two, or possibly three, different films at once – but that's fine because there is enough different sorts of content all brewing at once, and focused on at a balanced rate, that we go with it. One might say the film's attitude echoes that of its lead; it's doing things its own way, in its own style and doesn't particularly mind how you react. It's the kind of film that can go from a slow motion shot of two guys driving a sort-of stolen car that was sort-of stolen in the first place to the Star Wars theme; to a series of scenes that rely on a school teacher falling over a few times as a source of humour. The best thing about it all, is that it's all actually rather effective.

Review title: Every high school student dreams of this
Review_body: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986), written and directed by John Hughes, is a high school student's wish fulfillment dream. Imagine being able to skip school, enjoy a fantastic day in Chicago, and do this with your best buddy (driving a spectacular car) and your beautiful girl friend. Ferris Bueller knows he's on his way to a solid career and a trophy wife. He may as well enjoy the ride along the way. Even with our recognition that Ferris is dishonest, selfish, and arrogant, we can't help but be on his side as he outwits adults at every turn.Matthew Broderick was born to play Ferris Bueller, and he is spectacular in the role. All the other characters are only important insofar as they rotate in orbit around Ferris. Jeffrey Jones does a competent job as Principal Rooney, who plays Wile E. Coyote to Broderick's Road Runner. Rooney knows Ferris isn't sick and he takes on the job of catching his nemesis violating regulations. (We can guess that he'll be no more successful than Wile E. Coyote, but neither Rooney nor Coyote ever catch on.)Mia Sara is attractive as Ferris's girlfriend Sloane, although I'd advise her to think twice before considering Ferris as marriage material. Ben Stein is perfect as the economics teacher whose teaching techniques have reached a perfection of tedium.Finally, how can you not like a movie that features Charlie Sheen as "Boy in Police Station," and that gives the world the definitive cinematic version of "Twist and Shout"?

Matthew Broderick plays a kid who goes to high school and decides to take a day off.He plays hookie with his friends Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) and Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) and enjoys the day in Chicago.There's only one person who can stop the fun and that's the principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones).And Ferris' sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey).OK, that's two persons.Ferris is a slacker but in his parents' eyes he's a perfect angel.So can Ferris get away with his plan or will he get caught? Ferris Bueller's Day Off is an amazing John Hughes movie from 1986.The movie's twenty years old and yet it seems so fresh.Teens all over the world still love the movie.Oh so young Matthew Broderick shines in the lead.This movie was made for him.Just like the role of Marty McFly was made for Michael J. Fox in Back to the Future one year earlier this one was made for Matthew.All the other actors do a great job too.The young Charlie Sheen can also be seen in the movie as Boy in police station.The movie is filled with terrific scenes.One of the greatest moments is when Ferris gets up and sings Twist and Shout by The Beatles.This movie sends a great message for the kids at school.Everybody should follow Ferris' example and skip school once in a while.Let's all just get out of that class room and have a piece of the world out there.All you need is a good plan.You have to pretend you're sick.You're gonna have to be a good actor so you can fool everybody.It helps if your best friends' father has a Ferrari.It makes it all cooler.I'm kidding of course.You kids should stay at school.I'm graduating tomorrow and I haven't skipped any day of school.And no, I am not a geek.Now a few words about the movie before I finish.This is the king of all high school movies.It's entertaining, it's funny, it's serious in times.It has everything you can ever ask for a teen movie.Another thing to mention about the movie is Ferris' straight to camera monologues he gives.That thing works in this movie.That's some wise stuff he says there.It's a very well written movie.Much more intelligent than teen movies generally.Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a movie for all the high school students and those who feel like one.

Review title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off joyously shows that perhaps we should all pull a sickie occasionally.
Review_body: As with many classics which have been circulating around the historical presence of cinema, it's stupendously easy to be intimidated by a specific film. Ferris Bueller was one of those films. Endlessly referenced in pop culture, frequently discussed as one of the best teen comedies ever and directed by the 80s maestro himself that was John Hughes. Would I, a soulless British twenty-something, enjoy the fiascos and shenanigans of one Ferris Bueller? Turns out, yes! Ferris, nearing the end of the school year, decides to fake being sick so that he can explore the historical and cultural impact of downtown Chicago. However, hot on his tail are his sister and school Dean who are suspicious of his frequent absences.Not all films have to be heavy-hitting dramas tackling taboo subjects in a bid to evoke some repressed powerful emotions. Some can just be mild entertainment for the sake of depicting a joyous journey. Y'know, bringing a smile to one's face. And I know what you're thinking. "I hate smiling". Yes, well so do I. But I can guarantee, if you watch Ferris Bueller convince his friend Cameron to drive his father's 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California Spyder (believe me, had to look that one up!) or generating American buzz by slaying a infectious rendition of "Twist and Shout", you will not only smile. But laugh also. I laughed. I actually laughed!The sheer bombastic feel-good nature of this rather plotless comedy is too good to pass up. I mean, Hughes wrote the screenplay in less than a week, so clearly had intentions on character focus rather than an absorbing plot. And, despite a blasé hedonistic approach that lacked purpose other than being an exploration of Chicago (who goes to an art museum when pulling a sickie?), the intent narrative structure relying on characters worked to a certain extent.This is a film about the eponymous Ferris Bueller. His sly, meticulous and often charming personality makes him relatable. Fourth-wall breaks and all, a now legendary technique used to elaborate Ferris' inner thoughts. Broderick did a smashing job, and I couldn't envisage anyone else in the role. It was his, and his alone. Ruck as the constantly anxious Cameron also ensued some hilarity within his performance and was just as memorable as Ferris. Just a shame that the character of Sloane tagged along and had no substantial depth. In fact, she had no depth at all! An unexpected frustration from a screenplay written by Hughes, who usually carefully creates every character. Dean Rooney and Jeanie Bueller were also highlights and elevated the joyous buoyancy of the narrative. And there's something satisfying about a young Charlie Sheen playing a drug addict. I don't know why, but it amused me.The third act wrapped up too quickly for my own personal taste, with no real obstacles to overcome. Aside from Cameron confronting his father, to which we never see, Ferris surprisingly had an easy day which hampered the investment I had for the overall story. Ferris Bueller is essentially the "Easy Mode" of Chicago. Banging soundtrack though! "Love Missile F1-11"? What a tune!And to end the film with a poignant message, well, that's a Hughes film for you. Quotable, innovative and quite frankly a jubilant day off from start to finish. Despite my reservations for an actual plot, I would happily watch it repeatedly. Just so I can sing "Shoot it up"!

Review title: What Movie Grinches Gave This Movie Less Than 10?
Review_body: A movie completely dominated by its titular character and yet still enjoys amazing performance by the rest of the cast.Filled with iconic moments that continue to be enjoyed.Its funny, clever, charming and sweet without over doing it.This movie will be spoken about, referenced and enjoyed for decades to come :)

This is one of John Hughes classic movies, such as Sixteen Candles, The Breakfast Club, Pretty in Pink, Trains Planes and Automobiles, Home Alone, She's Having a Baby, and Uncle Buck (to name a few).The quality of this teen/coming of age movie has help up over the decades. The big thing about this is the silly interaction with veteran comedic actors and the Magic Realism that he creates for both the characters and the theme.Starring Matthew Broderick, Mia Sara, Alan Ruck, Jeffrey Jones, Jennifer Grey, Cindy Pickett, Lyman Ward, Edie McClurg, Charlie Sheen, and has cameos from other notable people, like Louie Anderson, Richard Edson, Larry Flash Jenkins, Kristy Swanson and Ben Stein.The movie takes place around Chicago, which is the city of choice for Hughes movies. Ferris runs around town with his friends, going to Wrigley Field, borrowing a classic vintage Ferrari car and going to the Metropolitan Museum, and a fancy restaurant, while being chased by his overbearing school Principal, Ed Rooney.

Review title: You can't get a better teen comedy. A movie that breaks frontiers!
Review_body: Seriously, this is a movie that display the real life of a teenager.See, I'm a Mexican 23 year old male. I had an American girlfriend who urged me to watch this movie. I was skeptical taking in consideration that this movie was highly compared with "American Pie" and many other American teen flicks.Well I decided to give it a try some years ago and I was impressed. This movie fits on any part of the world. Ferris has every single and possible clichè that perfectly shows how a teenager's life can be.The situations are hilarious and make you wanna return to high school times. Really! I couldn't stop praising American humor that does not necessary needs scatological references or clichèd mockery against minorities."Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is the perfect teenager movie with clever jokes, situations, and extremely likable characters. The chemistry between Ferris, his girlfriend, and his best buddy is simply charming.Ferries takes into practice the "carpe diem" phrase and teaches how a single day can change your life as a student. Sure, we all got responsibilities during that phase but come on, some spice is always necessary if not obligatory.My favorite scenes include the infamous car action where the two valet parking guys ride with the Star Wars score in the background; the way the Principal tells a girl "your ass is mine" thinking it's Ferris; the ending; the song "Oh Yeah" which is now used in "The Simpsons" as the Duff Beer theme, etc.Ah, this is a great movie that hasn't suffered from the strays of time. The best American teen movie to date. Forget about the "American Pie" boom.

Ferris buellers day off is is yet another very fun and enjoyable 80s teen comedy that holds up still today and it has a lot of very good staff in it,broderick as our lead ferris bueller was very charming and he was defienetly the best part of a film,rest of cast was also very enjoyable and interesting to follow their paths and stories,i think that many of young people can relate to this movie,cause most of us in high school were trying to achieve a one day without school and responsabilities ,and for sure i am one of them,story,script and direction were also pretty impressive and strong,to me it was even far better then movies like this deserve,ferris buellers day off was yet another great 80s teen comedy about breaking rules and geting some fun for our selfs

Review title: Have you ever thought of ways in which you could skip school, without getting caught? Ferris Bueller did think of it and he found a way out! Bless him!
Review_body: Skipping school without getting caught. Yes, it can be done. Watch how Ferris Bueller did it and how he enjoyed life to the fullest with his friends, far away from those boring teachers...One of the most popular teenage comedies of the entire eighties. To this very day, 30-40 year old folks still think back with fond memories to this movie, because it was the ultimate escape dream for every teenager in the eighties who was sick and tired of school.All good? Mwah, it isnt a gripping drama or shocking story. It is what it is. It's a bit silly, yet charming as well. Slowburning, yet so enticing simultaneously. Unbelievable at times, yet still so likeable. I still love this classic to this very day, as much as I did when I was a teenager. The movie comes across a bit more timid and slow nowadays, then when I watched it back in the eighties, but the charm is still as fresh and seductive as ever before. What a joy to watch!

There's a very easy formula to whether you'll like Ferris Bueller's Day Off or not. And that is whether you find the main character charming or not. Because if you do, this is a nice little comedy about a high school student taking a day off to unwind, to clear his head and to have fun with his friends. And perhaps even help one of those friends stand up to his father.Unfortunately I belong to the latter camp. And to me this is a movie where an entitled little brat decides one day that rules don't apply to him. He blatantly lies to pretty much all the people in his life to get what he wants. He creates dangerous situations, destroys property and doesn't really seem to care about the feelings of others if they're not in alignment with his owns.I really sympathize with Ferris's male friend, Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck), here. He's also skipping school on that day, but that's because he's legitimately sick. Nevertheless, he gets dragged out of bed, because Ferris can't possibly have his friend ruining his day by not being there, whether he's sick or not. Plus he needs Cameron's dad's car, because he deserves a sweet ride on this day of days. Sure, the sickness thing is quickly brushed aside and never mentioned again, because the movie can't have you questioning Ferris's decisions, but it's still there. And I remember it.Granted, the movie does have good jokes in it, good scenes. Ferris, played by Matthew Broderick, is a charismatic fellow, explaining why he can get away with all this anarchy.Still, I can't say I'd recommend the film. To me it's filled with bad stereotypes and mixed messages. Some people really like this movie, some people outright worship it. So I guess there's something in it. I just don't see it.

Review title: "80's Classic That Teaches Us To Enjoy Life Once In A While!"
Review_body: Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara, Jeffrey Jones, Jennifer Grey, Edie McGlurg, Cindy Pickett, Lyman Ward and Charlie Sheen star in John Hughes' 1986 comedy. Broderick (Wargames) plays Chicago teen, Ferris Bueller who decides to play hooky from school. Ruck (Speed) plays his ill pal, Cameron Frye and Sara (Legend) plays Ferris' girlfriend, Sloane Peterson who join him. Jones (Beetlejuice) plays principal, Ed Rooney who learns what Ferris is up to and tries to catch him. Grey (Dirty Dancing) plays Ferris' sister, Jeannie who is jealous of him for being able to fool everyone and get all the attention. Pickett (Hot to Trot) and Ward (Planes, Trains & Automobiles) play their parents, Katie & Tom, McGlurg (Back to School) plays Rooney's secretary, Grace and Sheen (Platoon) plays a boy at a police station Jeannie meets. I grew up watching this 80's classic and liked it since. It's definitely one of Broderick & the late, Hughes' best I recommend.

I love this man, his work, his sense of humor, and his way to say important things by comedy.However, I see that the comic scenes here were less than what they should be, or maybe it's just me who waited for more! Plus, somehow I think that the real hero of the movie's drama was (Alan Ruck) as (Cameron Frye) the friend, because he is the only person who changed through the journey of the day / the movie, as he was dying because of his fear to do what he really wants, as the opposite of (Ferris Bueller). However, at the end, he became capable of facing his fear to be what he wants. But on the other hand, the original hero, or the movie's title character, remained the same till the very end; as the selfsame liar, swindler, who's enjoying the moment without any concern, or whatsoever about the future!Maybe (Hughes) was showing a nice symbol for being loose, released and free just to teach us, as the regular bourgeois, how to loosen a little, so not to miss the train of life. The beauty of it is that (Ferris Bueller), with all of his values, isn't harmful. Look at his frauds; for instance, he didn't run away from school to do drugs, or robe a bank. He went with his friends to an art museum for God's sake. I tried, so many times, to do such a visit with my own friends, and after the school time, but I couldn't make them to! And (Hughes) presented him as that intelligent wicked, to the extent that he could beat any future problems, especially with the love of the people. For example, he vanquished the principal too many times by his cleverness, having the ultimate victory by his sister's last minute rescue, when she finally believed in his crazy deeds and his lively philosophy. Therefore (Bueller) was just a symbol, a lovely mentor, more than a guy who would change. Although it's not as strong as being weaker, or suffering from defects sometimes, but (Hughes), by this dealing, didn't only venerate the character itself, he also meant to disclose our frailty and failure, compared to such a young man.I loved the glee childish feeling of the whole movie, the condensation of all the events in less than a daytime, the special appearance of (Charlie Sheen) in a brief yet suitable role, so (Jeffrey Jones) as the poor clumsy principal who looks and walks as so confident (Dirty Harry)! Plus those fresh ideas: the school's contribution for the fake sick (Bueller), redressing the car's counter by the hard way, the mechanical robot as (Bueller)'s clone in bed. And yes, I loved the main character and the performance of (Matthew Broderick), but I just think that he was more sensitive and less bravery to be (Bueller). Of course (Broderick) is a gentle comedian and his acting here is so vivacious, however his soft presence was one of some reasons that made me think that he wasn't as mad, bold and indifferent as (Ferris Bueller), or maybe not as any (Ferris Bueller) of who I've met.At last, you must ask yourself with confusion, as well as fury, where is that great writer?, and where are his enjoyable, innocent, and meaningful comedies?, and how could he let us in the hands of so-called comedies which have tons of toilet humor, and don't say something that lives longer than a week!

Review title: " When Cameron was in Egypt land. Let my Cameron go ."
Review_body: In every school throughout the country, there are usually two certainties. There is a rules first and policy strict principal and consequently a very popular guy who becomes his Nemesis. There is no written code as to who is the most forceful, but it's easy to discover, if you're either a staff member or a school attending student. This film depicts an average day in the life of Ferris Bueller the most popular boy (Matthew Broderick) in school. Deciding he wants a day off, he convinces his parents Lyman Ward and Jennifer Grey) he is sick, who then advise him to stay home. Thereafter he cajoles his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) and his girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) to join him. However, the Principal of the school Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is not fooled and plans to catch him ditching. Making matters worse is Ferris's sister (Cindy Pickett) who wants to see him get caught. Charlie Sheen and Ben Stein make brief appearances and add to the overall festive day which sees Ferris breeze through a trip to the city, a visit to a posh restaurant, a museum and an unexpected appearance in a parade to sing Twist and Shout. All in all, a fun day for the audience who is literally taken for a joy ride. Recommended to anyone who thinks they deserve to a day off or just to take on the school principal. ****

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is considered a classic from the 1980s and one of John Hughes' best films. And it is a film deserving of this reputation because it was simply a fun film with well-writing jokes and lines and had some notable visual gags. It was a film that shows like The Simpsons, Hey Arnold, and The Goldbergs made their own versions and Family Guy stole some jokes. Ferris was a bit of an entitled ass but Matthew Broderick gave the character enough likeability and charm to override his selfishness. A little delight of a film.

Review title: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it"
Review_body: It'd been years since I last watched 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986),' and, as a young adult, I was struck by just how tame Ferris Bueller's day off actually was. In my memory, I'd concocted all sorts of exciting and dangerous escapades. But Ferris (Matthew Broderick), it seems, is quite intent on emulating adulthood, and his choice of destinations is characteristically "grown up": the stock market exchange, an upper-class restaurant, a museum. He asks Sloane (Mia Sara) to marry him, lightly but nevertheless earnestly. Even his choice of parade music ("Danke Schoen" by Wayne Newton, "Twist and Shout" by The Beatles) harks to an older generation. "Life moves pretty fast," Ferris tells us, and yet he seems intent on accelerating the process.Spontaneity comes with youth. At first glance, we might consider Ferris Bueller to be spontaneous. But is he? Abe Froman, touted as "The Sausage King of Chicago," never arrives for his three-person reservation at the restaurant. Could Ferris not himself have made the reservation, and simply feigned spontaneity for the benefit of his friends? We've seen for ourselves the cunning genius with which Ferris creates illusions – that he is too ill to attend school, that he is sound asleep in bed – and this is just another deception, only now he's even fooling the viewer. This is perhaps referenced at the film's end, when Sloane suggests "You knew what you were doing when you woke up this morning, didn't you?", to which Ferris coyly replies, "Me? Na." (Thanks to Scott Murray of "Senses of Cinema" for first planting this idea in my head).I haven't mentioned Cameron (Alan Ruck) yet, but he's the most important character. Whereas Ferris remains his usual glossy self throughout (whoever that may be), the uptight and neglected Cameron learns to stand up for yourself, particularly towards his cold (and appropriately absent) father. There's one particularly striking sequence in the Chicago Museum of Art, in which Cameron studies Georges Seurat's "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte," fixating so closely on the image of a mother and child that the child's face becomes indistinguishable amid the texture of the canvas. Is this a deconstructionist hint, referencing the artistic medium in the same way that Ferris' fourth-wall breaking does so? Or does it have the opposite intent? The more we look into it, the less truth we see. So just have a fun day, damn it.

Review title: We could all use a day off like "Ferris"...
Review_body: In the late producer/writer/director John Hughes's blockbuster 1986 teen-comedy "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," cool, easy-going Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) fakes being terribly ill in order to spend a care-free day in downtown Chicago with his beautiful girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) and his best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck).All the while, the trio are pursued by Edward R. Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), the dean of their high school who's out to catch them by any means necessary, and Ferris's younger sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey), who resents his free-spirited ways and for always getting away with his complex schemes.That alone would be enough to make the movie last for its two hour running time, but John Hughes, that "adolescent philosopher" (in the words of the late film critic Roger Ebert) who also made "Sixteen Candles" (1984) and "The Breakfast Club" (1985) and understood the teenage condition better than anyone else in his time, seems to have other things on his mind.In keeping up with one key theme from his two previous features, Hughes examines how the events of a single fateful day can forever change the lives of his teenage protagonists. In "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," Ferris Bueller faking being sick in order to ditch school is actually less about him having a good time in downtown Chicago than it is about helping his high-strung best friend Cameron develop some much-needed self-respect in order to stand up to a bullying and neglectful father. (In short, while the film is ultimately about Matthew Broderick's title character, its true emotional center is Alan Ruck's troubled Cameron Frye and his overcoming a dysfunctional family life.)Of course, this doesn't mean that "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is devoid of the usual teen movie antics. This movie is laugh-out funny; its laughs haven't diminished one bit over the years. I haven't seen "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" in a good long while; the film was a perennial favorite of mine during my early teen years in the late '90s, and I remember watching the film almost to the point of memorization during that time. In watching the film again today for the first time in years, it has yet to lose any of its appeal. Matthew Broderick was perfect for the role of Ferris Bueller, and it remains his most famous film role to date - though, one should not overlook his commanding performance in the Civil War drama "Glory" (1989). He's as appealing and charming as he's ever been, or will ever be.Now here, and in closing, we get a little bit personal. In watching this film today, it was a very conscious decision on my part. I realized I myself needed a "day off" - by enjoying a movie that's about leisure and taking it easy and forgetting your problems. And just having a good laugh. In getting over the recent failure of a really difficult relationship, I found a sense of peace and catharsis in this film that I didn't realize would be there. It's proof to me, that this movie isn't really dated - though it is very much a product of its era in the mid-'80s.I would recommend that anyone who needs a "day off" from the troubles of everyday life, watch "Ferris Bueller's Day Off." I promise you, it'll be the best "day off" you'll ever have.10/10P. S.: And Ben Stein is utterly hilarious in one of the single funniest, completely improvised scenes in film history. And Charlie Sheen's brief cameo, while funny, also turned out to be eerily prophetic...

Broderick banked off that boyish charm that made him so popular on the Broadway stage (Brighton Beach Memoirs) and brought it to this witty laugh ride about a high schooler who one day, just didn't want to go to school and puts himself and his friends in constant mayhem and jeopardy. Broderick is perfect, but it is Jeffrey Jones who gives a searing comic potryal of Ed Rooney, a Mr. Weatherbee-like principal wanting to catch Ferris in only act of treachery; holding him back for one more year of high school. John Hughes is at his best here. The dialogue for this film has received such a following that it has even been printed on shirts and recited at parties by true fans of the film. I don't blame them. It's a classic!

Review title: Wild, Carefree Hijinx with the Ultimate Coasting Senior
Review_body: An unusually sprawling, giddy production from John Hughes's most fruitful period as a director. Where his preceding efforts like The Breakfast Club and Sixteen Candles were rich, moody tales set almost unanimously in small high schools, Ferris is a plucky, enthusiastic fantasy that breaks free from the confines of an institutional setting and celebrates life outside the walls. Matthew Broderick brings the brash, popular title character to life with an energy that's so infectious it's easy to overlook a few ridiculous twists and turns, and the plot takes full advantage, pushing the envelope as far as it can feasibly get away with. Great comedic timing, an astoundingly deep, versatile cast of characters and the rocketing pace of an out-of-control avalanche help make this a timeless comedy that's aged extremely gracefully. The only sticking point, really, is the totally '80s wardrobe.

Review title: Decades have gone by and new generations continue to relate to this comedy
Review_body: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."In only a span of six years, John Hughes managed to direct some of the best comedies from the 80's which surprisingly hold up very well to this day. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is still regarded as a classic in the genre and despite being a simple mainstream movie, Matthew Broderick delivers such an iconic performance that many teens continue to fall in love with his character as the decades pass. The gags are handled with perfect comedic timing and the soundtrack has become such a recognizable tune in pop culture. I don't know exactly what it is that has made this such a beloved film amongst American teenagers, but it seems to transcend generations over time because of its accessibility. It's a light comedy about being young and mischievous that simply seems to delight and captivate audiences who are looking for some form of escape. It's rare for a film with a simple premise like this to continue captivating audiences over time and even those teens who watched it in the 80's and are now mature decide to go back and revisit it for nostalgic purposes or to introduce it to their now teenage sons. This is just further proof that no one had the comedic touch that Hughes had in the 80's with his teenage comedies. I still prefer Planes, Trains, and Automobiles as his go to movie, but Ferris Bueller was a delightful experience. I look forward to catching up with some more of his classic films. I remember having seen classic scenes of this movie, but this was my first time watching it from beginning to end and I was delighted and surprised because I didn't think I would ever like Broderick as much as I did here. This is by far his best performance.The film takes place in Chicago where we are introduced to Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick), a senior in High School who has decided to take the day off from school by fooling his parents into thinking he's sick. Ferris constantly breaks the fourth wall and speaks to the audience letting them know what he's thinking. His plan is so well thought out that even his friends at school think he's developed a serious condition and are trying to raise money for his treatment. He's the sort of guy that everyone in school dreams of being and his life motto is simply to enjoy life to the fullest. He personifies the spirit of youth and that is what makes him such a likable guy despite acting irresponsable at times. The only people who don't believe him are his sister, Jeanie (Jennifer Grey), who is angry everyone keeps on falling for his lame excuses, and the school principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) who is determined to discover his lie and make him lose the school year for it. Ferris has everything planned out very carefully and is convinced his plan will work. He calls his best friend, Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck), who has also taken a sick leave, but in his case he's really feeling bad. Ferris convinces him to come pick him up and together they come up with a plan to help Ferris's girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara), get out of classes. In a hilarious scene the duo call Principal Rooney impersonating Sloane's father and asking him to give his daughter permission to leave the school because her grandmother has passed away. Ferris then convinces Cameron to take his father's Ferrari and the adventure begins for the three friends through the streets of Chicago. Hughes has always excelled as a screenwriter and he is responsible for some of the funniest comedies from the 80's and 90's. He didn't direct as many films, but he has been involved with many scripts. In Ferris Bueller he seems to have written a simple but perfectly executed script of a young teenager who is trying to live life to the fullest. He could've come out as cocky, but there is some heart to his character and it becomes incredibly hard not to root for him, especially when Hughes put so much emphasis during the opening scene portraying the dullness of High School life and then introducing Principal Rooney as such a douchebag. The scenes where he is desperately trying to uncover Ferris's plan are incredibly cartoonish and over the top, but it is funny nonetheless. There are also a few heart felt scenes between Ferris and Cameron which make his character even more likable despite his bad influence. Broderick delivers the performance of his career and there are very few actors who can break the fourth wall the way he did here without interrupting the flow of the story (the other who comes to mind is John Cusack). There is also a great scene in which Ferris covers one of The Beatle's song in a parade that simply adds to the already amazing soundtrack. Jones is hilarious as Rooney and it's not often that these over the top villains are portrayed well. He never comes off annoying, and that's something difficult to achieve. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a comedy that has transcended time and generations and it may come as a surprise to many considering it's such a light and simple premise, but Hughes manages to work his magic. http://estebueno10.blogspot.com/

I watched this one again a few days ago. I was going to say that it hadn't aged well. But on reflection, I realized the sad fact that it is me who hasn't aged well. Teenage movies can be funny, or poignant, or dramatic, but one thing they can't be for me anymore is relevant. I recall thinking that this film was awesome back in the day. Now, it is amusing, but that's really all. Maybe a younger person can deliver a better comment.

Variety was way off the mark when it stated that Ferris Bueller's Day Off exhibits John Hughes on an off day. This is one of the high points of the teen-comedy genre and probably the best of John Hughes's films (only The Breakfast Club can be considered a rival).Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is a teenager from a rich Chicago family. Adored by the pupils at his school, Ferris is the ultimate Mr. Popular with everyone apart from his spiteful sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) and the school's obsessive principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones). One hot summer's day, Ferris feels the urge to skip school so he fools his parents into believing that he has a fever. He then enlists the aid of his depressed buddy Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) to plan the ultimate adventure. First, they "borrow" Cameron's father's classic Ferrarri, then they engineer a story to get Ferris's girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) out of school, before heading off to Chicago to live the dream. On their agenda are such excesses as lunch in a swanky restaurant, a visit to Sears Tower, a trip to the baseball stadium, a whistle-stop tour of the museum, an interlude at the stock exchange.... at one point, Ferris even hijacks a parade float and performs a Beatles tune for the adoring crowds! Meanwhile, Ed Rooney spends the entire day attempting to catch Ferris out, proving once and for all that he isn't the dream son his parents believe him to be.What makes Ferris Bueller's Day Off work is the simplicity of the premise and the skillful accumulation of comic moments that are built around it. Jones has a fabulous time in his role as the ever-suffering school principal; Lyman Ward is hilarious as Ferris's gullible, goofy father; Ruck is by turns funny and pitiful as the melancholy Cameron Frye; Grey perfects a bitchy scowl as Ferris's sister; and, if you watch closely, there's a truly outstanding cameo from Charlie Sheen as a streetwise junkie who melts Jeanie's heart. All this is held together by Broderick's good work as the central character. There are some terrific comedy moments, the best of which for me are when Ferris's father gets held up by a car being erratically driven by a 4 ft octogenarian, and the scene where a busty nurse turns up to "cheer-up" the poorly Ferris. Many critics and reviewers have noted the sentimental vein that runs through the film, and it's true that it spoils things slightly, but on the whole this is an irresistible comedy and an absolute must for anyone who enjoys a good teen flick.

Review title: Ferry Bueller isn't as good as he looks.
Review_body: This was a fun movie. The plot is very weird to be honest. Ferris Bueller takes a day off from school and the school principle tries to prove that he fakes it. This movie has many great jokes, but whole concept is just so weird. Ferris is good guy in heart but he does so many intentional evil things: he impersonates people, he forces his friend to let him use his dad's car, also he build a fanbase of students which he propogates to be rebellous, the list would go on and on. The principle is just doing his job he tries his best to keep kids in school, he tries to get Bueller so he could punnish him and maybe his fandom would reduce. As I said this is a fun and funny movie, but the concept is just so weird.

Review title: Refreshing Hughes teen flick one of his best
Review_body: Teen flick king John Hughes is writer/director for this escapist movie about how high school kids should try not to let life pass them by in the prime of their youth.A great boppy soundtrack which includes Yello's "Oh Yeah" and "Twist and Shout" from the Beatles accompanies Matthew Broderick's refreshing turn as the excessively confident and immensely popular young Ferris. He is perfectly cast, as is Mia Sara, the attractive girlfriend, and Alan Ruck, Ferris' ever paranoid and worrying friend Cameron who supplies the trio with their 'choice' transport, a 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California. Also great value are Jeffrey Jones as the Dean of Students from hell who is determined to catch Ferris, and Jennifer Grey as the insanely jealous sister with an attitude. Charlie Sheen drops by with a cameo as a drug fiend with some friendly advice.While one of Hughes' best teen comedies, the movie still has his trademark misplaced scenes. Much of the attempts at drama are corny, the serious moments don't work and any moral messages fall flat. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" works best sending itself and other films up. Some very clever comedy is evident and Hughes produces some hilarious scenes including two terrific running gags involving firstly an over the top "Save Ferris" campaign and secondly a little tune called "Auf Wiedersehn". Broderick talks to the camera through much of the film which proves to be relatively effective.Friday, May 19, 1995 - Video

Review title: Not just a classic of the 80s, but of any decade
Review_body: Matthew Broderick looked so brilliant in those days. While this film single handedly made him Ferris Bueller forever, at least this is a film that can be seen all throughout the years without dating too badly. Sure, the music and props will signify a time of discontent and bad hairdos, but the idealistic look of a man simply wanting to ditch school has never been made more daringly and charmingly. Everything about this film was gold, from the postmodern "conversations" with the audience to the little back stories which seem to shape the overall canvas of the film. While Alan Ruck was way too old to play in this movie, at least he proved to be a great opposite to the cool and nonchalant Ferris. Gross-out comedies may now be the norm, at least we can look back to this film and enjoy a good, genuine laugh.

Matthew Broderick is perfectly cast as the title character. Its the only time in his career he did a John Hughes movie and boy did he pick a good one, but its mostly because of him that its so good.  Ferris enjoys life, has a ton of friends and a very pretty girlfriend named Sloane Peterson.  The only strain in his life is his best friend Cameron who is prone to anxiety attacks, wild mood swings and general unpleasantness.
One day Ferris decides he cannot bear school so fakes an illness to spend the day with Sloane & Cameron.  They go to Chicago, see the city from way above, go to the Art Institute of Chicago and a Cubs game, have lunch in an upscale restaurant, and join in on a parade.  While all that is going on, Ferris is being found out by the principal Ed Rooney.  His sister is also after blood because she knows he's faking it and is jealous of his ability to get what he wants. Its all for fun and a lot of it works, but for me the movie drags considerably when Cameron starts in on his litany of problems.  I am not unsympathetic to a teenagers problems, but they are in the wrong movie. 
The best thing about this movie is the parade.  Ferris yells 'Twist and Shout' by the Beatles and all of Chicago joins in.  Something about all those people, all getting along and laughing and smiling and having a great time, makes me really love that scene.Lastly, what a car! And I don't even drive, but if I had that car I'd learn in a hurry!  8/10.

I honestly couldn't tell you how many times I've seen "Ferris Bueller's Day Off", but it's got to be close to double digits at this point. I'm not one of those people who thinks Ferris Bueller is a perfect movie, nor do I think it's one of the funniest movies ever made- it's not- but it is a film that I like to come back to every once in a while because I enjoy spending time with the characters and the situations they find themselves in, which, while sometimes a bit overblown, are still enjoyable to revisit. Ferris Bueller is about pitch perfect when it comes to finding an easy-going, feel good film, and, more than thirty years later, it's still incredibly iconic.

Well, I saw it originally in the theater in my mid-twenties. And now 35-years later saw it was on Netflix so why not? It's a classic comedy for sure as it still makes me laugh out loud. Broderick gives John Hughe's vision the perfect on-screen protragonist for a true hoot of an ultimate day off from school. It could only be, however, so entertaining as the surrounding cast fit like hand-in-glove. Momentarily tealing the show on many ocassions was Jeffrey Jones as the luckless principal Ed Rooney. The combination of Broderick and Jones will live in infamy! This was worth my wait...hilarious!

Review title: A classic comedy caper of the 1980's.
Review_body: Such a wacky comedy caper, which plays like a teen version of 'Alfie'; where the focus is on a school kid who pretends to be ill to get off school (once again). Some of the very best comedic situations and the cast of chosen actors are just perfect to pull this one off. You can totally understand how some state this is as their all time favourite film and innocent in the most immoral way possible. Charming in places and containing subtle details in relationships. Also a great turn by Charlie Sheen (in a cameo appearance). A comedy classic that helps define the whole of the 80's decade.

This movie is consistently funny and entertaining. The characters are interesting and well acted. If you're looking for a fun time, then go watch this movie. This is a classic that holds up. Everything about this movie is absolutely fantastic and I'm struggling to come up with any criticisms for it. I highly recommend this movie. If you haven't seen it already, then go watch it asap.

Well, this movie started off really well, in a fast and entertaining pace. However, after some while, I could guess exactly where this movie was going, and surely knew it wouldn't bring anything new or extraordinary to the genre. Even Charlie Sheen worked in this picture, looking like a vampire from "Twilight"; I could barely recognize him being that young-- I'm more used to his age in "Two and a Half Men" era. Main character is a sharpie guy that fools everybody and, in the end, gets away with murder. His sister, a correct girl that does everything right, ends up being labeled as the bad guy off the story. These scenes are at least useful to remind us that good people always end up being misunderstood. Obviously this film inspired many of modern teen comedies, such as "American Pie", "Not Another Teen Movie", "Road Trip", among others. I confess that I enjoyed 1988's "License to Drive" much more than this one, even thought that movie copied many aspects of this. Also, Marlon Wayans' productions are much better in making you laugh. All in all, it's an interesting movie for the time it was released, but offers nothing different of modern comedies.

Review title: "It is his fault he didn't lock the garage."
Review_body: This is a film that will lift your spirits every time. A real feel good movie, it delivers with a great story and first rate comedy. The film itself is funny and entertaining to watch from start to finish, with some scenes that feature a lovely Ferrari 250 GT California, which does get the attention of Ferris, who wants to take the Ferrari out for a spin.While it may be difficult to watch Ferris Bueller run up slides and jump on trampolines all to get home with a serious eye, one must admit that when one looks back at school, some things are like that, even if only in your mind. The movie has very funny jokes and slapstick. The parade downtown with Ferris on the float singing "Twist And Shout" is a showstopper, and a memorable cinema scene. Broderick is good. He brings Ferris' cocky charm to life and makes it real. Grey is perfect as the sister from hell. Overall, this is a great, funny, poignant movie, a tribute to living, instead of getting caught up in life.Overall rating: 8 out of 10.

I've always thought this movie would have worked better if the Ferris Bueller character was less of an inconsiderate dick. I mean: this is the protagonist you're supposed to root for here, was it so difficult to give him some more redeeming qualities or something? Sure, he's supposed to be a Mahoney-like rebel that fights the system and whatnot, but is the system in this movie really that awful? Oh no, Rooney checks if Ferris is ditching school! That's his job of course, but how dare he actually do it? Apart from that, the movie is just a typical John Hughes film, coming of age and such and such. There are some laughs here and there, but mostly it's about teens trying to cope with growing up. This is done a bit better in "The Breakfast Club" though, that movie has more compelling characters. This one focuses a lot on a rather whiny Alan Ruck, too much I'd say. I do love the tertiary role for Charlie Sheen though, that was classic. Overall I never really felt the full appeal of this movie, though it isn't really bad either.

This movie is a comedy classic of the 80's! Ferris Bueller(Matthew Broderick) is a teenager boy who thinks that ''life moves pretty fast. if you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it.'' He is a master of skipping classes and very popular not only in his school, but in his city. His parents always believes in his excuses to not go to school, and his sister (Jennifer Grey)hates him more than everything for that.One day, he, his best friend Cameron Frye(Alan Ruck)and Bueller's girlfriend Sloane Peterson(Mia Sara)decides to miss a day in school to walk away in New York. This makes the school's director,Ed Rooney, stay mad, and he wants to prove that Ferris is lying for his parents no matter what. Very cool and with a nice message of enjoy your life while you can!

An American comedy; A story about a teenager who skips school for a taste of carpe diem around Chicago and so he can help his best friend win some self-respect. The school dean is hot on their trail but Ferris Bueller is always one step ahead. All of the adults are dim-witted and one-dimensional and the solutions to teenage problems are quite simplistic but there is warmth, whimsicality, sweetness, good humour and the film's heart is in the right place.
One of the best movie of there but is so underrated it deserves more than this

Until the arrival of American Pie, FBDO was truly in a class of its own: unlike Sixteen Candles or Breakfast Club which weren't comedies or Weird Science which is farce, Ferris is a comic creation for ever.It is a true classic.It contains the ideal: the ideal cool teen who can make the world work better for him, oneupmanship on family, school, and society, and all done in a way that rocks - it's never mean or cruel, just fun...For an absolute blast with tons of great lines and action you really can't choose a better teen comedy than this - the archetypal teen comedy of the 80s and one that is still immensely watchable time after time.

Review title: Nostalgic for a certain age group but otherwise unremarkable
Review_body: More than twenty years after its release "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is something of a cult classic. Simply put, it's the story of one young man's struggle to take it easy.The title character is played by Matthew Broderick and, for me, that's where the problems start. I'm not a Broderick fan at the best of times and here it's twice as bad since he's playing a character that I find it very difficult to like. I blame John Hughes's script for giving little or no justification of why Ferris is almost universally liked.Ferris's pal Cameron (Alan Ruck) is a little more engaging but his girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) serves no discernible function other than that of eye-candy. Easily the best effort in the acting department comes from Jeffrey Jones who gives an iconic performance as the dean who's out to get Ferris.Considering these characters, the story is unsurprisingly slight. The trio basically drive around town in a Ferrari and supposedly live life to its fullest, though in actuality doing little of consequence. Adding just a smidgen of depth to the proceedings is the introduction of a crisis that will force Cameron to decide if he'll finally start standing up to his father.The direction by John Hughes (who was also the screenwriter) is well handled though not particularly remarkable. The soundtrack is a typical 80's melange, complete with Yello's soon-to-be-cliché "Oh Yeah". I would say that the production values are solid but they're not going to turn the tide if you can't connect with the characters.If you have fond memories of this film then I doubt that they'll be dashed by seeing it again but if you didn't see it back in the 80's then I wouldn't really recommend seeing it now.

Review title: I never wanted to see this but finally did...
Review_body: 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off' is known as one of the great comedies of the 80s. And I was urged to watch it by the teenager in my life. Oh dear. The movie's premise is the title - the character of Ferris (played by a young and cute Matthew Broderick) being a liar who convinces other friends, via lies, to spend a day off with him. He fills the day with events, convincing a friend to steal his father's prized Porsch and another to say her grandmother is dead. He bulldozes his sister, his parents, school staff and his friends. I found him obnoxious and dishonest to the extreme of not liking the main character at all - thus I was in trouble in the first ten minutes of the film.To add to this turmoil, there is a caricature of a principal, Mr. Rooney, who endeavours to track down Ferris. Mr. Rooney winds up in extreme slapstick situations, quite unfunny to this viewer and far too frequently I was reminded of that awfulness "Home Alone", in fact a lot of the scenes are similar, complicated gadgets rigged up at the last minute to foil the "bad guy", in this case the school principal doing an extreme form of his job.Nothing really makes sense. Jennifer Grey does a lot with her role as Ferris' sister as does Ferris' best friend. I guess confronting and beating authority is funny when you're say, twelve, but there's not much of a story for anyone in the other demographics of the movie watching public.3 out of 10, some of the music was really good, some scenes are quite striking, but not enough to carry the whole mess.

Review title: The film that started it all...
Review_body: ,,, my irrational hatred of Matthew Broderick, that is!  I saw this film and initially thought I hated Broderick, which was puzzling, since I'd previously found him amiable enough in "WarGames" and "Project X".  Then I caught "The Cable Guy" on TV and realised that it wasn't necessarily Broderick that I hated, but Ferris Bueller!   Some people admire the character's brash personality and hip posing.  I don't.  Every time Bueller was onscreen I wanted to punch the smug, cocky little **** into the middle of next week.  Was it just me?  My repeated fantasies of doing immeasurable harm to Broderick with various sharp implements were just that, fantasies.  What's worse, is that I will never get my chance to exact revenge on Ferris Bueller, due to the minor inconvenience of his non-existence...  Despite these barely checked psychopathic tendencies at the mention of Bueller, I found it impossible to dislike the film.  It screams "good natured wish fulfillment movie" at every turn, is pretty inventive, and gets you wondering "What would I do?" at certain points.  The cast all have fun will their roles, but Matthew Broderick's status as a C list star and John Hughes' current record of cr*p movies is living proof that they are being punished by a higher power for their hateful rendering of such an obnoxius little prig.    After all the bonhomie, only the hardest of hearts will remain staunch in their hatred of the movie.  The hatred of Ferris Bueller, however, will remain supreme.  The fact that certain characters in the movie also hated Ferris as much as I did made a slightly bitter pill that much easier to swallow.   This could have been a great teen movie, but the fact that I consider it slightly over-rated and want to kill the main character merely makes it good.  There is a silver lining to every cloud, though, and for "Ferris..." it is this:  the fact that I consider it only a 'good' movie means that I do not feel obligated to add it to my collection.  Were I motivated to rate it one mark higher than the 7 out of ten that I actually gave it, it would require purchase; and then I would have to grimace through an otherwise decent film every time 'HE' appeared onscreen...   One final point: you may think that my slight hysteria over the main character is something of an act, in a crude ploy to make my review more interesting and amusing.  This it MAY have done, but an act I can assure you it is not.  I think I'll go have a lie down now...

As a kid I liked this film but never got the big deal about it. As an adult I absolutely love it and find it so hilarious. Matthew Broderick (Godzilla) is so hilarious in the lead but the film's real MVP is Jennifer Grey ( Dirty Dancing) as his sister. She's hilariously negative and her seen with Charlie Sheen (Wraith) is everything. As well all know we just experience the best cut day ever and Broderick is wonderfully charasmatic. And don't let me forget Alan Ruck (Twister) as his worrisome, likable friend Cameron. All in all the film was deservedly a huge hit and is definitely a classic.4.5/5

Review title: A classic 80s comedy that never gets old
Review_body: What John Hughes brought to Hollywood in the 1980s was some classic teen comedies that went on by cult classics and brought inspiration to many other teen flicks. Hughes was a director that brought a new generation to the coming-of-age genre, and with films like 'Sixteen Candles, 'Weird Science', and his most famous 'The Breakfast Club', comedies that many teenagers today are sadly missing out on, as Hollywood has declined more and more with original comedies. In recent years, the teen comedy genre has been gradually losing its vibe with movies depraved of originality. This comedy directed by John Hughes, is one that stands high on the pinnacle of teen films. Matthew Broderick plays Ferris Bueller, a popular Chicago high school senior who's been known playing hooky from school by faking medical illnesses, unlike his sister Jeanie (played by Jennifer Grey) who's grown frustrated for being unsuccessful with ditching school without getting caught. On another day of skipping school, Bueller calls his reluctant best friend Cameron (played by Alan Ruck) and his underclassmen girlfriend Sloane (played by Mia Sara) to ditch school and join him on an adventure through the streets of downtown Chicago for a day of fun in Cameron's dad's 1961 Ferrari GT. Their truancy however, gains the attention of the school principal Ed Rooney (played by Jeffrey Jones) who's tried desperately to catch Bueller skipping school throughout the year, and goes the hunt for him, Sloane, and Cameron as they tour through Chicago on their day off.Ferris Bueller is definitely the role that defined Matthew Broderick's career, at least my opinion. Bueller is the kind of character who is easily likable and fun to watch, and his message about how life moves pretty fast and if you don't stop to look around every once in a while, you could miss it, a message many can relate to. The movie itself is very easy to relate, especially nowadays. When you reaches your senior year of high school, there's a good bet you developed a case of "senioritus" to the point where you might have planned a day to ditch school with your friends and go to the mall, got to the movies, etc. Yes, it is not the smartest decision to make and can handle you into trouble, but it is just the reminder that we were all teenagers at one point. Matthew Broderick brings such delight and charm to the titular character, and he is very funny in most scenes that it keeps viewers entertained and liking him as a character. Alan Ruck who plays his best friend Cameron who struggles to endure their day of fun from the fear of being caught by his hard-nosed father or Bueller's day who happens to be touring around Chicago the same day, is very great in his role and fun to watch, much like Mia Sara who plays Bueller's girlfriend. Every scene these three are in is entertaining, and provide viewers with some of the most quotable lines ever delivered in a comedy, as well as beautiful imagery of downtown Chicago and a nostalgic 80s soundtrack. And then there Jeffrey Jones as Ed Rooney, the sneaky principal has nothing better on his agenda than to catch Bueller skipping school and hold him back for another senior year. He provides some good comedic relief as we watch him involved in his unexpected shenanigans that make his day a living (and funny) hell. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is classic 80s comedy that certainly holds up today and something that everyone should watch, especially the teenagers who have yet to explore the 80s era of Hollywood. This movie is easily one of the most memorable movies of its decade, and quite quotable for many. If there is a friend you know who hasn't seen this, I strongly encourage you to make this a recommendation for him or her.

Review title: Never gets tired or old,kinda like the characters themselves
Review_body: Sharp-as-a-tack high schooler Ferris Bueller(Matthew Broderick,whose long and successful career since owes itself majoritively to this role over any other)decides on this particular sunny Chicago day that he should take another "sick day" off. His reasoning is simple: he feels that going off to school like a mindless drone when there are other things he'd like to do is a complete and pitiable waste. As he so famously puts it:"Life goes by fast,and if you don't slow down,you'll miss it. So slow down."To this end,he perfects a simple yet elaborate ruse to dupe his parents into having him stay home,much to the seething envy of his sister Jeanie(Jennifer Grey,who will always be Jeanie to me,much the way she's Baby from Dirty DAncing to others)who rarely gets this kind of parental benefit of a doubt. Next,he rounds up his two best friends:dyspeptic,hyper-depressed killjoy Cameron(Alan Ruck,fantastic here!)and his pretty,quiet girl Fallon(Mia Sara,lovely),who as much become party to the ploy as Ferris himself.The three are pretty much in the clear,save the dogged suspicions of the pompous,self-righteous principal(Jeffrey Jones,practically born to play this role it seems!),who goes in pursuit of catching Ferris,whom he's been convinced has been faking it through all of the(so far)nine sick days hes taken. It goes without saying that all three,Ferris,Cameron and Fallon have all done this before,and gotten quite good at it.From there,the tour-de-force(farce?)becomes a rollicking travelogue for the city of Chicago. The fun that is culled from these experiences is nearly surreal,and the time-line that these events(German Day parade,Chicago Cubs game,Art museum,dining at a ritzy four-star)would suggest that they didn't spend too much time in one place,just enough to drink in the experience.Director and co-writer John Hughes was on a colossal roll in 1986 and after dipping into darker material in the previous year's The Breakfast Club,returned to lighter fare here and did it seamlessly. Probably one of the best elements of the movie was the breakdown of the "fourth wall",where Ferris talks to the audience,setting the tempo and giving the story a "persona" that is endearing as well as humorous. This film is a keeper,and despite the datedness of the music,clothes and hairstyles,this film is timeless in its theme and as always enjoyable.

Ferris Bueller's day off is one of my favorite films. Not only that, it's one of my favorite comedies. There are a rare few comedies that actually work now days. I mean, look at The Love Guru, that movie was just awful. But Ferris Bueller is a film that I grew up with and will never grow away from. Ferris Bueller's day off is probably the best teen film ever too. There are some great teen comedies, like Clueless and Mean Girls, But Ferris Bueller is absolutely fantastic. Every character in the film is likable, even the ones that you wouldn't expect to love. Like Jeanie(Jennifer Grey, who gives her best performance to date) and Rooney(Jeffery Jones, who also gives his best performance to date). Of course Matthew Broderick is fantastic Bueller, and i love it when he's on that float. Ferris Bueller's day off is one of the most memorable teen comedies ever. My favorite scene is where Jeanie and Rooney jump out at each other and Jeanie kicks his ass. Ferris Bueller's day off is a classic.The Plot: Ferris Bueller, the funnest teen in the world, decides to take a sick day off. Him and his friend Cameron and his girlfriend Sloan join with him. Meanwhile, Principal Rooney and Ferris's sister Jeanie go out of there way to prove that he is skipping school.

Review title: A dream for kids; a nightmare for adults.
Review_body: No matter how you try to put it, this will always be a teen movie, or at least a movie for people under the age of 25 who were recently in high school. It's premise is based on the human urge to go against the system and buck the rules and just have a good time. Practically every kid that feels stuck in the walls of an institution such as high school is going to get these urges, and for all of those kids, Ferris Bueller is their hero. Matthew Broderick brings a warm, innocent charm to the title role as a young man who has luck on his side. Everything goes his way, from worming his best friend (Alan Ruck) into taking his father's rare Ferrari, to warding off the high school principal (Jeffrey Jones) to getting his girlfriend (Mia Sara) out of school as well.Writer/director John Hughes takes his love for teenagers and school situations and gives us a story that deals with life outside school and the freedoms and privileges of being a kid. What Ferris does is, as they say, getting away with murder, but it is such a joy to watch him get into predicaments and wonder how can he possibly get out of this one. Broderick is a delight, as are the supporting cast, especially Jennifer Grey as his envious sister. This movie is about luck and what that power can do for you. It is also about enjoying life and the power that can do. It is the ultimate skipping school movie and is one of Hughes' best efforts as a writer and director. See it for the story, the funnies or the plain joy of skipping school and catching a glimpse of life.
