Review title: Lots of fun, though ridiculous at times
Review_body:
This used to be one of my favorite movies, and I still love watching it, but I can't help but realize more and more flaws in each viewing (which can add to the fun).  I understand it's a farce, from a teenager's point of view--and that's why all the adults are such incompetent jerks--but you gotta draw the line somewhere.But all in all, "Ferris Bueller" is not an easy film to resist.  It's a wild, energetic ride that will probably even make discerning grown-ups crack a smile.  There are some landmark moments, including Ferris singing "Twist and Shout" at a German parade and him driving away with his buddy Cameron's Ferrari with the song "Oh Yeah" pumping in the background.  Matthew Broderick gives a spirited performance (probably the one that put him on the map) and you couldn't imagine anyone else portraying Ferris as well as him. The same goes for Alan Ruck as Cameron and Jeffrey Jones as Principal Rooney.  Mia Sara is a beautiful choice as Sloane, Ferris's girlfriend. Keep a lookout for Charlie Sheen in a cameo as a drug addict who ends up falling for Ferris's sister, Jeannie.  I guess one of the reasons why I love this movie is because I relate to it, in my own way--and I'm sure many others do too.  Everyone aspires to be like Ferris--slick, free-spirited and without a care in the world.  My best friend is somewhat like Ferris, in a free-spirited sense.  And I would compare myself to Cameron.  I admit, I am quite cranky and paranoid at times.  Cameron doesn't like to throw himself into troublesome situations, like me, mostly because he's under the strict rule of his parents.  Now, my parents aren't that strict and they are decent people, which is why I don't try to violate their trust.  But there is something inside of me that wants me to break out of this constrictive shell that I seclude myself in, and I am somewhat envious of my best friend for being able to function without that shell, like Cameron is obviosly envious of Ferris without that shell.  I believe that everyone either is Ferris or knows a Ferris, and everyone is either Cameron or knows a Cameron.  The characters are both exaggerated, but the basis of them are true.
There are ridiculous scenes that couldn't help but make me roll my eyes and scream "Yeah, right!"  How many times did Ferris almost come face-to-face with his Dad and escaped at the last minute?  After Jeannie kicked Principal Rooney in the face, how come she reported that a stranger invaded her house? She knows Rooney from school!  When Ferris's Mom went to check on Ferris, how come she didn't actually step inside the bedroom and check on him, even after she remembered back to Rooney mentioning he was absent 9 times?  I'm sure any mother, whether her son was sleeping or not, would've went inside to check on him.  This is a great fantasy world, but us young people ain't stupid and our parents ain't either.  I don't even have overprotective parents, but my parents (well, my mom at least) are like human lie detectors.  They have extra-sensitive senses and are basically like psychics.  It's like the characters, not the actors, read the script and memorized their cues to become ignorant morons.So if you wanna have fun with this movie, please suspend and suspend and continue to suspend all disbelief.  The plot holes are so evident that a 10-year-old can point them out, but trust me--it's still a wild and crazy ride with some good laughs to spare!My score:  7 (out of 10)

Review title: One of a Small Number of Gen X'er Films Which Captured an Era: More Satisfying Than "The BreakFast Club"
Review_body: The so-called "Great Generation", those who fought in and/or came of age during and just after the Second World War, predominantly born during the First World War (circa 1910 to 1925), have been characterized as doing their duty. The Silent Generation, born circa 1925 to 1945, were known for conforming, hence they were "silent" on social matters instead focusing on careers and buying homes. Then came "the Boomers" (born circa 1946 to 1960), often associated with not only the social protests of the 1960's but also challenging the status quo. Then came Generation X, born circa 1961 to 1980. Generation X, so-called because they were largely undefinable, were about "me", sometimes called "The Me Generation". "I want to do this, and I don't want to do that" has been the mantra of Generation X. "Ferris Beuller's Day Off" is quite possibly the quintessential Generation X film about a kid who skips school to give a repressed friend the time of his life."Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is certainly a comedy-fantasy, but unlike most comedies of the 1980's, there is an underlying message which spoke to Generation X. Certainly the message is perhaps not as deep as that found in something like "Rebel Without a Cause", but it does have a point to make. Through a largely innocent fantasy tale of three high school students who decide to take a day off from school without permission, they learn about life outside the classroom. They have experiences which couldn't be gleaned from text books from within the Purgatory of an American high school.The catalyst of this little adventure is Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick), a relatively intelligent but free-spirited high school-er who is determined to get the better of the school administer. He concocts a plan to fool the school and his family that he's in bed sick, which is one of the best bits in the film. His friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) is in desperate need to "get out" and live a little bit. He suffers from hypochondria, obsessed with his health, and repressed resentment against his father. They are joined by Ferris' girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) where they take Cameron's dad's car for a day trip into Chicago. They explore the city by doing among other things visit art galleries, sing in the streets, and attend a Chicago Cubs' baseball game.Meanwhile, school principal Edward R. Rooney, Dean of Students (Jeffrey Jones) believes something is amiss. He's convinced Ferris is up to something and decides to expose the "cheating" high school-er by engaging in a chase to trap him. For Generation X'ers of the time, Ferris getting the better of a high school administrator was probably worth the price of admission when it was originally released in the 1980's. But the principal is not the only one. His sister Jeannie Bueller (Jennifer Gray) is also suspicious that Ferris is not really home in bed. She ends up having a conversation at a police station with Garth played by Charlie Sheen in a small role.This is mostly a pure fun film but strangely I found it more satisfying than "The Breakfast Club" also directed by John Hughes. In "Breakfast Club" the characters talk and talk and talk, and they dance. In "Ferris Bueller", the characters actually do stuff. Yes, they do dance and sing, but they do other things too. And of course Ferris, being smart enough to outsmart previous generations, gives the film it's bite. However, it's not him but another character who actually makes the biggest statement through a faux pas action, something "The Breakfast Club" characters never do. Sometimes I wonder what if Ferris had burst into the library where the Breakfast Clubbers were being detained and saved them from the angst of 1980's American teenage-hood. I would have paid good money to see that. In a sense, "Ferris Bueller" is a kind of send up to "The Breakfast Club", demonstrating what happens when Gen X'ers are released from Purgatory. Look out!

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is among the most acclaimed and beloved comedy films of its generation. Which is quite startling as this is a very ordinary, frankly disappointing, film. There's not enough fun, not enough laughs. The movie never truly sparks to life. Ferris Bueller had a pretty eventful day. But it doesn't translate. Ferris, the character, probably found his day off to be wildly exciting. Living it is one thing. Watching it is another. For those of us who can only watch it is not particularly exciting at all.It's an absurdly simple story. High school senior Ferris Bueller skips school and, girlfriend and best friend in tow, goes to Chicago and does some stuff. There's a subplot about the school principal who is obsessed with catching Ferris. This subplot falls completely, and rather annoyingly, flat. The principal is an unfunny irritant. Time spent with him is time wasted. We'd rather spend more time with Ferris and his friends. But honestly the time we do spend with them is disappointing as well. Matthew Broderick gives a game performance, infusing Ferris with some personality. But the girlfriend, played by Mia Sara is a dud. A stunningly beautiful dud but a dud nonetheless. And Cameron, the mopey best friend played by Alan Ruck, is a total drag. Ferris tries to get Cameron to loosen up and have a good time. Not happening. And then, in a film which is meant to be escapist fun, things get all too serious as Cameron has to deal with his unseen, overbearing father. The tone here is all wrong. It puts a damper on a film which wasn't even as fun as it is cracked up to be in the first place. The great adventure Ferris went on wasn't so great. It was quite frankly mundane. Laughs are in desperately short supply. The principal is notably annoying and the other supporting characters, including Ferris's sister, add nothing to the proceedings. The device of Ferris breaking the fourth wall and speaking to the camera is overused and wears thin very quickly. All in all this is a very disappointing movie, one which falls far short of the expectations you would have of it given its stellar reputation.

Ferris Bueller reportedly lives life on the edge, unplanned, spontaneous, spur-of-the-moment. But what we only later see are the clever little devices he has rigged up to precisely maintain an illusion of his sickness, and how he has carefully orchestrated a day for his friend to gain some self-worth and respect so that he may stand up to his father. It is easy for a viewer to take the opposite perspective in line with the dastardly Principal Rooney. Ferris is young, good looking, popular, has the girl; the sorts of things that are easy to be jealous of. And his sister, too, is not convinced like his legions of adoring fans, and in particular, his parents. We see then, how Hughes has magnified each and every close call because of this perspective, this needy desire to expose and ruin a teenager's fun. When Katie Bueller creeps up to her son's bedroom to check on her, the soundtrack takes a shrill, horror-influenced turn and the walls turn into something out of The Shining as she slowly approaches (and note that the fake arm is clearly in view; but these caricature parents are so endearing and loving that they never once question Ferris). And then as she is relieved, she skips down the steps and the score is once again pleasant. The same technique is used as Rooney attempts to trap Ferris in his tricks, only for a two way phone call to suddenly put into harsh light all the insults he has sprayed through the speaker. Again, this loud, ominous fanfare blasts as we zoom into his shocked realisation, and his bumbling attempts to patch up the situation milked all the way from Hughes, until the humorous reveal that Cameron is now on board with the day-trip. From the loathing tone in his voice you might have thought that Ferris was an escaped murdered on death row. But what we instead see are a series of innocent little adventures through the city of Chicago that are designed to slowly peel away at Cameron's shell. As they lean their heads on the glass of the Seers Tower and survey every tiny ant with their own lives, all he can think about is the coming rage of his father. Later, he nervously teeters as Ferris bluffs his way into a high-end restaurant before assisting him yet again by mimicking a police officer. In perhaps the most iconic sequence of the movie, they visit the Art Institute, and on the backdrop of a dreamy cover of Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want (a teenager's plea, if ever), they lose themselves and descend into playtime. Hughes freely admits this as a sort of self-indulgent nostalgia binge; a place of refuge and comfort for the youth of his time. And here they pose in mock pretense, they kiss like teenagers do in the silhouette of the beautiful blue glow of Chagall's America Windows, and it's just so soft and light- hearted. And like a teenager does, Cameron seems to find meaning in a grand Seurat, and through a series of axial cuts he focuses until the details are merely splotches of indistinct paint. There's no real meaning to be found in the canvas, but there is plenty of introspection that can be found in Cameron. And in the midst of these whirlwind events, there is a little side- plot that concerns Ferris' sister, whom is constantly pushed aside. While Broderick charms and addresses the audience directly and invites them along on his day off, we see reaction shots that tell us Jeannie has been enduring this farce for so long. She got the car, but what good is it if she cannot escape school like Ferris has the ability to? So while we are swept up in his adventures, there is a quiet, modest scene completely dedicated to Jeannie, where she voices her frustrations to a stranger played by Charlie Sheen. She bemoans the fact that he is always getting away with things that she cannot, and how unfair it is; anyone with a sibling will know this feeling. And then as he makes her come to the realisation that this says more about her than it does for Ferris, she becomes this giggling schoolgirl and her facade is shattered. This is handled extremely well without attacking Ferris, but allowing Jeannie to really show who she is, and that her problems are not really that bad. Another memorable scene is the parade that seemingly erupts in the middle of the day, to be high-jacked by Ferris. It seems like something of a daydream. Where did these people come from, and how do they have the time to dedicate to an elaborate dance and song? We see everyone drop their things like it is a pre-planned flash-mob, but it is anything but. The construction workers up above join in to a rousing rendition of Twist and Shout, and even Tom Bueller dances in his office. It's just pure, clean fun. And the iconic theme of Star Wars magnifies the slow- motion frenzy of two parking attendants who take the Ferrari for a joyride, where in some other film might result in a crash and a panicked hurried attempt to patch things together before Cameron's father reaches the front door. But that doesn't happen here. It seems that most people just need to take a Ferris Bueller day once in a while.

Review title: Still a highly entertaining teen comedy after over twenty years
Review_body: This popular teen movie was first released the year I was born, so obviously, I didn't have the pleasure of seeing it on the big screen back in 1986. I didn't even know about the film throughout my childhood and early teens (I was obviously too young for the majority of that time), but was finally introduced to it when I was around Ferris Bueller's age. I saw quite a bit of it at the time, but didn't see the rest of it until later. I have watched the entire thing again since then, and can say that overall, it's definitely my kind of comedy! On a beautiful day, fairly close to the end of Ferris Bueller's senior year, the rebellious student decides to take the day off. In the morning, he pretends to be sick, and even though this is certainly not the first time, his parents still buy it. Now that Ferris has the day off, he calls up his friend, Cameron Frye, who really is sick, and manages to lure him out of bed so he can try and enjoy the day with him! Together, they manage to get Ferris' girlfriend, Sloane Peterson, out of school by making phony calls. All three of them go out to have fun, but Ed Rooney, the school principal, just knows that Ferris isn't really sick, so he goes out, determined to bust him and prove to other students that he is not a good role model! Ferris' sister, Jeanie, is aware of her brother's tricks, and also wants to bust him! The popular high school rebel may be in trouble, as he will not graduate if he is caught!I must confess, I think there were a few jokes I didn't get, even though I can't think of any off the top of my head right now. I don't know if these are dated jokes that I didn't get because they're before my time, or if it's something else. However, for the most part, this certainly wasn't an issue. For me, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is mostly highly amusing, filled with slapstick and silliness! If you ask me, there are so many comic highlights in the film, including Cameron's reaction to Ferris taking out his father's rare, extremely valuable Ferrari, and the trouble poor Ed Rooney experiences as he tries to bust Ferris! The film may go downhill a bit towards the end, but in my opinion, this is not much of a problem. For those who are into the kind of humour that "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" has to offer, I think it should be entertaining to some degree.

Review title: There's a Ferris in all of us
Review_body: Matthew Broderick (war games) stars as Ferris Bueller, a cocky teenager who doesn't want to go to school on a day when the sun is shining and there is so much to explore, and this ideology, I believe, is something that is hidden in all of us.How many of us wake up in the morning and think, ah the hell with it, I'm skipping school/work today and going exploring, to see sights and enjoy myself! It is something with its consequences, but with so many more personal benefits. Both are explored in a comedy fashion by John Hughes in my personal favourite teenage comedy.Undoubtedly there are problems when skipping the day of the normal routine, whether that's your jealous sister (Grey) or a paranoid teacher (Jones) and these supporting characters lend such good support and humour to the tale of this mischievous kid.But what about the benefits? Well not sitting in class, seeing the world and spending time with those you love what more could you want? It is the true meaning of freedom, and the unfortunate boundaries that we have to live in sometimes, and this wouldn't have been justified without such a great central protagonist.The opening shot of Ferris in the bed pretending to be sick and his parents buying it is funny, and later when he starts addressing the camera, invites us into his world of crazy ideas, intelligence and sophistication, beautifully portrayed by Broderick.The comedy is great, with a lot of slapstick humour and smart timings and insults thrown in for good merit.Teenage comedy mean girls is run by stereotypes, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is run by a stereotype, but a classic one who we can all relate to, and who we should all take a lesson from.

Before all the slapstick, before re-writing "Home Alone" umpteen times and before selling his soul to "Disney Pictures Inc.", John Hughes was believed to be THE scribe for teen angst. He wrote eloquently of it in "Sixteen Candles", "The Breakfast Club" and "Pretty in Pink". And with "Ferris Bueller's Day Off", he creates a person and a time in life that just about anyone who's ever been a teenager can relate to.Who hasn't known someone like Ferris Bueller (Broderick)? Someone who always has a plan, someone who made loafing off an art form, someone who could fall in a barrel of you-know-what and come out smelling like a rose?All he wants to do is take a day off from school and enjoy the day in Chicago - simple enough, but he must also try and convince his best friend Cameron (Ruck) and his best girl (Sara) to join him and, in the process, learn to enjoy what life has to offer.Naturally, there is a tyrannical school dean (Jones) who is determined to catch Ferris in the act of hookey and Ferris' own sister (Grey, pre-nose job) who has it in for her brother, the "trouser-snake". There are funny situations throughout the movie, and the characters are ones that grow on you, especially Ruck's worry-wart portrayal of Cameron Frye, constantly fretting about his dystalic, cursing his father and nearly drowning in a pool, all in the name of friendship.Sara has less to do, but she plays the object of desire well, and Ferris' passion for her is understandable. At least he thinks about the right things, like what their lives would be like after high school.All the way from beginning to end, this movie is a great trip in search of fun, relaxation, not taking life too seriously and how to sing Wayne Newton songs in the middle of a parade. You want to catch vintage John Hughes and classic '80s teendom at its best? Seize this "Day"!Ten stars for "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".

Over the past few years there have bee list after list of the greatest film ever made and Ferris Bueller's Day Off seemed to make the top 100 list's quite often so i was interested to see what all the fuss was about and as usually is the case i was dissapointed. Maybe this was a good film back in 1986 but now it look very dated . Perhaps this led way for all the teen comedies we see far to many of these days, if so, it has a lot to answer for. Perhaps i am being a little harsh because really it isnt that bad but top 100? no way! This does have it's moments and Jeffrey Jones ( the Head teacher ) does come out of this was credit for a funny performance. Over all dated and Overrated. 6 out of 10.

Review title: Ferris Bueller is the Best High School Movie
Review_body: For seniors in high school, this movie serves as a guidebook for fun. And what fun you can have skipping a day of school with your friend and girlfriend. Only to have the principal stalking you, trying to find you out. Which, by the way, the principal in the film is a reminder to us all what a high school principal is really like, a JERK! At least in most cases, and especially if you skipped, I mean missed a lot of school. This film can be summed up in least words possible, AWESOME. This is the absolute best work of Matthew Broderick, and I think most fans would agree. Overall, this film is the best high school film to date, and nothing has surpassed "Ferris Bueller's" glory yet.

Review title: My Personal Favorite Film from John Hughes!
Review_body: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it." Ah, wise words from our new young friend, Ferris Bueller. In John Hughes's 1986 film, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, all Ferris wants to do is take a day and have fun. That is the most simplistic theme the movie has. You can go deeper, but the main takeaway is that it is okay to have fun. That is a motto I have taken to heart. I really loved the film. People consider The Breakfast Club to be Hughes's best and most important movie. That's a fine statement to make, but I would personally rank the film number two behind this particular one. The teen characters are instantly relatable, it has a memorable antagonist for the children, and this is basically a thirty-year-old travel guide for Chicago. Just how Woody Allen creates his movies as love letters for New York, this is applicable for John Hughes. A Chicago love letter!Like all of his films, Hughes wrote his own script. Due to possible picketing from the writer's guild, Hughes wrote a basic first draft that had a beginning and an ending. The middle would be made up as production ensued. The first cut of the film was nearly three hours long, so the rest of the screenplay would be completed in the editing room if that made sense. Hughes, always the adolescent philosopher, wrote a very familiar screenplay. Teens that are relatable and one-dimensional adults who do not believe in the word "fun." Somehow, these adult antagonists seem to make the history books as the roles to remember. Just as I remember Paul Gleason's principal role in The Breakfast Club, I certainly remember Jeffrey Jones's dim-witted Ed Rooney here. Hughes takes time to develop his characters which should come as no surprise.I guess if you were going to commit truancy, you would want to follow in the footsteps of our main hero, Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick). All he wanted to do was take a day off from school. He enlists his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) to steal his father's red Ferrari. The duo, along with Ferris's girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara), head into Chicago for a day to check out the sites; the architectural landmarks, the art museum, the fancy restaurant, Wrigley Field, and an American-German parade where "Danke Schoen" and "Twist and Shout" might be key songs to remember. Meanwhile, Principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is hellbent in capturing Ferris. He might have an ally in Ferris's moody but really pretty sister Jeanie Bueller (Jennifer Grey).Hughes always wanted Matthew Broderick as Ferris. Broderick possesses a charm that is not seen in many modern actors. After watching the film, you could obviously see why Broderick and only him was cast in the lead role. Broderick had a close friendship with Alan Ruck which led to great chemistry between the actors. Despite being 29, Ruck did make a believable high school student. He was excellent and captured the true feelings of a high school student not wanting to go to school. Mia Sara is beautiful, but she wasn't given much to do. Molly Ringwald wanted to play this role, but Hughes cautioned her for good reason apparently. Yes, Ed Rooney is a one-dimensional, child-hating character but my gosh is Jeffrey Jones ever memorable. I love the scene where the dogs sic him and is forced to ride a bus. Hehe. Jennifer Grey is fantastic! Finally, a shoutout goes to Ben Stein and his monotonous lecture on economics.Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a wholesome, incredibly fun film. There is nothing mean-spirited to see. It is all about teens wanting to have a good time. If I were to be truant, this is how I would want my day to go. The other theme is Ferris wanting to lift the spirits of his best friend from his materialistic father. A more subtle theme, but I appreciate it. This is one of those movies that is wholesome, but also incredibly funny. I laughed too many times to count and that is a rarity. Great performances and great fun add up to John Hughes's best film. Yes, I rank it higher than The Breakfast Club.My Grade: A

Author's Forewarning: I am making many comparisons between this and The Breakfast Club because the two represent John Hughes' best work.  Forget Sixteen Candles and Weird Science, if you cannot handle such constant comparisons, get a life and start thinking.Matthew Broderick has never grown out of the image he created with Ferris Bueller's Day Off, he never will.  His poise is correct for the character, proving that John Hughes can make some proper casting decisions.  His wise-ass comments are not as clever as Judd Nelson's in TBC, but raise Ferris' character level beyond Bender's.Alan Ruck and Jeffrey Jones are the real saving graces of this film. Anthony Michael Hall was smart to turn down the part of Cameron because it would be out of his line and, while Ruck never went onto anything better, he did make his declaration here.  Jeffrey Jones' Rooney is absolutely in line because, perhaps, he is the only one sans Broderick to understand the overwhelming parody of the movie.  I am extremely thankful that Hughes didn't use Molly Ringwald (again) because she is unable to expand on his paper-thin roles.  Mia Sara is no better, but at least she has fewer lines.Hughes is more artistic here (in an MTV fashion) and Broderick knows how to exploit this change to his advantage.  The editing is both efficient and superior to TBC, but here it is merely editing for the sake of comedy and pacing whereas TBC tried developing character.  The script, conventional Hughes as it is (see my Breakfast Club comment), has some key points that both age it and retain its value at the same time.Though Hughes' movies are for teens, their level of credibility ranges from innocent (as in this case) to insulting (Weird Science anyone?), thus I find TBC to be more insightful in the long run.  Ferris Bueller has its moments, but there are no long-standing messages to take away other than Cameron's fits.  Unfortunately, since Ferris' world is so focused on youth, the distant world of adults is falls into the similar problems of TBC except here it is merely for laughs.  There are no brief moments of self-discovery for Ed Rooney.Overall, I give this a tied recommendation level with TBC due to shifts in tone and ideas, but recommended this for anyone between 14-22 years old. 3.5 out of 5 stars.  Isn't high school all about malarkey anyway?

Review title: Awful people, awful story, awful message
Review_body: Ferris Bueller's Day Off would be a strong contender for my least favourite film of all-time. I have no idea how this movie became so popular and garnered such a cult following. Breakfast Club was bad enough but John Hughes went one step further with this drivel.The character Ferris is one of the most unpalatable central characters I have ever seen in a movie. This guy is an over-confident brat who lives in a mansion with loving parents while receiving a first-rate education yet decides to actively rebel against his so-called oppression. And John Hughes thinks we are going to relate to him somehow? Not only that, he looks like a spoiled rich kid. Matthew Broderick has one of those incredibly smarmy faces that you just want to slap. He also looks 25 years old despite being baby-faced and its very difficult to take him seriously as a schoolkid. It is highly fitting that the final scene of the movie is Ferris smiling at the camera with an unspeakably smug expression on his face.Also, how exactly does Ed Rooney, the school principal, become the bad guy? Is caring about your students' attendance some kind of character flaw? This kind of writing makes the kids look like spoilt brats, not trendy rebels.And as for Cameron, another overgrown man-child, are we really supposed to like this guy as well? A rich kid living in paradise who is happy to smash up his daddy's $100k Ferrari just to iron out some personal insecurities? Does Hughes think this is commendable in some way? Would there be any actual consequences to Cameron's actions like a beating from his Dad or being kicked out of his house? Almost certainly not. These are the most low-risk rebels ever created.The carnival scene where Ferris mimes to Twist and Shout is one of the most excruciatingly cringe-worthy things I have ever seen. This is just pure self-indulgence from John Hughes, who I am pretty sure only makes films to coddle his own warped fantasies about what it would have been like to be the cool kid at high school.The only real positive in this movie is the soundtrack which, like most eighties films, is great. Jennifer Grey is also quite good I suppose, at least in contrast to Broderick and Ruck. Aside from that though, this is just complete trash. Not funny, not meaningful and actually quite offensive.

I've kept coming back to this film over the years and am firmly convinced that besides being John Hughes's finest work, it is THE teen comedy. Hilariously perfect in every respect.Sensibly eschewing the wholesale teenage angst of many of his other pre-adult films, Hughes just focuses wholly on comedy tinged with a liberal dose of gentle satire, which is generally manifested in a continuous Mickey-taking of adult behaviour. In Ferris's world adults don't understand the teenagers in their care, be it Ferris's parents or the high school principal Mr Noonan, who makes it his mission in life to catch Ferris in the act of doing something he shouldn't be doing. His litany of comedic failures contrast markedly with Ferris's success in doing all the things in just one epic day off school, that many of us might not have the nerve to do in a lifetime. He is aided and accompanied in his adventures with girlfriend Sloane and best pal Cameron.The casting is perfect with Matthew Broderick excelling as the exuberant, witty hero in what is undoubtedly his most famous role. Not to be outshone though is Alan Ruck in what is arguably his most beloved role as the also talented, but far less self-confident Cameron. Amazingly, the near 30 year old Ruck convincingly looks the part. Mia Sara is suitably elegant as Sloane, whilst Jeffrey Jones uproariously and inevitably plays the hapless coyote, to Ferris's always superior road runner. One cannot look past Jennifer Grey either, as Ferris's bitter but attractive younger sister, Jeanie. Both Charlie Sheehan's (police station) and Ben Stein's (form teacher) cameos are not to be missed by anyone ... anyone?The Windy City of Chicago plays its extremely functional part in all of its late spring (actually early autumn) glory. Memorable side trips include the observation deck of Sears Tower, Wrigley Field, the Chicago Art Institute and the stand out Von Steuben's Day Parade where the famous lip-sync of Twist and Shout occurs with a good deal of both improvised and choreographed dancing among the crowd.Hughes's decision to have his lead character frequently break the fourth wall was a winner, as were the many striking camera angles used and the music selected for the soundtrack.John Hughes passed away far too early. But in Ferris Bueller's Day Off, he left a lasting legacy full of cross-generational appeal. It's a classic!

Okay, I never watched this in the theatre. I never watched it the first few thousand times it ran on television. Recently, it popped up on the USA Network and I just didn't bother to change the channel. Broderick does seem to have some sort of charming bad boy charisma that makes this movie interesting and a tad funny, but the movie's concept and plot are extremely out of left field. There is no way he could possibly be prepared for every contingency or get away with everything he does. Making his family as wealthy as they seem to be is an obvious plot point because Ferris has to be wealthy to explain his attitude and above canny luck. For me, seeing Mia Sara playing a typical teen after knowing her just for the Tom Cruise movie Legend is one of the few things that made this movie interesting; that and hoping Jeffrey Jones will get him. At least this film inspired the much more enjoyable Parker Lewis Can't Lose series which was so much more funny.

It's very possible that Ferris Bueller is the type of movie I had to have seen in my teens to really have any feelings for. As it is, having just seen it, I'm not that impressed. Broderick made for a poor lead; I didn't feel any of the charisma other reviewers talked about. Jeffrey Jones was a very unconvincing villain. Alan Ruck and Jennifer Grey were the only cast members who were really effective, in my opinion (in addition to a lovely little cameo from Charlie Sheen.It does have its moments; John Hughes only ever did one genre, but he clearly knew his way around it. There are some good scenes here that are probably the origin of its cult status. But if this movie wasn't a part of your childhood, you probably won't get a big kick out of them. In other words - I recommend it only for people who have already seen it.

Review title: That comedy that everyone should watch once in a lifetime!
Review_body: After seeing the film, one only wants to watch it again and again and again and again. The film had a very interesting story, very comical scenes (mainly the scenes that break the fourth wall), very bonse actors a fantastic soundtrack. Highly recommend.

I love 'The Breakfast Club', but this John Hughes movie is totally overrated. The main character is not likable and the story almost morally offensive. There are some funny and memorable scenes though.

Review title: I felt sorry for Ferris' friend, not Ferris
Review_body: 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off' is one of the classic comedies to come out of the 1980s. It's acquired a following of its own over the years, partly because it is quite easy to relate to it. In summary, the film is about Ferris and his friends, a female he has a crush on and his geeky male friend. Ferris is determined to get a day off of school, and this day is filled with events and plenty of mistakes and some comedy. Some of it is at the expense of his poor geeky friend, who I felt immensely sorry for because he was forced to follow an over-bearing Ferris and ended up with a big problem on his hands.Despite the comedy geared at the adult authority figures (who do not understand the youth), the film really did not make a lot of sense or provide a good story or conclusion. Right, Ferris gets his way and the principal makes a fool of himself and faces the consequences; this is a typical teen rebellion film.It's a classic comedy, but in terms of a good story, Ferris Bueller falls short. And, you either enjoy this type of comedy or you don't enjoy it. If you don't enjoy it, then you will not enjoy the film. Simple as that. Personally, while I thought that some of the humor was good, I felt that it could not carry the story for me, and I felt more sorry for some of the characters and did not feel sorry for the main character at all. And, if you cannot stand the main character, then, well, it is difficult to enjoy the film.

Anyone who has attended high school in the last 30 years knows that this movie portrays exactly what it is like. Who doesn't know someone exactly like Ferris? Or Cameron? Or Sloan? Or Rooney? Or the dad? There are Ferrises, Camerons, Sloans, Rooneys, and dads in EVERY American high school. One of the funniest parts about this movie is that it IS so accurate. This movie is filled with jokes about our culture. I haven't met one person yet who has seen it and not liked it. Talk about a 1980s cult classic. The film uses witty humor and a bit of goofy humor. It's the PERFECT film for light comedy. If you're into those kind of films that make you think a lot, this one definitely isn't for you. On the other hand, if you laugh at things like lip synching to Wayne Newton, you'll love it. 7/10.

This movie is good from beginning to end. A goofy classic of over-the-top principal chasing a kid who decided to sneak out of school for the day.4.5/5. Really loved how the film explored the city of Chicago in this movie. One of the reasons why I fell in love with the city.

Review title: My smile is a rifle I'm pointing at you
Review_body: Even as a child when I saw this movie, I never liked Ferris, I thought the character was a creep and that something was wrong with him. It always baffled me why the character was painted in a heroic light. I understand that people love this movie and I don't want to take that away from anyone, you love the sh*t out of this movie, also I see plainly that I am in the minority, in regards to audience reaction to Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Recently, some one has published an article arguing that from a clinical observation, the actions of the character Ferris, would in real life be those of a psychopath.I feel a lot of validation from reading this article ( apologies to the article's author, I didn't bother to learn your name ) because it explains to me the impression of Ferris Bueller I had as a kid. Filling his hours with meaningless deceptions, manipulating everyone he comes in contact with, always seeking to be the desperate center of attention. F*cking monster.

Review title: One of the finest in it's kind
Review_body: Even though Ferris really is a spoilt brat you gotta love the guy for the things he pulls in this great teen flick from the 80's.Ferris is a popular guy who has a lot of things going for him. One day (well, every other day really) he doesn't really feel like going to school, so he calls in sick and asks his best friend, depressed Cameron, to spend the day. In the process, they pick up Ferris' girlfriend Sloane and the three of them have a blast.Principal Rooney however knows Ferris is up to something and wants to catch him in the act, and big sister Jeanie hates the way Ferris is always getting away with things. Is Ferris going to have to stay another year in highschool or is he in luck yet again?Great fun in this one, as Broderick just *is* the cheeky Ferris. The story about Cameron and his parents sometimes is a bit of a downer (literally) but overall this film is pretty good. You gotta love Jones there in his role of principal Rooney. He's hilarious!7/10.

Review title: The Smash Hit Teen Comedy that became a blessing and curse for its star...
Review_body: FERRIS BUELLER'S DAY OFF was the fresh and imaginative teen comedy that followed a smart-aleck high school senior through a series of amusing adventures when he decides to skip school for the day. This comedy was a smash hit at the box office that became an instant classic and made a star out of Matthew Broderick, who is absolute perfection in the title role. Broderick lights up the screen and tackles this role with an effortless charm that is quite engaging and even appears quite comfortable during the moments when Ferris talks directly to the camera. John Hughes' inventive direction is a plus and Broderick is given sterling support from Jeffrey Jones as Ed Rooney, the principal of Ferris' school who is determined to catch Ferris ditching school, Edie McClurg as Rooney's secretary, Alan Ruck as Ferris' best friend Cameron, Jennifer Grey as Ferris' jealous older sister, and Lyman Hall and Cindy Pickett as Ferris' parents. Yes, the screenplay is a little one-sided...all the adults in the film are made to look like idiots, but if you can accept that, this comic-fantasy adventure is one entertaining roller-coaster ride. The film made a star out of Broderick but he was so good in the film that he became type-cast for years to the point where no one would even think of casting him as an adult, but if you're gonna get typecast, be thankful it was due to a classic like this one. Followed years later by a brief TV series.

Review title: This movie makes my heart flutter
Review_body: Wow astonishing that in the 33 years since ferris bueller came out we still haven't been able to make a movie with as great a one-two punch as the emotionally moving museum scene followed by the sexiness and pure joy that is the danke schoen/twist and shout parade scene...
Brilliantly charming, and it's influence can be seen in nearly everything in the genre that came after.

Review title: One of the great teenage movies
Review_body: The movie is an absolute classic of the teenage variety. This was made by John Hughes back in the prime of his career when he was pumping out great movie after great movie with this movie, Sixteen Candles, The Breakfast Club, Weird Science and so on.Ferris, Cameron and Sloane skip school and set out to have an adventure all over the city of Chicago going to Wrigley Field, Art Institute of Chicago, Sears Tower, stock exchange and even to the Von Steuben Day parade.Easily my favorite performance of Matthew Broderick's career where the role is basically made for him. Alan Ruck, Jeffrey Jones, Mia Sara and Jennifer Grey are also great in support.

Review title: Playing hooky was never this cool.
Review_body: I enjoyed this film a lot. It has a lot of re-watchable value. It also seems funnier each time I have viewed it. This is one of John Hughes' best films.

I just saw the movie Curtindo a Vida Adoidado! With the plot of the young man who executes a whole plan to get rid of the school principal and be able to miss his school, so that he can enjoy a whole day on a program around the city with his girlfriend and his best friend. A delicious and exciting adventure. The recording style, with the protagonist speaking directly to the camera, did very well and the editing did very well, making the film very light.Film seen on June 30, 2020.

Review title: In the top three of the best teen movies made by John Hughes!
Review_body: This movie is funny, and sometimes very funny. It's in the top three of the best teen movies made by John Hughes. It's entertaining, and very cool. The first time I saw Ferris Bueller's day off was in 1989 I think. I give Ferris Bueller's Day Off *** out of ****

Review title: One of the best comedy movies ever made
Review_body: When John Hughes was interviewed about the reason why he made movies in the first place and he said "To prove how stupid some teenagers can really be without even realizing it." For people who haven't watched his movies his reasoning may sound strange to them, but for some who have know for a fact that he puts his proof into comedy.In Ferris Bueller's Day Off he proves it with excellence. The movie stars Matthew Broderick as Ferris Bueller a senior in high-school who is determined to act sick so that he can ditch school for a ninth consecutive time so that he can some fun with his best friend Cameron (played by Alan Ruck), and his girlfriend Sloane (played by Mia Sara) for the whole day while his parents are away from home, while Ferris is on his so called sick day his school principal Ed Rooney (played by Jeffrey Jones) is determined to get him busted for ditching school. Writer-director John Hughes has written the perfect story for a well done teen comedy, and his direction and his cast try to prove that the stupid thing that teenagers do can be very laughable. the movie also includes a very good supporting cast which includes Jennifer Grey as his sister Jeanie who gets ticked off in the beginning of the movie when she knew all along that he was going to ditch school when her parents found his performance to be very convincing as well as the other 8 times that he ditched school to take a guess, and Cindy Pickett and Lyman Ward as their parents Katie and Tom Bueller the parents as I mentioned earlier got fooled by his prank. The movie itself is a film that I consider to be a must see for all people who like movies that not only make fun of teenagers in a laughable way, and for people who like comedy movies in general.

If there was an perfect actor for a movie, it would be Matthew Broderick in Ferris Bueller's day off. All that lovable cheek, and those classic facial expressions, one when looking straight to camera, sometimes before he delivers his insightful and colorful monologues. Ferris, the professional, shows us some tips for successful faking in front of the folks. There's absolutely no way you could hate this guy, unless you were Ferris's sister (Jennifer Grey) who envies him the way he always gets out of stuff, like school, and his award winning performances of a sick kid in bed, his parents taking the bait, where he gets to bludge his way through college. He takes no chances, making sure his operation is foolproof, where all avenues of his little charade, are backed up, if anyone should pay a visit or ring the house. He has a tape equipment, with a synthesizer of sounds, coughs, vomiting, or barfing up a lung. Only the headmaster, Ed Rooney is onto his little show, out to catch him if it's the last thing he does, even if it kills him, which it almost does, on a return bus trip back to school, in tattered garb. What this movie's message is, stands true to a few of Ferris's wise words. Everybody should relax and take a break every so often like a day off work, or in Ferris case, high school, though never as many days as Ferris. Being a wagging student myself, I did relate a bit to it, only I just went on and wagged school, especially in my last year in grade eleven, where I left a week before the end of the second term. Coincidentally, I left a week before this movie hit cinema. In home class, the last two or so months, I was absent almost every day, and my parents never got a call. In fact I was wagging subjects I didn't like and I had an assortment of grades ranging from A's down to E's. And to tell you the truth, I felt much better, liberated, and defiant. How I hated biology. Ferris's best friend, Cameron, worked and stressed to the max, with a real arse...e of a father, although we never see him, is a severe example of someone who needs to decompress, I was myself concerned for him, even though he was just a character. On Ferris's latest day off, he keeps hounding Cameron, to drive over and pick him up for a city trip. Cameron's sick in in bed, though Ferris tells us, it's only in his head, which I believe too. Cameron folds, helping Ferris too in a plan of phoney voices, that involves taking Ferris's girl (Mia Sara) out of school. You'll love how this plays off. So now they have the rest of the day, and how they spend it makes it a fun filled adventure. One scene in particular, that's unforgettable, is in a museum, with Cameron relating to a painting of void, that keeps minifying, where he feels so small. Ferris brazes out, and risks all, jumping up onto a float before live t.v. and sings Twist And Shout. Another potent scene involves Gray at the police station, pouring her troubles onto, a wasted teen, who else but Charlie Sheen, who makes her see with his insightful analogy, that Ferris is not the problem. And just when you think Ferris is about to be caught out, when making like a hare, crossing numerous backyards and jumping fences, in a hasty rush to beat his parents, returning home, guess who saves the day. Highly infectious comedy cult hit of 86, that I've heard favorable mentions from people here and there. One of Hughes's best, again another one with it's share of morals.

I didn't like this movie nearly as well as most of my family and acquaintances, when it was originally released. Recently, visiting friends, they had rented it for their teenage daughter, and all watched it one evening. I thought I might enjoy it more, and having lived in Chicago previously, like to see the locales there in any film.However, I liked it even less the second time, and, frankly, have enjoyed looking at information about the film and cast on this site (IMDb) even more than seeing the picture.I found Broderick's character un-funny, annoying, and even obnoxious. It is also interesting and humorous (more than the flick) to see that naughty high-schooler Broderick was 24 when the film was made, and Alan Ruck, his laconic sidekick (also annoying in his droll lethargy) was either 29 (or 30!!). Little sister Jennifer Grey was actually 26 (two years senior to Broderick) - but at least the girlfriend was "only" 19. And this assumes none have "fudged" a couple of years on age, not uncommon for "show biz" personalities Another interesting factoid from this site: the actor and actress portraying the Buehler parents met on this film, and married in real life (but were later divorced at an indeterminate date).Finally, anything as ludicrous as Buehler's boarding the parade float and singing like a nightclub emcee, to the participation and enjoyment of the girls properly on the float, the marching band following, and every onlooker in sight, is not only outrageous, but not in the least bit amusing, also. When this sort of nonsense is put into this type of film, it had better be funny, and this wasn't. Equally outrageous, stupid, and even less humorous (if possible) was Buehler's supposed duping the maitre d' in the swanky restaurant. This wasn't as funny as even the weakest skits, performed every week on SNL or Mad TV - and far more appropriate to one of these.

It's amazing how many John Hughes films I hadn't seen before my 80's April film list. Ferris Bueller's Day Off was the Hughes installment for 1986, which followed a lovable mischief and his quest to get a day off from school and have a memorable day in the process. Starring Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, and Mia Sara, Ferris Bueller's Day Off attempts a fun look at the lovable loafer character that everyone seems to know at least one of in their life. Unfortunately, the film results in leaving one feeling resentment to a personality that is usually enjoyed.Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is a high school student that doesn't take much of anything too seriously, except getting out of responsibilities. Throughout the film, Ferris highlights some of his exploits that involve him avoiding responsibilities and making the most of his responsibility-free time. One morning, Ferris decides to take the day off from school and bring along his girlfriend Sloan (Mia Sara) and his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) and show them a good time. Cameron, especially, needs to unwind a bit, as he is his overbearing parents and constant stress is overtaking his life. Among the activities he decides to have the trio engage in, including a baseball game, hijacking a parade float, and swimming, Ferris also convinces Cameron to take out his father's prized Ferrari as their means of transportation. While Ferris is enjoying his time off with his friends, principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is out to prove that Ferris is faking his illness and intends to prove that, no matter what he has to go through to do so. Hot on their trail, but always a step behind, Ed Rooney won't stop Ferris from enjoying his day, but a destroyed car of his best friends father might.I love a film that breaks the 4th wall. Matthew Broderick breaks the 4th wall all throughout Ferris Bueller's Day Off. The continual breaking of an otherwise frustrating film was definitely the standout. I think most people would agree that they have met or known a Ferris at some point in their lives. We all know the happy-go-lucky person that never plans anything yet always has situations work out for them. Most of the time we can laugh off that personality and wonder if life will ever catch up to them. Watching the exploits of someone like that on-screen, though, was a maddening experience. Ferris had no regard for the person who he called his best friend. Although Cameron is a rigid personality that would occasionally do well to be pushed out of his comfort zone, Ferris continually disrespected him and pushing him to make reckless decisions that he will have to confront himself. The longer you watch the film, the more you think that Ferris is a jerk, and his sister might be right to resent him so much. On the bright side, the film did have a fun score and a great end credit sequence that really makes you stay until the last minute, a piece of cinema I miss.

Review title: the most accurate depiction of high school on film!
Review_body: At least that's what me and most of my friends believe. realistic portrayals of boring classes, easily tricked teachers, faking sick to stay home, and the utter joke that modern education is. Review title: An Over-rated Classic. A Pretty Good, Well-Directed Film.
What a day off can do for you!
Review_body: When it comes to making films about teenagers, John Hughes is really the only writer and director who can get it right. Some of his incarnations can be very thought provoking like The Breakfast Club. In other cases, they can be downright funny. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is such an example, and manages to be quite inspirational too.Set in Chicago (like all of John Hughes' films), the audience is introduced to Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick). Ferris is a teenager who realises life can be complicated. That is why you're never too old (or too young!) to have a day off.He fakes an illness to his parents with "a non-specific symptom", much to the chagrin of his sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) who just knows he is faking it. But still, his parents fall for it, hook, line and sinker. They believe their son is an angel who would never lie to them.Once they're gone, then the audience is properly introduced to Ferris Bueller. A hip, trendy, free-wheeling, philosophical spirit who has now been absent from school for a total of nine times in the past semester.One of the nice touches about this film is the way Ferris addresses the audience. He does seem to like to give sermons about how to enjoy life, and some of his observations about life are quite interesting. This derives from his personal philosophy that I must quote:"Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it."It is exactly for this reason he wants to take a day off from the monotony of high school. When we actually see some of his lessons, you understand in an instant why.But a day off is no fun on you're own. It is an experience best shared. Ferris wants his best friend Cameron Frye (The superb Alan Ruck) to join him.Cameron is the exact opposite of Ferris. Ferris doesn't worry about anything, and manages to make the impossible possible. Cameron, on the other hand, is a neurotic, paranoid young man who is not in school that day because he genuinely believes he is sick. He is terrified of life, and how it seems to control him.Ferris hopes this day off will help Cameron to reflect and learn to appreciate life instead of running from it. When Ferris (eventually) convinces Cameron to come over to his house, they still have to add one more person into the mix.Ferris' girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) has been invited along too. In a scheme concocted by Ferris, Cameron calls the school pretending to be Sloane's father. This is one of the most hilarious scenes in the film, because his impersonation is so funny it had me in hysterics. It made me wonder if Sloane's father was really like that.Claiming that Sloane's grandmother has passed away, they manage to get one over on the principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones). He is certain that Ferris is faking his illness, and would like nothing more than to catch him in the act. His purpose in the film is to expose Ferris and failing in every attempt.Once they've got their hands on Cameron's father's Ferrari, a car his dad loves more than life itself (and sadly more than Cameron), Ferris, Cameron and Sloane are ready to go.Once they're in the city, our trio enjoy the sights and sounds. From checking out the Sears building to a baseball game, dining at a fancy restaurant, enjoying modern art, the audience begins to realise this is all for the benefit of Cameron. He's not really enjoying himself, mostly because he's terrified something will happen to the car.Gradually, he does begin to loosen up. Events such as Ferris singing on a parade float help Cameron to do that. That scene is so funny, because the whole crowd join in on Ferris' enthusiasm. It's quite nice as well to see so many people enjoying themselves at once.Cameron eventually manages to bring his perceptions of life into focus. He knows he can't just stand by and let life control him. For too long, he's allowed that to happen. Because his parents have never given him the love and affection he has wanted, and given it to the Ferrari instead, his first act of rebellion is to destroy the car.He is willing to take the blame, because he now wants to be the agent of his own destiny. This is something Ferris has been trying to teach him. Cameron is the real star of the film, and his courage about standing up to his father for wrecking the car is both inspirational and touching.Matthew Broderick is perfect as Ferris Bueller, bringing the boyish charm he is famous for. With people like Jeanie and Rooney against him, and coming out on top, it is hard to dislike him. Although Jeanie learns something from this day too, and becomes a better person for it, like Cameron.This film has a great deal to teach, about how life's moments must be seized, and reflecting on it to make the way for a better future, not only for yourself, but for other people out there like Cameron. It also has a wonderfully surreal touch, that adds a whimsical feeling to the whole enterprise.This is definitely my favourite of John Hughes' teenage films.

Review title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off — The best way to skip school and have fun in the 80s
Review_body: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a teen flick by John Hughes which became a cult movie and is now a classic.Its genius lies in the direct perspective of the teen mind. It's not an exaggerated view in the sense that it is not trashy. It's just a dream day any teen would love to be able to pull off and Ferris the coolest dude everybody wants to know. Great story, well developed characters, and cool dialogs.The only negative things I can say are that I find that Matthew Broderick's acting is sometime a bit off. While it gives his performance a certain flair and a very distinctive flavor, it can be distracting at time. Mia Sara is also part of the those little negative things. She's just not top notch in this film, unlike Alan Ruck and Jeffrey Jones. She had done better.If you don't mind a trip back to the 80s, I recommend it.

Review title: One of the Most Successful Movies of all time
Review_body: First order of business, Rest in Peace Mr. John Hughes as of yesterday which was Thursday August 6, 2009. He made some of the greatest coming of age comedies and dramas of all time.Now on to the business, Ferris Bueller's Day Off. This very successful 80's comedy stars the very entertaining Matthew Broderick. The movie is really just a simply entertaining and excellent concept. Ferris is trying to play his parents for yet another absence this year. He finds himself once again home from school, so he calls up his best friend Cameron and they pick up his girlfriend Sloane from school.Following this Ferris has probably the best day of his life, all with the principal and his sister trying to bring him to justice. Honestly there is no reason to pick out the flaws in this movie, because the movie is just flat out entertaining and funny. So if you want to see a film that will not disappoint then I suggest you check out Ferris Bueller's Day Off, it lives up to its reputation as a classic.10/10

Review title: One of those movies you just CAN'T hate
Review_body: There is no way in hell anyone could hate Ferris Bueller.There are so many funny, silly, random, great moments.Matthew Broderick gives the performance of his career as Ferris Bueller, the fun-loving, school-hating, technology savvy, sneaky, smart, witty protagonist of this light-hearted story. Ferris is one of those characters you just want to see win in the end.Alan Ruck was funny as Cameron Frye, the nervous, insecure, self-loathing, self-contradicting best friend of Ferris.Mia Sara was good as Slone Peterson, Ferris's girlfriend. But she didn't contribute all that much to the plot.Jeffrey Jones was hilarious as Ed Rooney, the obsessive, evil, witty, determined principle.There were many other great small performances, like Ben Stein "Bueller...Bueller...Bueller...Bueller...".Throw in a great music score, original jokes and lots of memorable lines and scenes, you have one of the funniest movies of the 80's.9/10.

Not just an 80's classic. It's an all time comedy classic that just happens to be from a decade of great moviesThis is hilarious, easily Brodericks best movie. The games between Ferris and Mr Rooney are great. All of the actors do a top job but Jeffrey Jones steals the show as Edward Rooney, hilarious.Excellent comedy.

Fantastic one of Broderick's best.Check out for the scene in the restaurant,the dog scene with his headmaster and of course the specific song which also has a videoclip.I recently watched it and I will watch it again.Highly recommended.

Of the John Hughe's 80's frat pack movies, this is my personal favorite. While The Breakfast Club may technically be better, this movie is just a lot of fun to watch. I would love to try and do exactly what Ferris did in this movie, except for the fact that my city is boring and I'm too afraid of getting in trouble.As for negatives, well the musical numbers in the middle were annoying, not saying Matthew Broderick can't sing, but they were pointless and every time I just fast forward through them. Also some moments aren't that funny and go on for too long.The reason this movie works is because of Ferris, and it's weird, I should hate this guy, but he is just so charming and likable. I know I will get hate, but he's kind of like Sam Witwicky for me. Cameron is me, he acts exactly how I would act in this situation. And the movie is so over the top, unlike Breakfast Club, this one doesn't try to be realistic, which is why I like how the princibal acts. And it's just funny.

Review title: If you've got to remember, it's a fine memory
Review_body: He is known as the philosopher of adolescence, the creative genius behind the cash cow that is "Home Alone", and, last not least, incumbent role model for Kevin "Silent Bob" Smith. Writer-director John Hughes is all that and more. In a movie packed with memorable moments and outrageously funny scenes, he conveys the laughter and tears that come with growing up. Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick, arguably in his career's single moment of glory) radiates an indestructible zest for life, culminating in his spirited performance of "Twist and Shout" atop a parade float in Chicago's Von Steuben Day parade. Outstanding performances by Alan Ruck as world-weary Cameron and Jeffrey Jones as Ed Rooney, the headmaster from hell. Notable guest appearances by Jennifer Grey as Ferris' ball-busting big sister and Charlie Sheen as a juvenile delinquent. Watch it, then watch it again. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" gets better every time. Promise.

I've known if this film for a while but always been hesitant to get round to it as I don't really mix with comedies that are considered "classic" but this was one that certainly lived up to expectations. Postmodern but not overly pretentious and highly relatable I felt I watched it at just the right time personally as I can fully understand all the jokes and the characters situations. It's bold and ambitious in a way not too dissimilar to Home Alone and those high stakes usually result in some hilarious jokes. Packing in exceptional word play and other smaller scale physical jokes there's so much on offer here to laugh at as well as a serious and emotional "subplot" of sorts. A true classic of cinema and one I'd regard as in my all time 10

Review title: Smart A*s v. The Establishment -- Ferris Bueller Rules!
Review_body: Ferris Bueller was either loved or hated by his peers for always getting away with anything he'd do. Some would want him expelled, others want him for Class President. On this extremely eventful day, the audience is invited to follow Ferris, his best pal and his girlfriend from morning to afternoon (when they all should have been in school), enjoying a holiday declared by the resourceful Ferris Bueller.They get to speed on the freeway in a Ferrari, sing "Danke Schoen" on an Octoberfest Float, eat at the most exclusive restaurant in town and always keep just one step ahead of a furious principal in hot pursuit. With fake computer grade and attendance records, Ferris has it made.The scene where the principal hitches a ride on a school bus after having been "torn up" by Doberman watch dogs is worth the ticket price (Oh Yeah!). This is one of the funniest "high school prankster movies" ever! Has it been 20 years already? This is a definite Cult Classic! Right up there with Animal House and Caddy Shack.

Review title: classic 80s film - a joy to watch
Review_body: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a bona fide 80s classic. If you haven't seen it, where have you been? Much loved, much quoted and preferred, it stands the test of time as a gripping, funny, high school caper. Basically, Ferris Bueller is the class prankster and decides to play truant one day having convinced his friends (Ruck and Sara) to come along. So the plot follows the school Principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) trying the catch him out, to prove he is skipping not - as he claims - sick.It's brilliant. Broderick is so believable, mischievous and exciting to watch, against the foil of his sister played by Jennifer Grey pre-Dirty Dancing. The one-liner thief of the film is Charlie Sheen, in a small role, but memorable! This is the sort of film you watch again and again, don't turn over when it's on TV and know most of the lines from. Watch it and enjoy.

Review title: Longing for the transvestite of humor
Review_body: "Enjoying the adoidado vida" is not a great film just for its humor, sarcasm, direction and captivating personages, what makes this great work is its moral not explicit, its philosophy on the life to be fleeting and its ramifications on the perturbation of the head by cameron. The script that tells of the acts of rebellion of Ferris Bueller is opposed to the depression of cameron, the pair, along with the girlfriend of Ferris embarks on a journey of fun, after they leave class, in search of amusement and to enjoy life, but between these intervals each one understands a little more about life and about oneself. John Hughes is a director who knows how to talk and broadcast the dramas and yearnings of youth like no one, always dressed in comedy, his films take all audiences and always preach the philosophy of total entertainment, from beginning to end (not stopping even in the credits) , but John also uses his communication skills to talk to his audience (even though the feature of the breakdown of the fourth wall is widely used here), John creates a film of three characters discovering themselves, but of an emphasis mainly on Cameron , he is the character who understands his purpose and makes the biggest break of rupture of the film, the whole movie is based on trying to enter his mind and understand his personality -Vide the scene of the pictures- he is the real protagonist of the film, and John deserves all our respect for including all this layer on the long and cover of fun and comedy. But in addition to that, the feature has a wonderful technical direction, camera angles and cuts of the film are surgical, in addition to those against flat and long plans, not to mention the richness of screen compositions and costumes, and the striking soundtrack, speaking in remarkable things, we can not forget Mattehew Broderick, who plays the role of his life, although all the actors are great in their roles. Lastly, "Enjoying the Sweet Life" is a film that transcends generations with fun, good humor and intelligence.

Ferris Bueller. The coolest guy in his school, possibly in Chicago. After Ferris (Matthew Broderick) determines that he should have a day off he fakes sick and calls up his odd-ball, morbid friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) to come and pick him up in his fathers Ferrari 250GT California Spyder.After a few phone calls and smart designs, Ferris and Cameron are able to get his girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara) out of school. Now it is an all out adventure through downtown Chicago: going to a baseball game, singing in a parade, faking names at a restaurant and trying to solve Cameron's state of frozenness after seeing his car has an extra 100 miles on it. All the while Broderick brings the life out of the cool guy we always wanted to be in high school. Always on Ferris' tail is his high school principal,Mr. Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) and Ferris' hateful sister, Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) out to get him.The movie is funny and deals with high school life minus the drugs and sex involved in most high school films today. Broderick surprised me after seeing his work in Glory (1989) that he was able to do a comedy like this. This is the ultimate teenager film.Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Starring: Matthew Broderick, Mia Sara, Alan Ruck, Jeffrey Jones, and Jennifer Grey.4 out of 5 Stars.

Review title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986) - Bueller? Bueller? Bueller?
Review_body: The leader of the Brat Pack, the late John Hughes, comes back with another movie for all coming of age teenagers. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" takes place on a popular high school student named Ferris Bueller who gets away with everything, when skipping nine days of high school, and his principal is on the loose to finally get him busted. The movie was perfectly funny, and there were some perfect moments with drama hiding behind it. John Hughes has made a movie teaching us to do what we want, be free, have a day off, and get away with it. That sounds like something you can steal from a teenager's diary. And the great cast including Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara, Jennifer Grey, Lyman Ward, Jeffrey Jones, Cindy Peckett, and Edie McClurg, were all hilariously brilliant. But besides Broderick, who made a great favorite of a performance, it was Alan Ruck who caught my attention as Cameron, and looking at the character, reminds me so much of how I am as a person. I sometimes can't handle things, and can't get my way out of anything, and that makes me a bit similar to this particular character. Now, who knew John Hughes can come up with an awesome coming-of-age teenage story of the 80s, and put it on film. The movie was funny, dramatic, and mostly a well-written diary of what every teenager wants to do for a living. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off", in my review, "a well-written, coming-of-age story".

matthew Broderick stars as Ferris Bueller who decides that it is too nice outside to go to school and if he can get away with one more sick day - he better make the most of it..He then gets his best friend out of his true sickbed..sneaks his girlfriend out and has a day on the town taking in and doing anything and everything..with the usual close calls and the principal looking for the one chance to bust him A fun movie to watch...one of those movies where you turn off your brain..Broderick turns on the charm in his role, Grey is good as the fuming sister who cant believe that he is getting away with it, Norton plays his best friend and Mia Sara is his pretty girl..Almost all the adult characters are portrayed as idiots or just plain stupid.. on a scale of one to ten..7
