Perhaps John Hughes' hostage to fortune, certainly the only one of his films as director that has some--not a lot, but some--of the devil-may-care attitude of his days as a writer for the National Lampoon, when writing about sex with teenagers was his forte. Matthew Broderick stars as the antithesis of Hughes' usual sad sack heroes, a smarmy, cocksure, insanely popular high school senior with an optimistic, yet realistic, outlook on life who decides to cut school along with his girlfriend (Mia Sara) and best friend (Alan Ruck) and spend the day seeing the sights of Chicago; meanwhile his antagonist, Principal Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), plots his capture. Broderick is genuinely charming and perfectly cast as the sophisticated yet sweetly dorky kid that the director clearly wishes he had been and when Broderick's doing nothing but cajoling and insinuating, he fills the film with a heart that Hughes' other films sorely lack. It's all terrific, inspired fun until the third act when Hughes trudges out his usual collegiate psychobabble aimed squarely at the lesser characters of Ruck and Sara; then the whole thing submerges into the usual deep self-pity that renders his movies unbearable. With Jennifer Grey as Broderick's sister, herself a model of crack comic timing, and Charlie Sheen, uproarious in a scene-stealing cameo, as a placid, monosyllabic burnout with the wisdom of a Confucius.

Review title: A day in the life of Ferris
Review_body: There are some movies that hit the right spot with the right people and they become cult classics. We all know about star wars and the Rocky Horror Picture show. Did you realise that FBDO is also one of those cult movies. There are those who watch it over and over again....be warned before you get this movie, you could become an addict.The idea behind this movie is great. It is about all the lessons you learn during your school years which you don't actually learn while you are at school.Ferris is the sort of guy that school is good to. He is good looking, but not a jock, he is good at study but not a nerd, everyone likes him, but he is not a hero, he is good looking but wears bad 80s clothes and has a bad 80s hair cut.Skipping school, borrowing his friends dad's Ferrari, singing "twist & shout" at a parade and crashing an exclusive french restaurant don't quite add up to a riveting story.What we have a school student who is not a loser who makes good, but someone who is perhaps too perfect. He is the person whose head you would must like to shove down the toilet and flush on a bad day at school. But he is also the person you like and in many ways admire. He is the over dressed wussy boy you actually want to be (or perhaps date...or both).Like "pretty in pink" it was one of those movies in the 1980s you quietly mentioned to friends you liked only to find they also liked it. Because there is nothing else like it around it is worth seeing.

Review title: Would rather have gone to school
Review_body: It's hard to believe that John Hughes filmed this back-to-back with "The Breakfast Club". Ferris Bueller is a smooth operator who is something of a transgressive figurehead at his high school for his rebellious nature. Throughout "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" he breaks the fourth wall and addresses the viewer, letting them in on his schemes and tricks of the trade. On this day, he shows us how he fools his parents into thinking he is too sick to attend school, making it his nine sick-day this semester. His parents molly-coddle him and then head off to work, leaving him in bed. His miserable-faced sister (Jennifer Grey) sees right through his antics and loathes him for it. Another person who can not stand Ferris is the highly-strung school principal played by Jeffrey Jones (His performance being the only good thing about the film for me). He makes it his mission to find Ferris out and show him for the truant that he is. But Ferris has other ideas for his 'day off off' (They are actually highly unimpressive and uninteresting) and these involve his girlfriend and best friend Cameron. I usually don't mind Matthew Broderick but he creates one of the most irritating characters in movie history here. Bueller is sarcastic and very arrogant, and is not at all funny. Unfortunately, he never gets what's coming to him.

I've always loved 80's movies. So when I saw that this was on Netflix I was excited. It's a funny look at how to skip school. (Don't worry, it would never work today) However, when I finished watching this I thought: "This is the basic premise of a typical Phineas and Ferb episode." Kid plans something big. Parents are oblivious. Only sister knows truth. Tries to get brother in trouble. Fails. Evil guy vs. family pet. So yeah, Phineas and Ferb doesn't seem very original now. And this is so much better, anyway. It's got teen hijinks, humor, and is just all-around fun movie for the mid-high school-crowd. Grade: B- (took away points for profanity, and lots of it) 8/10 3.5/5

Review title: A Great Comedy Film That Is Really Fun To Watch When You Are Not In School(SPOILERS)
Review_body: SPOILERSWow, that was a lousy summary. Anyway, I had a very fun time watching Ferris Bueller's Day Off. It is one of the funniest movies ever made and is well, really, funny. When I watched this I felt like ditching school the very next day. I did not, but I felt like it. This movie contains some very famous scenes, like Ferris Bueller's trip back to his house, and the parade scene, and more. I also think that this Matthew Broderick's very best film, and funniest film.Here is the plot. The title pretty much says it all. A popular teenager named Ferris Bueller takes, well, the day off from school with his friend and his girlfriend. He pretends to be sick. Amazingly, his parents do think he is sick. He puts a dummy in his room. He takes a trip into the city of Chicago. The only problem is that his principal and his sister Jeanne do not think he is sick and they both try to prove that he is faking it. By the time he does everything he could possibly do he runs home to his house. His parents never found out that he skipped school.Overall, this is an excellent teenager movie. I also loved the very end of the film when Ferris Bueller asks the audience way they are still bothering him. The movie is over. Also, this is only Ben Stein's second film. He also has a great line, "Bueller? Bueller?" Anyway, anyone that is a fan of comedy would bound to love this film. This is definitely John Hughes's best movie.9/10Recommended Films: The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles.

Review title: I thought it was going to be a good movie, but I did not like it at all
Review_body: I am so disappointed as I was expecting this to be a good movie because of the good ratings and reviews it has, but I did not enjoy it at all. The problem I have with this movie is after Ferris skips school, he doesn't do anything exciting and rebellious, which made the movie boring for me. Also I didn't like Ferris's personality as I found him selfish towards his mate and his a bit too cocky. This is supposed to be a comedy movie, but I think there was only a couple of funny moments in the movie. I was trying my best to like this movie, but I just couldn't with a plot where nothing thrilling happens. I want to understand why this movie has gotten so much good praise because I don't; surely people watching this movie for the first time cannot like this movie and say it's better than most movies or TV shows of today that are based on high school and teen rebels.

Review title: Absolutely fantastic comedy classic - fun, sweet, and oh so righteous
Review_body: John Hughes' 1986 classic comedy Ferris Bueller's Day Off is irresistible. It set the benchmark for teen comedies which few have matched, with its all out fun story.The story is simple enough. Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is everybody's favorite guy. He's handsome, cool, funny, fearless, and charming to no end. He has a beautiful girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara), and a very paranoid, yet lovable best friend, Cameron (Alan Ruck). One day, Ferris wakes up and decides that he doesn't want to go to school, thinking that spending the day in downtown Chicago sounds like a better idea. So Ferris whips up a clever scheme that fools his parents, and drives to pick up Cameron and then Sloane at school. However, 2 people are not fooled: over zealous and crazed school dean Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) and Ferris's sister, Jeanie (Jennifer Grey...yes the one that dated Matthew Broderick...weird, eh?).The character Ferris Bueller is simply irresistible. Matthew Broderick brings an unprecedented amount of cool to the character that will make him one of the most lovable rebels in film history. Each of our 3 main characters compliments the other. While Ferris has his wild and crazy moments, Mia Sara's character brings out the good guy in him, as they have great on screen chemistry. Alan Ruck is also great. Cameron is the exact opposite of Ferris...paranoid, by the book, afraid of confrontation, and unwelcome to change. But that's what makes them such excellent buddies. Ferris brings out the best in Cameron and vice versa. Jeffrey Jones is great as well, and the film features a priceless cameo from Charlie Sheen that may be his on screen breakout (prior to Platoon, of course). All in all, this movie is a great example of why Broderick and Sheen are as bankable and famous as they are today.John Hughes just knows teenagers and the 1980's. The spirits of both are alive and well here. The music is 80's, as are the characters. But the mark of how great a movie it is and how classic it is is that it can be enjoyed by anyone from any generation. It's a great movie that I'd recommend to everyone. Everybody should see Ferris Bueller's Day Off, because of the wonderfully fun experience it is.10/10 --spy

Review title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off - Should Not Be Skipped!
Review_body: Ferris Bueller's simplistic view of faking out his parents is void. It's a lot more difficult than that nowadays, and the only way to get out of high school legitimately is actually being sick.Matthew Broderick is Ferris, with Alan Ruck as his sidekick, Cameron Frye.An interesting story, with a good cast, a kick butt musical number, witty remarks and a whole day of fun, there is no reason for anyone of any age to not love this classic.If you find one thing to despise about this film, point it out to me because I can't find anything to not like.

Sorry folks but got to go against the norm here. I pretty much hated this. I watched it in the 80's & couldn't remember much about it other than I liked it. Watching it again, heaven knows how. The worst thing I found was that it had dated badly. The first Home Alone say, retains far more features which keep it relevant & able to stand the test of time than this.My main comment is identical to the correspondent below. I too spent the entire film just hoping against hope that Ferris did get his come uppence & that I'd forgotten it. But sadly he didn't & the ending was poor. I never saw the Rooney teacher as the 'baddie' nor found anything that happened to him remotely amusing. Infact I struggled to see where any of the laughs in the film as a whole were. Also, I found Ferris' dad an absolute drip & irritating. Nor was anything they actually did in the day off even slightly exciting. Had I had a choice of a going to a museum, watching baseball or walking alongside a float I'd have chosen school any time. It was hardly worthy of a day off.And at the risk of being labelled a leftie I didn't like to see the stealing of someones car & then have it speeding around the roads with a uninsured & inexperienced teenage driver at the wheel, trivialised & inserted into a film in the hope of a few cheap laughs. Likewise I've always found something a bit sick in people who use family member's deaths as a means of bunking off school or work, and again this was the basis of more humour. Of course that happens and of course it has a place in films. Someone pretending their nan had died would fit in fine in the Godfather or the Krays but it didn't do anything for this film.3/10 the lively innovations.Oh & would anyone called Ferris be that popular?

Review title: I did not care for this cult hit.
Review_body: Ferris Bueller's Day Off-*-Worthless- Directed by: John Hughes. Written by: John Hughes, Starring: Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara, Jeffery Jones, Jennifer Grey, Cindy Pickett, Lyman Ward, Edie McClurg, Charlie Sheen, Ben Stein, Del Close, Virginia Capers, Louis Anderson, Max Perlich, T. Scott Coffey, Kristy Swanson.Pointless and irreverent comedy with Broderick as a cool as ice teen who ditches school with his best buddy (Ruck) and his girlfriend (Sara) but must avoid the angry principal (Jones) and every adult who tries to destroy their plans but miraculously fails.John Hughes is artificial in his storytelling because there is nothing truthful to say about teenagers. To him, there are two groups of teenagers, those that are unharmed and those that are harmed. By this, I mean Bueller as the unharmed and every other teenager out there as the harmed. Bueller is perfect in every sense of the word and I do not understand how a filmmaker fixated on the destabilization of the teenager could create a protagonist so devoid of conflict.Ruck's character is Hughes's attempt at realism if only Ruck had played the part a bit better in terms of conflict. Yet Ruck did what he could, the character's emotions come out toward the end and without any warnings, which is Hughes's signature uneven qualities. In the film, kids are great and all adults are morons, which is more nihilism than counterculture. It's silly and goes on without much of a point besides tips and tricks to an unrealistic day of fun grounded by a director who does not know how to keep the elements of his story together.

Review title: Sometimes funny, sometimes obnoxious, and sometimes just puzzling, "Bueller" is a transitional work
Review_body: "Ferris Bueller" has its moments, and most of the best ones are of its own making. The much greater number of moments that don't work are a mix of atonal original content and otiose memes of better films.Almost immediately, Ferris sets the movie outside the bounds of realism by talking to the camera. The technique suits Matthew Broderick's characteristic sense of detachment from the process of acting, his ability to exist on screen without seeming to even try to act but without seeming at all natural either. The cold eyes and feces- eating grin that accompany his verbal asides, though, give the impression that something more is going on in the film than whimsy. There is a darkness—not exactly a darkness, but a kind of menacing quality to the movie, as though it were a prank, and the audience is forever suspended in the instant of dawning horror and appreciation. It as as if John Hughes and a real-life Ferris Bueller are out joyriding in our cars while we are trying to figure out what we are watching, and realizing that it is both a joke for us and a joke on us.The laugh-out-loud bits are played fairly straight. Ben Stein's steady drone in front of catatonic students. Charlie Sheen's cameo in which "drugs" is an inevitable but perfectly-timed punchline. The cheery profanity of a seemingly old-fashioned school secretary. A glorious song and dance number in the middle of the movie fills the streets of Chicago with color, and the spectacle seems as rich with directorial intent as it is with pure exuberance. John Hughes' placement of WASP city fathers on one side of the street, the ethnic European element of the city in the center, and the black community on the other side is undoubtedly conscious, and is appropriate for Chicago. There is probably no attempt at a social message here; it is part of the movie's non-judgmental celebration of the Windy City, and to portray the city as integrated would have been false.A gawking fixation on Chicago adds to the sense that there is a movie going on beneath the movie, because there is no way that a kid like Ferris would choose this itinerary for his dream day. The Sears Tower? It's only for tourists. The Art Institute and its collection of 19th and 20th century masterpieces? Please. A black tie restaurant? I'd expect a real teenager to prefer deep-dish pizza and brats. Maybe the secret to understanding Ferris is that he's having the dream day that adults wish they had had, but only if they had known then what they know now.But if Ferris is such a figure of fantasy, and so above the movie, why does Hughes burden him and his friends with the serious suburban anxieties that some people decades later derisively dub "affluenza"? Hughes had covered that ground very well in "The Breakfast Club," a film whose kids are much more real. In this movie, with its cultivated sense of superiority and apathy, the periodic downshift produces whiplash and slows the pace to an intolerable crawl. Alan Ruck is a good actor, but his best friend character is designed to be a drag and succeeds at it better than intended. Mia Sara's idealized, sexualized girlfriend character is a drag, too, because she has so much less mold-breaking individuality than Ally Sheedy and Molly Ringwold had brought to their earlier collaborations with John Hughes and Matthew Broderick.Yet "Ferris Bueller" prefigures 21st-century entertainment in a way that the thoroughly dated brat pack films do not. Its use of antihumor, wherein a joke is held in abeyance for a long time while anticipation builds, and in which the big payoff is often understated, paved the way for postmodern high school comedies like "Napoleon Dynamite." This approach to humor is best exemplified by the additional content that plays during the movie's closing credits. Such stingers are rarely seen before "Ferris Bueller" but became a staple of the genre afterward. Instead of using 80s hits, the movie's musical cues are more timeless, like John Lennon and the theme from "Star Wars." Frequently, though, its pop culture references feel arbitrary and meaningless. Why bring "Alien" or Wayne Newton into this? They're drawn from a hat, like a "Family Guy" joke or an internet gif. The uneven "Ferris Bueller" is sometimes funny, sometimes obnoxious, and sometimes just puzzling.

Review title: This Movie Was Too Fairy Tale And Unrealistic!
Review_body: This movie was anyone's dream and no reality! (Spoilers ahead!) Ferris Bueller fakes being sick to get out of going to school. Why didn't his stupid parents know that he was sick. And why didn't the stupid principal catch him in the act? His friend was so stupid! How many people in real life would let their best friend borrow their father's car? Why didn't Ferris' father see him all of those times Ferris was near him instead of in school? In real life,  his sister would have told on him instead of covered up for him at the end of the movie!

Review title: A film as care-free as any day off.
Review_body: Matthew Broderick plays the title character in "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," a hilarious, congenial and timeless comedy from the 80's teen-flick king John Hughes ("The Breakfast Club," "Sixteen Candles"). When one sees the words "A John Hughes Film," one expects an 80's gem, a pure classic. In the case of "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," truer words were never spoken.Despite the fact that he is nearing the end of high school, Ferris will do anything for a day off. This means enlisting the aid of his depressed best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck), his too-nice-to-be-true girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) and a mint 1961 cherry red Ferrari. Cruising through downtown Chicago, taking in a baseball game, partaking in a parade, inspiring an outlandish dance routine, strolling through an art museum and playing grown-up at a classy French restaurant, Ferris is bound and determined to live it up, partly for himself, and partly for the benefit of his troubled friend. Along the way he must match wits with his principal (Jeffrey Jones) and his bitter sister, Jeannie (Jennifer Gray).Without a doubt, this is Broderick's signature role, the one he will be remembered for. Despite the fact that his character appears mildly psychotic – throwing caution to the wind one too many times, talking to imaginary people (a.k.a. the audience) – it's a well-written one that is as likable as it is life-like. If John Hughes was known for one thing, it was creating believable teenagers on film, and Ferris' best friend Cameron is perhaps his best example. Alan Ruck nearly steals the show as the character more people can relate to, but despite his serious tone, never drags down the film and the film never feels too melodramatic for it. The rest of the cast is superb as well. Jeffrey Jones is unforgettable as the mad principal holding a grudge, and even Charlie Sheen manages to sneak it a cameo as a charming junkie.The film is sharply written, brilliantly paced and most importantly: Timeless. The idea of skipping school (or work) is a fantasy we've all indulged in at one time or another. Surprisingly, it has not dated itself too badly either. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is simply a fun film that people from all walks of life can appreciate and which generations of teenagers will relate to many, many years down the line. To put it in a sentence, they sure don't make 'em like they used to.

Review title: Spoilt brats laugh at the working man
Review_body: Let me first say that the main story here, involving the kids, contains many iconic scenes.The problem is the sub-plot about the misadventures of the school's principle (Mr Rooney) which seems to come from a different and inferior film. Its lazy slapstick brings to mind the worst parts of Police Academy or Home Alone.But the problem is deeper than that. It is philosophical.For here we have 3 affluent kids who have pampered lifestyles (particularly the insufferable Ferris), and our sympathies are supposed to lie with them. Meanwhile the butt of the joke is someone who actually has to work for a living.The cruelty with which he is subjected to humiliation while the kids swan around at others' expense is actually quite sickening. It is like seeing aristocrats gorging themselves and then being invited to laugh at their servants.It is no good saying that he is an authority figure. That would only work if the kids were of a lower standing in society as he is. If they were Chaplinesque hobos who needed to kick a cop up the behind or they were acting out of necessity, you could understand it. But they are entirely selfish.Ferris Bueller is an impossibly perfect youth, good looking, pampered by his parents, with a beautiful girlfriend and an assortment of gadgets which would have cost his adversary, principle Rooney, a year's wages back in the mid 80s. We are constantly told how popular he is in school. Why? I imagine a real life Bueller would annoy the hell out of most people.His friend Cameron has access to at least two cars, one of which is a fabulous Ferrari which his father keeps in a large garage overlooking a specular wooded area.And we are supposed to care that these, and Bueller's girl, go on a joyride? Rather like in the old Road Runner cartoons, which suppose our sympathies should lie with a one-dimensional annoying character rather than the harassed workaholic, I guess many people were hoping that Bueller would get his comeuppance in the end. Alas no such luck.

"Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is a 10/10 in my book and one of my favorite comedies, especially of the teen genre. The only other teen comedy I gave a 9 or 10 to is "10 Things I hate about you". In my opinion "Ferris Bueller" is not only John Hughes best film, but one of the best comedies in general. The three lead actors are terrific, the supporting cast is also great, and the film moves along nicely, leaving the audience feeling as if they joined Ferris on the day's adventure.The other plus for "Ferris Bueller" is that it is funny without needing to be too crude or crass, which most comedies of this genre are. And the film does not feel dated even today; it doesn't have that excessive 1980's feel that say "Pretty in Pink" has which was released the same year. Also, the cinematography is top notch, with Chicago and its suburbs providing an excellent setting, almost becoming a character in this film.And who can forget the terrific art museum scene which is one of my favorite scenes in all of cinema. It was filmed beautifully with a great instrumental musical track overlaid. While Ferris and Sloane kiss under the beautiful blue stained-glass, Cameron is searching for himself in the complex pointillist painting of Seurat. This scene exposes the audience to art that they might not have otherwise seen; this is unique in film, for what other big film spends minutes showing an art museum? And this scene is far from boring, rather it is one of the highlights of the film, making the whole film anything but fatuous.I also liked how both Sloane and Ferris are keen on getting married soon, nowadays I don't think this attitude would appear in film. People today seem reluctant to get married, especially at a young age. But I think it is nice to see Sloane and Ferris be honest and vulnerable with their needs and wishes. If you are fortunate enough to find someone to love, who loves you back, then why not tie the knot sooner rather than later?"Ferris Bueller" is the film which perhaps best embodies those feelings of being 16-18 years old, unsure of your future, but full of hope and optimism, with a twinge of fear. It shows an age in betwixt childhood and adulthood, where one is old enough to go have a fun adventure independently, but not too old to enjoy it. Youths are not yet jaded by the world, filled with ennui and boredom, just a trip to a city can be an exciting adventure at that age. Whereas older folk often just want to rest, weary from work and life's responsibilities.So, watch this film to relive those youthful days if only for a few hours, days which were full of wonder and magnificent possibilities. Sure Ferris is self-centered, spoiled, and maybe narcissistic, but he is that friend that so many of us need, the guy who can pull us out of our comfort zone and motivate us into doing something fun and memorable while you have the chance, because as he said: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."

Dated, not particularly funny. Quite frankly Ferris is really annoying.
Sorry.

In my opinion John Hughes's best movie, great non-stop action, memorable scenes, well picked actors, good acting, this movie is definitely on of the best movies from the 80's. You can definitely see where John Hughes got the ideas for Home alone, since Ed Rooney got treated the way the thieves did in home alone. :D Ferris Bueller just could pull anything off, on the other hand his friend Cameron was scared to do anything. This is a great message, sometimes it is better to risk and try, not just sit around wasting your time and being bored. The things Ferris did were a little bit too hard to pull off in real life, but the point was, that with courage and confidence you can do so much and it is really one of the most important things in life.This movie, without a doubt, is a classic, definitely one of the greatest comedies ever. Remember, sometimes it is better to take a day off school and to something fun and memorable, but only sometimes ;)
I loved this movie! Everything about it was hilariously absurd and very enjoyable. If you want a good laugh and a good time, watch this movie.
Although it has its memorable moments, it falls short of the plot and charisma of the characters.

Ferris Bueller is a film icon. His performance is electric as he breaks the third wall, helps his best friend find himself and have an amazing day off. "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it." One of the best and most carefree films of all time.

Review title: Fun, but not terribly fun for adults.
Review_body: I'm going to say something unpopular here. Ferris is not a very likable character. While I loved this movie as a kid, and I find the surreal aspects of the movie incredibly enjoyable, it hasn't aged very well. Viewing the picture as an adult, I find Ferris to be ultimately too selfish, too narrow-minded, and too pseudo-intellectual.Regardless, the film is fun, but only until you grow out of it, then it becomes a reminder of how short our sight is as a know-it-all high school student.The characters are pleasant caricatures, the only exception being Cameron, who is treated poorly.To see a real high school hero, go watch the Ferris knockoff, Parker Lewis.

Review title: Take a day off and watch this gem
Review_body: John Hughes defiantly had his finger on the pulse of teen comedy when he made this gem. My favourite comedy of all time, it has everything you want to keep you entertained. It is about a boy bored with school who decides that he is determined to have one last day on the wag before he and his friends finish for good.  Despite being totally over the top in many parts you will be able to relate to near enough everything that happens during the first half an hour. Tying to fool your parents by faking illness, The stroppy sister telling them that there's nothing wrong with you while your extra busy parents are in a rush! Best of all, which will strike a chord with everyone is the boring teacher who sends everyone to sleep as he rattles on in a monotone voice!!! Matthew Broderick is excellent in the role he was born for, while I wish they had girls in my school who were are gorgeous as Mia Sara, convincing as his girlfriend. Alan Ruck is brilliant as Ferris' extra nervous hypochondriac best friend Cameron while Jeffrey Jones is a hoot as Buellers Nemesis (The Headmaster at school)  The gags speed along just as fast as the kids do in Cameron's dads Priceless Ferrari!!. Comedy like this makes good viewing for everyone and I recommend it highly.

John Hughes is one of my favourite writers and directors. He has the ability to write teenagers in a realistic way and Ferris Bueller is one of two defining films of his career - the other being The Breakfast Club and as much as I love both films, Ferris Bueller's Day off is one of my all time favourite movies. The fact that it was written so quickly is just insane by how great it came out. I have watched this movie the most out of any film and still haven't gotten bored of it. The epitome of '80s cinema and one of the greatest comedies of all time! Save Ferris!

Review title: Ten stars for "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".
Review_body: Before all the slapstick, before re-writing "Home Alone" umpteen times and before selling his soul to "Disney Pictures Inc.", John Hughes was believed to be THE scribe for teen angst. He wrote eloquently of it in "Sixteen Candles", "The Breakfast Club" and "Pretty in Pink". And with "Ferris Bueller's Day Off", he creates a person and a time in life that just about anyone who's ever been a teenager can relate to.Who hasn't known someone like Ferris Bueller? Someone who always has a plan, someone who made loafing off an art form, someone who could fall in a barrel of you-know-what and come out smelling like a rose?All he wants to do is take a day off from school and enjoy the day in Chicago - simple enough, but he must also try and convince his best friend Cameron (Ruck) and his best girl (Sara) to join him and, in the process, learn to enjoy what life has to offer.Naturally, there is a tyrannical school dean (Jones) who is determined to catch Ferris in the act of hooky and Ferris' own sister (Grey, PR-nose job) who has it in for her brother, the "trouser-snake". There are funny situations throughout the movie, and the characters are ones that grow on you, especially Ruck's worry-wart portrayal of Cameron Frye, constantly fretting about his dyslectic, cursing his father and nearly drowning in a pool, all in the name of friendship.Sara has less to do, but she plays the object of desire well, and Ferris' passion for her is understandable. At least he thinks about the right things, like what their lives would be like after high school.All the way from beginning to end, this movie is a great trip in search of fun, relaxation, not taking life too seriously and how to sing Wayne Newton songs in the middle of a parade. You want to catch vintage John Hughes and classic '80s tendon at its best? Seize this "Day"!Ten stars for "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".

if you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it" says Ferris (Matthew Broderick). Twice. A wise statement. In the pop 80's, »the decade that made as« (as advertised in National Geographic). An era, where USA was in it's heights (pop culture were exported oversees), materialism was the name of the game (Ferrari GTO, stock market, slow food restaurants), the music was dance/pop/new wave (Ziggy Ziggy Sputnik, Yello,MTV was the channel, which actually aired music videos), John Hughes made the movie in which everyone around the world could adopt. I remember, that I was in elementary school, when it was in '86 played in our cinemas and it was a huge hit back than. Everybody wanted to be Ferris, skipping school and enjoying freedom in sunny day. Seeing this movie some 25 years laterit brought a lot of memories. At first, i was a little bit skeptic, if I would be still fond of it, but after seeing it, i can only say:« Kudos to John and the cast for making this masterpiece, still watchable and enjoyable some 30 years after«. It's one of that movies, which simply makes you feel good. It hasn't got any weak parts and after watching it, you are sad that is over. As for me, a critical viewer, i rate it 9/10. (It would be 10/10, if they put Micheal J. Fox in it, instead Matthew, but i guess he was too busy with Back to the Future trilogy). Sure, one could argue, that some scenes are highly unlikely and that it hasn't got a depth in the characters (like in »Breakfast club«), but all this is forgotten, when you dive in Ferris world of a free man and watch unforgettable "Twist & Shout" scene.

Review title: Forget everything else, THIS is the best film ever made.
Review_body: Where do I start? This is just too good to not see. Every scene is a classic, from start to finish.Highlights include:Ferris' guide to faking sick, The "snarty" waiter, Twist and Shout ft the actual mayor of Chicago, Dad's advice over the phone, Water Music with vomiting sounds (funnier than it should be!), Ferris' Dad's driving mannerisms, Charlie Sheen's druggie, shave and a haircut.I could go on.The quotes are endless; I use so many in my daily life that I could probably recite it all by rote:Hey Ferris hows your bod?, You killed the car, Niiiine tiiiiiimes.... , Shouldn't you be in class? Probably, So that's how it is in their family.Again I could go on.Life goes pretty fast. If you don't stop and see this film you could miss one of the greatest pieces of entertainment ever made.Save Ferris!

I've been scanning reviews for various movies on this database and I am always a little surprised that in reviews for films, that are absolute tripe, you will find the odd person that loves it and vice-versa.  This got me thinking...ah Ferris, surely everyone must love Ferris, a simply superb cheer-me-up-feel-good movie, I was wrong.orb-2, I know we're all entitled to our opinion, but surely you're taking this film too seriously.  This film was a wonderfully done satire on student life and stereotypes, it was obviously ridiculous, but that was part of the point, this film was never meant to be taken literally or seriously it's just a wonderful fantasy film.Everyone wants to be super-cool, popular and in control, not to mention driving a Ferrari and singing beetles songs to everyone, but alas the world in not that way.  This, as films should do, is make us forget real life, the recession you mention, and indulge in our fantasies.   I for one have a big smile on my face when I watch this movie and it always cheers me up every time I watch it.  I would love to see more of the same. I suspect that if more people watched movies like this the world would be a better place.

Review title: What's wrong with this movie? Nothing!
Review_body: This movie pretty much set the bar for all teen movies.It's proof that you can be funny and rebellious at the same time.There are too many reasons why it's almost unsellable once you've bought it, but I'll just name my top 5.Number 5: The famous parade float dance scene... you gotta have some pretty big balls to do that.Number 4: It's a movie with a great message: (Say it with me if you know it.) "Life moves pretty fast; if you don't stop and look around, you might miss it." Number 3: It's totally quotable.Number 2: Simply put, cult films kick ass.and finally, number 1: Everyone who has a pulse and a sense of humor has seen it and loved it! If you haven't seen this, (that's rare.) do it! you'll love this movie.10/10

Great movie. Certainly not your average high-school movie fare.Ferris knows every trick in the book (hey, he wrote the book) for skipping school, pulling the wool over his parents' eyes, having his way with people...yet he doesn't just use all this for selfish ends, to have a good time. (not only that, that is...) The whole point of the excursion is to spend more time with his best friend Cameron, try to get him to shake off his terminal melancholy. Ferris connives, schemes, lies...but is in fact a good-hearted kid. You get the feeling that Ferris and, by the end of the movie, Cameron have a better grip on what's important than the people they're supposed to be learning from.I don't know whether his parents' amazing gullibility, or the fact that the kids skip school to visit an art museum, is harder to believe...but 's OK, go along for the ride anyway.

This movie had survived the test of time. I saw it recently and still laughed my ass off. Plus: it's the best tourist guide of the city of Chicago you'll ever find. Who can forget the role that made Ben Stein a legend? John Hughes, who will be remembered as the director who made the 1980s his decade, reached his peak with this film. A neo-classic.

Without a doubt, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is a 1980s comedy classic. This is a statement I believe most people would have a hard time finding fault with, but the question is -- how relevant is this movie today? For the most part, I'd say the film has aged relatively well. Sure, a lot of the elements are dated, such as the clothes, technology, fashion, and expressions of the day, but having said that, I still feel it is relatable to today's generation. Everyone's had a god-awful, boring teacher like Ben Stein, a friend who was wound up too tightly like Cameron, and a friend who got away with everything like Ferris.I do like this movie, but I've seen it so many times over the years that I do feel it's been played out. Now when I watch it, I don't laugh because I think it's funny, I laugh because I remember thinking it was funny in the past, and now it seems it's just a conditioned response.Realistically, it's probably highly unlikely, if not altogether impossible for Ferris to have done all that he did during his day off in the Windy City, but it wouldn't have been very fun to watch a movie called, "Ferris Bueller's Uneventful Day Off" either.The only problem with a movie as famous as this is that by the time you see it, assuming you've never seen it before, you probably know or have heard a lot of the famous lines, but never in context. It's worth seeing if only to be able to say you've seen it, too.This movie is definitely what put Matthew Broderick on the map, that's for sure. It's strange to think how at one time he played the ultimate cool kid, but now he's been relegated to playing mostly obnoxious losers. Actually, that's just sad.In closing, I'd say I recommend seeing it. However, keep in mind that as funny as you may find it initially, it will lose its luster in time. Is "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" still relevant today? Watch it and judge for yourself.

Review title: "Bueller...Bueller....Bueller", an icon in comic history, Broederick and Hughes are sensationally funny
Review_body: **** Matthew Broederick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara, Jeffrey Jones, Jennifer Grey, Charlie Sheen, Ben Stein, Edie McClurg. Directed by John Hughes. Comic icon John Hughes strikes again with this uncanny comedy of epic proportions, after winning big with other teenage films "Breakfast Club" and "Sixteen Candles". The story about a teenage kid Ferris (Broderick) who decides to take the day off with friends; high strung Cameron (Ruck) and his girl friend Sloane (Beautiful Sara). With principal Ed Rooney (unforgettable Jones) hot on his trail (so he thinks) and determined to catch Ferris if it's the last thing he does. One of the funniest movies about a day in the life of a teenager that just wanted to skip school. Hughes is the master of comedy when it comes to High School, one of my favorites. My final rating 10/10.

Review title: Beware of Friendships That are Sugar-Coated B.S.
Review_body: This movie is over-rated and uneven. I'm not even sure why it works, but it does. I think Reese was cast just for eye-candy, and I think the movie should have, instead, focused on the interaction between Ferris and Cameron: What does Ferris have to offer Cameron? Is it possible that Cameron has something of value for Ferris to learn? Because of Bueller's smug attitude, even toward his best friend, the manipulation disguised as "liberation" he offers Cameron comes to a destructive, suicidal head as Cameron acknowledges the lie he is living and seeks escape from both his unfeeling father and Bueller. There are some funny moments in the movie, don't get me wrong. Broderick also has charm and stage-presence. The supporting cast is wonderful, especially the High school administration members. Jennifer Grey is a fine actress and Charlie Sheen's cameo is memorable. In Ferris Bueller's Day Off, the main character gives us a somewhat potent illustration of the lesson many of us need to un-learn: How to project an illusion. As a testament to Cameron's character, he survived the "friendship", and hopefully, there-after, demanded a new level of authenticity from his social contacts.Even with Ferris's falsity and smugness, his manipulation and shallowness, we all find ourselves rooting for him during the movie; (even at the absurd, surreal end scene where the entire city is gathered at an indescript "parade", with Bueller doing an impromptu, amplified lip-synch to a rock n roll song. Screw the fact that he might have just ruined his only friend's life: He wants to be the center of attention and adulation.

I've recently met too many people in their twenties that haven't actually seen this film (although they're familiar with it). Twenty-six years later, however, it's still hilariousthe fashion and technology are outdated, but the comedy is timeless, and the commentary on society is still keen. Broderick reminds you that every day is an adventure waiting to happenget off your couch and carpe diem! Ben Stein became famous from this film by demonstrating the pitfalls of the lecture system in high schools. With the help of burn-out street therapist Charlie Sheen, Jennifer Grey shows you how sibling jealousy will only hold you back in your enjoyment of your own life. And Ruck exhibits how rich, repressed kids can turn into ticking time bombs.This movie is a pop culture icon. The recent Honda CR-V Super Bowl commercial is a testament to that. If you haven't seen this flick yet, your penance is throwing an 80s party within the next couple of weeks, featuring an old-school boombox, Pop Rocks & Mountain Dew, and a screening of this filmand invite me; I'm there.For more reviews and a kickass podcast, check out www.livemancave.com

The movie contains certain scenes that may require Parental Guidance (PG) but far better than high school movies of today. Other than that it is a family entertainer and is one of the best. Review title: A Few Laughs, But Predictable and Over-Rated
Review_body: I remember this movie when I was in my first year in college, People billed it as a classic and it certainly made Matthew Broderick a star. The problem that I have with this movie is that I have a resentment for smart-alec know it all kids who make adults look like one-dimensional airheads, making the kid out to be some sort of hero for skipping school, slacking off, and pushing people into uncomfortable situations. The audience thinks that the "Know it all" is the greatest, coolest, most wonderful person in the whole world. But in reality, Ferris Bueller is a character with an attitude. Give Matthew credit for playing him brilliantly, but if you are like me and a "character type" person rubs you the wrong way, you won't think this movie is as great as so many make it out to be.We all know the story: Ferris Bueller is a typical high-school slacker who wants to take the day off, so he cons his RIDICULOUSLY gullible parents into believing that he is sick, calls his best friend Cameron over, talks poor Cameron out of stealing his father's Ferrari out of the garage, picks up his girlfriend Sloane by disguising himself as her father in a phone conversation, conning the Dean of Students Mr. Ed Rooney into believing that her grandmother has passed away so that he can get her out of class disguised as her "Dad" driving Cameron's Dad's classic car.He acts like a jerk in a classy restaurant to a Matre'D, pulls a few strings to get an expensive lunch, goes to an art museum, and a baseball game, while always able to elude Mr. Rooney and his parents.It's the typical teen comedy movie where you root for the teen because he's able to get away with crap, while the parents and school administrators can't catch him. It's too bad that the adults are made to look so superficial in this movie, because some do a good job such as the zany school secretary, some funny lines by the Dean of Students Mr. Rooney, and Ben Stein as an economics teacher, (Who's lecture, other than the roll call, was improvised because he had a Master's Degree in economics and John Hughes the director liked the idea.) Maybe it's because I have grown out of the teen years, might be another reason why I can't give this movie a higher review. I think people in their teen-early adult years might like it better.

Review title: Good, but why the high rating?
Review_body: I don't get why this movie is Rated PG-13 in the U.S. I really like Matthew Broderick's performance, I just wish he hadn't talked to the camera. Of all the movies ever made, Ferris Bueller feels like one of the most iconic movie characters. Years after this movie was made, there'd be an even more iconic movie character in a Coming Of Age movie, Napoleon Dynamite. Napoleon Dynamite which I think was supposed to take place in the 2004-2005 School Year as it said it on his I.D. looks like it was supposed to take place in the '80s. Ferris Bueller actually does take place in the '80s, but looks like a more modern recent film than Napoleon Dynamite, even though obviously the producers didn't intend for Napoleon Dynamite to look modern. I'm not a fan of Napoleon Dynamite, and would say Ferris Bueller is a much better movie.About being iconic, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is no doubt one of the most iconic '80s movies, and most iconic Coming Of Age movies. So, I just mentioned 2 more aspects that make this movie iconic. Watching this movie gives you an '80s vibe. I've heard so many people wish they could go back to the 1980s. This movie will give you a reason to wish to go back, especially as a High School Student back then.Even though this movie is from the '80s, like I said it will not look so old. It is no doubt a timeless movie. They brought out some of the best technology they had at the time this movie was made. A computer before computers were everyday devices, and hacking onto somebody else's computer in the '80s. A Ferrari from 1961. A synthesizer which was $8,000 in 1984. We see how Ferris's keyboard has sound effects of coughing. We have a nice suburban neighborhood with nice houses, and a lot of this movie takes place in the city of Chicago. There's that memorable exciting scene of the parade.The plot of the movie is also timeless. Playing hooky from school. A high school student not feeling like the things he's learning in school are worth his time. But, we have the main message and quote from this movie, "Life Moves Pretty Fast, If You Don't Stop And Look Around Once In Awhile, You Could Miss It."Another interesting thing about this movie is how the whole movie takes place in a single day. It doesn't even go to night. This movie is a clear example of enjoying life and how much you can do in just a single day!! That reminds me, I think it's interesting how we think time flies. It can be hard to believe how many days have passed in our lives from moments that happened years ago that might not seem so long ago. We can easily calculate online how many days have passed since then, and it will seem like a lot. Most of us wouldn't be able to remember at the top of our head what we did on a random date years ago. I've heard of some people with a memory that good. It's hard to believe that each one of those days was 24 hours.But, that's what make this movie amazing. They might be awesome movie characters, with the right actors for their parts. We might be curious about what happens next? But, this movie has no official sequel, because it's supposed to be a certain day. I think this movie shows us how much we can do just in a single day. We can't get the time back when it's gone, and it's hard to believe how many days have passed. But, we can ask, "What Can I Do Today?"This movie is a fun exciting movie to watch that will put you in a good mood. If you haven't seen it, definitely see it!! This is one movie that is worth seeing at least once in your lifetime.

Review title: Possibly my favourite movie of all time!
Review_body: "Life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop to look around once in a while you could miss it." Ferris Bueller's Day Off isn't only my favourite comedy of all time, it could also be my favourite movie of all time! I have watched this movie four times over the course of four days, this movie is so damn re-watchable. I found myself relating more to Cameron and kinda hating Bueller.It's so quotable as well! This review will contain spoilers so if you have not seen Ferris Bueller's Day Off... WHAT ARE YOU DOING WITH YOUR LIFE? Seriously! The movie begins with Ferris in bed, he's a very sick boy, his parents insist that he stays home. "I better get up. I have a test today. I want to go to a good college so I can have a fruitful life." His parents go to work and we find out that it was just a big prank, "They bought it!" He has quite possibly one of the greatest opening monologues in film history (no searching up, I remembered it off by heart); "Incredible, one of the worst performances of my career and they never doubted it for a second. How could I possibly be expected to handle school on a day like this?"We get a very hilarious introduction to the character Cameron played by Alan Ruck. "I feel like complete sh** Ferris, I can't go anywhere. When Cameron was in Egypt's land, let my Cameron go!" "Pardon my French, but Cameron is so tight that if you stuck a lump of coal up his a** in two weeks you have a diamond." It's just... so quotable. Cameron drives to Bueller's place to make a phoney phone-call to the school principal, Edward Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) pretending to be Slaone Peterson's dad (Ferris Bueller's girlfriend). This scene is 110% hilarious!They say her grandma has just passed away and that they want Slaone outside the school so they can pick her up. Their plan works of course, because, I mean, it's Ferris Bueller, the guy knows what he's doing, they go drive Cameron's dad's Porsche around the city and go to a museum, a fancy restaurant and many other places.Overall, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is just one of those perfect movies and of course I am going to give "Bueller? Bueller? Bueller? Bueller?" an A+.

Ferris Bueller is truly a 1980's classic, defining a generation of young and bored teenagers, emphasising the escapism that repressed many a teenager alike.We all dream of being Ferris Bueller, what a cool, righteous kid that guy is; what I most liked about the lad is how relate-able he comes across, he isn't a young thug, or a hoodlum that you simply despise, he's a simple crafty kid that just wants a day off (don't we all?), and he'll do everything in his power to get that day off.The pacing of the film is top notch, it never misses a single beat and keeps you hooked throughout, my only qualm, if you could call it that, is that it just didn't last long enough, I wanted more thrills, more adventure, I pictured myself in Ferris shoes and didn't for one moment want to take them off. The 1 hour 43 minute run-time felt like robbery, couldn't it have lasted at least a half hour longer?Alan Ruck played the dumb friend, Cameron, very well..., Mia Sara was excellent as Ferris girlfriend, Sloane..., and as for the master Matthew Broderick, in my humble opinion, he was outstanding as one of cinema's most iconic characters (yeah you heard me right). The best of the best in turns of scenes had to be at the school, as Ferris craftily tried to pull the wool over the eyes of his principal, Mr. Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), also as he tries to pull his girl Sloane out of class, pure genius, subtle comedy at its funniest.Jennifer Grey, who would go onto play the lead role in hit musical, Dirty Dancing, had a smaller role here as Ferris sister, Jeanie..., although only a minor role, the serious performance of Jeanie who despised her brother and carried a hint of jealousy and dismay towards him, only added to the humour. He wanted a day off and boy did he get one, now I suggest you take a day off too to watch this well sculpted 80's masterpiece..., do it now before Mr. Rooney catches you!

Review title: Please Ferris, tell me how you do it!
Review_body: Oh, God- if only it were that easy. I try to ditch school and the teacher phones home to ask how I'm feeling, and... well. Yes, obviously it's no cinch for Ferris to not get caught, but as we learn, Ferris Bueller never gets caught. Sure it's no sophisticated Oscar winning comedy but I'll watch it over 'Shakespeare In Love' any day. Why? It's light, it's easy, you don't have to stop and think to understand the jokes, it's one of those stupid comedies that you can't resist. One of those movies that you keep in the video drawer and watch on a rainy day... it's also a movie you don't want your kids to get ideas from.I haven't seen many of Matthew Broderick's films but from those I did, this is my favorite (I mean Godzilla, eh ok, but Inspector Gadget, in the old Jewish words of wisdom: Oy Vay). Matthew Broderick is absolutely brilliant and Alan Ruck (Cameron) and Mia Sara (Sloane) are great too. I have many favorite lines, but one of them is in the beginning where Ferris explains the rules on how to ditch school without getting caught, after he finishes explaining- he then says: "It's a little childish and stupid but then- so is school". I also liked when he said: "I asked for a car, I got a computer. How's that for being born under a bad sign?", yes Ferris- we sympathize with you. But enough quotes.Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a great movie that can be enjoyed by anybody (even teachers, well maybe I'm going a bit too far now). It's one of my top ten favorites, a must see for all kids who wanna skip school and a reminder to parents of how naive they can be some... all the time.

Review title: Movie is good for fun but with a 2020 perspective it's a bit overrated
Review_body: Sure Bueller isn't a total jerk but it seems unnecessary that in order for him to be happy he had to step on some people as much as he did. The Cameron angle which is supposedly the center of the story according to die-hard fans of the movie isn't anything spectacular since it's done relatively artificially and without much coherence.

Review title: Life moves pretty fast ...so take the Ferrari that smells like a diaper!
Review_body: Before Matthew Broderick became typecast as a lukewarm simpleton, he was the epitome of 80s cool. British flag adorned doors be damned, Broderick was the natural heir to the throne of cinemerican teendom. James Dean was rendered irrelevant the instant a Mohicaned Matthew decided to sing in the shower. I mean this is a righteous dude who can eat pancreas, contemplate modern art, make downtown Chicago sing and dance all in one irresponsible day. Ferris' technological arsenal of tricks designed to dupe adults make anything that Kevin McCallister concocted look childish. But the best thing about Ferris Bueller's Day off is not Ferris Bueller. No! It's his best friend Cameron Howe! Cameron is a depressed hockey player (formerly of the Detroit Red Wings) who quite frankly deserved a sequel based solely around his plight. Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and steal your friend's dad's Ferrari and visit an art museum once in a while, you could run the risk of being lamer than a vest with no leopard print.

This is a good movie. It's a comfy classic that's fun to revisit from time to time. Like a fair amount of 80's movies, I don't find it hilarious, but it has a couple chuckle-worthy moments. The characters are loveable and relatable (to a degree). My favourite part is when Cameron freaks out at the end.

This movie is such a classic! It has very funny moments and has also very iconic scenes and quotes. The acting is great, there were just some scenes where I thought Mathew Broderick wasn't that great. I loved the ending, that was my favorite part of the movie!

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of those "feel good" movies that makes you want to laugh or in my case, memorize every single cute commentary of Ferris Bueller. remember in the bathroom scene? the European socialist test. i laughed my head off in such funny and witty comment by Ferris. John Hughes is absolutely wonderful. he can make people laugh and think, "hey, he has a point!". filled with the ever so popular street scene, Ferris can do anything to make you just smile like crazy. definitely a 10 for this amazing movie.

Review title: I first saw this in a high school class
Review_body: I first saw this movie after a test in high school (believe it or not), and this what I call a classic movie. I will admit it does get slow at times, but the Ferris Bueller character has to have almost every teen's dream come true. First he fakes being sick to stay home, then takes his friends out on a wild cruse through the city using a car he practically swipes from his friend's rich father.The only part I didn't care much for is that it gets a little slow in the middle. One part of this was the scene with his sister coming home and the principle breaking into the house. It was also rather unbelievable when he tries to take the car's mileage out running the car in reverse, and accidentally breaks it through the window. But the movie does pick up at the end, when he goes running back to his house and fools his family again, all hot and sweaty (from his run), his parents think that he is still sick with a bad fever.

Review title: Ferris Bueller can have all the days off he wants.... when he's expelled
Review_body: My friend told me i had to see this movie. he said i'd love it and i'd add it to my collection in an instant. not only did i NOT love it, i did add it to a collection. my 'light the movie on fire' collection.This is one of the most infuriating movies i've ever watched in my life. i don't know why everyone loves it, and i was in high school when i first saw this, so i was at the perfect age. and i STILL hated this movie.Besides not liking Matthew Brod (except in lion king) the main thing that frustrated me in this movie is that ferris decides that he deserves to have a day off. This confused me because he'd already had 8 days off and he couldn't have another one off. Now correct me if i'm wrong, but doesn't that mean he's already done this EIGHT times? so WHY does he deserve a day off? he doesn't and should be in school. Maybe it's because my mom rocked, but when i didn't feel like going to school because i had a test i didn't study for or something, she let me stay home. however, that's because there was TRUST and i never broke it. This movie spits all over parental/son trust and just everyone in general. I did not find this movie enjoyable in the least. it's the second most overrated movie next to godfather and it's boring and stupid. I felt REALLY bad for the principal and thought Ferris needed to be expelled. then he could have had all the days off he wanted. i saw this for the first time when i was 15 and now i'm 22 and i STILL despise this. The only lesson i gathered is to skip school, wreck a car, and everything will turn out OK. Bull.Ferris Bueller fails the chemistry test, with a 1. out of 10.

Review title: A family member dies... and you insult me, what the H*** is the matter with you????
Review_body: If you've seen Ferris Bueller Day's Off, then you should recognize the above line as one of the funnier quotes and scenes in the movie. The way principal Rooney stumbles over himself in an effort to appease Mr. Peterson (that's not really Mr. Peterson... so that's how it is in their family!) is one of the many highlights. Even 14 years after the film release, my friends and co-workers still drop lines from this movie constantly, and always get great laughs with them... "Yes... call the police, this should be a HOOT!!!", "I asked for a car, and they got me a computer... how's that for living under a bad sign?", "When Cameron was in Egypt's land... let my Cameron goooooooo!!!!"So many great scenes, lines and situations in this movie, that to tell you about them all, would take... well, it would take 90 minutes at least! So, just go rent or buy Ferris Bueller Day's Off, as I certainly can't tell them the way Hughes, Broderick, and crew do! "Would you like some life savers? They've been in my pocket all day, they're warm and soft!"

Review title: One Of A Kind. Often Imitated - Never Equaled.
Review_body: On my IMDb "Top 10 Greatest Comedy Films" list.No other "Coming Of Age" teen film since has been able to knock Ferris Bueller off its post-American Graffiti "COA" throne. Like the 1961 Ferrari GT 250 SWB California portrayed in this film (more than one used in production, and all were well-made knock-offs), there is simply no substitute. (albeit George Lucas' American Graffiti' still reins as the all-time #1 COA film, but that came 10 years earlier, and is in a class by itself).This was John Hughes' 4th directed movie, during his most prodigious period from 1984 to 1990, that also included 'The Breakfast Club' and 'Home Alone'.Hughes tried to portray teens realistically and gave them relevance in his films - he was empathetic to the challenges of adolescence, and consciously avoided Hollywood's often shallow characterizations of the teen high school years.The Library of Congress selected the film in 2014 to be preserved in the National Film Registry, honoring FBDO for its cultural significance.

Review title: Overrated, despite doing some things right
Review_body: When Ferris Buellers day off was released in 1986, it got so much positive reviews and became so famous it had a lot of movies/ TV shows reference it. That's just a brief history of a movie that I think is actually really overrated, frankly. But how come? The story in this is about a teen wise guy named Ferris who pretends to be sick so that he can force his friend to go and lie to get his girlfriend out of school so that the 3 can spend a day in Chicago. The problem with the story is that its just weak. I mean, just a highly sophisticated plan for a day off of school? That's not all. There's no emotional journey for the protagonist, no real drama, and no heartwarming moments. There's also no message. I mean, this film is so lighthearted they lacked all those things. But one thing people might be wondering, is at least funny? Well, the movie actually has some really great humor and plus its a little enjoyable to watch with a great soundtrack. But that still doesn't make up for the pitiful main story. Also, one really bad thing about this movie is that it makes skipping school when there's something important like a test without permission from your parents or teachers so that you can have fun look cool, which is a not a good message at all. I give it a 4.5/10 The characters in this movie. Let me say that they are just one dimensional with no development. First off, our main character, Ferris, is a high school hot shot who's selfish, unlikable when he bully's his Ill friend to go on the trip, and a liar. Like I said, he makes skipping school and being selfish look cool. He is an absolutely terrible role model for kids. His ill friend Cameron, is a character that you can feel bad for because of not wanting to be on the trip to Chicago but he's actually a great guy whose honest, kind, and doesn't find Ferris's selfish acts cool. Ferris's girlfriend Sloane is just a one dimensional girl who agrees to go to Chicago and forgettable. The "Villain" Principal Ed Rooney, is actually good because of trying to bust Ferris, but pointlessly bumbles around the suburbs doing so and has no development, but he's a bit funny. Then there's Ferris's sister, Jeanie, who is aware of Ferris's whereabouts. She's very bland and instantly forgettable.So overall, Ferris Beullers day of is funny, has great music and is enjoyable, but it still has a weak story, and lacks any real drama, emotion, and character development. The characters are all one dimensional with a couple of bland ones. So this movie is just a light hearted comedy, and if you want a movie with a valuable message, this is not it.
This film is my favorite movie ever! It has everything! It is a 1986 Great movie! Better than howard the duck by: Ten times!

How can she get through to her parents and expose her brother for the faker he is? (Recognize the guy she joins on the couch? None other than bad-boy bro to Bratpacker Emilio Estevez, Charlie Sheen...) Not to mention, Ben Stein's breakout role ("Bueller....Bueller..."), this also brought Jennifer Grey and Matthew Broderick to America's attention. (Feel sorry for Michael J. Fox...I heard he turned down this role. But he already had our attention, didn't he?) I went to the theater twice to see this one when it came out. I don't own it -- yet -- but am looking forward to adding it to my collection. Well worth sitting through this one. Enjoy it with your friends and even your kids. It's a lot of fun.
