He's selfish and rude, and totally irresponsible. I cannot believe that this movie is worshipped by a generation that calls younger people entitled.

Review title: This film became the basis for my education, sorry dad
Review_body: Another John Hughes classic teen movie. This film along with Blues Brothers ranks as my favourite film of all time.Why? Well its simple. This movie became the basis for my education (as my summary says) the things Ferris did to skive school and things he did WHILST skiving all became a part of my life - ok i wasn't old enough to drive, but i had a moped, and would go into the nearest city (peterborough in this case) and hang out, do the tourist thing etc.Ok, so skiving aside why does the film work. Chemistry and timing between the characters. You feel for Cameron and his many illnesses, you wanna see Ferris ALMOST get caught again just to see how he gets out of it, and Sloane, well she just looks cute in the pool scene.The gags are plentiful, and the cameo of Charlie Sheen very funny. I haven't seen the TV series, but i am kinda guessing it wasn't too much of a success otherwise it would be available on dvd :)I truly enjoyed this movie, and try to watch it every time its on sky. They just dont make films like this anymore, which is a pity as am sure kids of today would love a `hero` like Ferris :)

BEST MOVIE EVER! I laugh every time I watch this movie. I wish I could have that exact day with my friends. This movie is very clever and witty. I love every little facial expression, tone, and gesture. If you haven't seen it...please go watch it!

What a marvelous film.  I forget how many times I have seen this and can almost recite the dialogue verbatim.Matthew Broderick is a gem as Ferris.  He has a slickly clever attitude without being too cocky, which is a relief as the character of Ferris could so easily have been overdone.  Ferris makes you want to BE Ferris.  He holds your attention in the palm of his hand throughout.  His 'to the camera' moments are wonderfully done and give you a sense of being part of his capers.  The rest of the cast do their job admirably, especially Jeffery Jones as Ed Rooney who goes in search of Ferris.  Very comical.This is a Must See movie that I can heartily recommend.  You will not be disappointed.

_Ferris Bueller's Day Off_ is one of those classic movies where the main character's struggle is something we've all strived for at one time or another: the struggle to take it easy. We've all had that one teacher or authority figure in our lives that just drives us nuts, and in this movie, Ferris, his best friend Cameron and his girlfriend Sloane fight against school, evil principals, and thier own inner deamons. A perfect film for anyone who's ever appreciated thier youth.

Ferris Bueller's day off is an inspiration to everyone that understands the complexity of high school. Ferris Bueller (Mathew Broderick) is an American Idol to all in this country. Everyone can appreciate the movie magic that is created when he takes of in the red car. The ingenuity of a moving, mechanical sleep dummy gets him started and on the right path to a truly successful day off. The plot is carefully orchestrated with Ferris Bueller (Broderick) as a wise-cracking high school senior from the fictional northern Chicago suburb of Shermer, Illinois (in reality, Lake Forest, Illinois), who decides to skip school (Lake Forest High School) for a day on the town by pretending to be sick. He convinces his nervous friend, Cameron (Ruck) to take his father's carefully restored 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California out for a spin, although Cameron's father has so little trust in him that he has memorized the car's mileage. Ferris makes the promise to erase any miles they put on the car by running the car in reverse when they return. Masquerading as her father, Ferris springs his junior girlfriend Sloane (Sara) from school on the premise that her grandmother has died. this is a truly remarkable film. This movie simply cannot be subjected to being graded by the same criteria as any other movie. It is completely original. To attempt to assess the acting in this movie is just stupid and pretentious. I have yet to see a movie that stands out in my collection (which is considerably large) as does this. Whether you are looking for depth or just comedy, which i think this movie achieves with class. Aimed at a younger generation of the time, it's truly surprising how much credit this movie gives to its audience; the esoteric conversations, the humor-in-dialogue-form, and the lack of crudeness is significantly above meant-for-the-average. This movie delivers any message a viewer may wish to find with class such that the movie/characters establish(es) an almost intimate relationship with the audience which must feel flattered by the highly intelligent work of art this movie is. It's a compliment to its viewer. Nine out of ten.

Review title: One Mans Struggle To Take It Easy
Review_body: In 1985 I saw this film on a plane. An after that it became part of my life. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is not just a film, but its an instruction manual for a teenager to real life, guiding them to become a success. Its true, FBDO is a film that can build confidence, cure depression and make you realize that everyday of your life should be filled with as much fun, learning and excitement as you possibly can, and in many cases not even spend a penny. Successful people in the world are those who are confident, speak clearly and know how to plan and have great time management. Ferris Buellers Day off will be the cheapest MBA you could ever pay for, and perhaps be just as good. Trust me I have one from Oxford. Since 1985, 20 years later, I have seen FBDO 109 times, and know the dialogue by heart and even the entire cast including the extras. And I could put it on right now and watch it again. By 1996, with the scope of the Internet, it was only then I realized that I was not alone. Millions of people where Ferris fans and the film had a strong cult following. A TV serial was made, but without the originals charm, its popularity died. Matthew Broderick played Ferris Bueller as if he was born for the part. His on screen presence portrayed true charisma and charm. Broderick has never played a role more perfect since. 20 years on the film still does not look dated, in spite of DOS operated computers and the use of payphones (no mobiles / cell phones invented then) as John Hughes used classic cars and posh surrounding that fit in well even in the year 2005 and beyond. Save Ferris!!

This movie is one of my favourite ever movies and I still watch it today.
As a character Ferris is amazing and when I first watched this way back when he was 'my hero'.
John Hughes came up with a good few movies but this one is the top for me.

Review title: Imagine Catcher in the Rye if it was from the POV of a teen yuppie
Review_body: After liking''Planes, Trains and Automobiles', and having taken into consideration the cult status this film enjoys i was expecting good things. What i got was an irritating little movie where the central conceit leave a bad taste in the mouth. The films message; Take a break from the mundane-take a 'Day off'-escape the banality of everyday life and find adventure. Whats wrong with that you might say? Well privileged little Ferris Bullers life is anything but mundane. He gets to drive around in a ferarri with a supermodel girlfriend in a world where he never has to take responsibility for his own actions, then sits there earnestly telling us about ''life passing him by?'' I wanted to throw things at the screen. Hughes completely misses the point in the same way Ben Stiller did recently with his awful ''Secret Life of Walter Mitty''; these people seeking something more from life already lead perfect lives so its impossible to to relate to them or understand what they have to feel hard done by about. The film is not really a Bildungsroman, it does not really deal with coming of age; its kind of a bastard relative of the baby boomer movies from the 70s but made for the brat pack generation. We are expected to root for a spoiled overachiever who believes the universe revolves around him and, as others have correctly pointed out, seems to demonstrate sociopathic personality traits. That i can't do. Hated it.

Review title: promotes and extols the virtues of unkindness
Review_body: The movie was excruciatingly painful to watch as the teenagers went out of their way to be unkind and inconsiderate to adults. This is not okay, and it should not be promoted as a desirable way to behave toward others. These are very fine actors in this movie and I seriously doubt they would ever think to behave this way toward others.

Review title: Absolutely favorite movie of all time
Review_body: If you list the greatest movies of all time, Ferris Bueller makes the cut. From the pale lighting in the school to the large grandiose shots of downtown Chicago, This movie has it all. In what could be Matthew Broderick breakout performance, this movie was a portrayal of one man's effort to just take it easy. The lighting in this movie is worth mentioning, when they are in the high school the lighting is very pale and boring. Much like the school they are in, the natural silence in the classroom is what carries over the boredom in your head as well as the character's learning about "voodoo economics". Also one thing to mention is Ferris bueller's foil in the story, Edward Rooney. Ed is a man who takes his job too seriously and his attempt to finally catch ferris in the act of ditching led for some of the film's more funnier moments. One of the thing that really gets to me is the character development of Ferris' friend Cameron. Cam is a very troubled young man who lives in a very troubled household. My favorite part of the movie is him finding himself and his confidence when he destroyed that beautiful Ferrari and said that his dad and him will have a chat when they get home. His self discovery is something a lot of people can relate to. Overall the story of ferris bueller is one about living life to the fullest and not wasting opportunities. As ferris says "life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop to look around every once and awhile, you might miss it." This movie is a classic and one I can watch a million times over. I suggest that if you are fan of comedy and teenage high school films then this movie is the one for you

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of my all time favourite comedies and one of my all time favourite movies over all. John Hughes was a great and underrated comedy writer and director and this is probably his best comedy overall. But I have to admit for "best John Hughes" movie it would be tough to beat "Trains, Planes and Automobiles" which is almost as funny and also incredibly touching, with a couple of John Candy's scenes almost making me cry.In Ferris Bueller the story is a simple one of a brilliant but underachieving student scheming his way out of going to school by convincing his parents and trying to convince his principal that he is sick. A running joke is that the students at the school are incredibly worried about him as if he is at death's door, which really annoys his sister who is stuck going to school and knows that he is completely healthy.He also gets his girlfriend out of school, as well as his hypochondriac friend Cameron who has serious daddy issues which come to a head at the end of the movie. That poor poor car!Super funny and just a fun movie to spend some time on.

A great movie that takes the mirror and points it right back at you. Great movie to not only to put you in a good mood, but a great movie to inspire you to get up and live your life. I'd recommend to anyone dealing with any mental health issues. Though it won't solve your problem, it'll definitely give you the motivation to solve your own problems.

this is the one film that really stands out in my '80s childhood.  in fact, while visiting relatives in milwaukee as a youngin' i pleaded my grandparents to take a train to chicago for a day, which we did.  chicago will forever be associated with this film in my mind.  (yes, i did the sears tower scene.)don't we all want to BE ferris bueller?  well, in less than 2 hours time, that fantasy was fulfilled...  my #1 "feel good" film of all time.

Review title: The BEST cult classic film - EVER!!!!
Review_body: This is the best classic 80's movie out there.  Many great one-liners that will be quoted for eternity!!!  A "must see" no matter what age you are.  Hilarious!!!  John Hughes is the comedy master!!!

Review title: Great movie, too bad they destroyed the car.
Review_body: I must say, this film made me cry more than any other. Oh, come on. You know that when the Ferrari went out the window, you were in tears also. However, it was acted beautifully, and is one of Broderick and Ruck's finest performances.

Review title: The most original and interesting comedy in a long time
Review_body: This was a GREAT movie. I even admit I got into it when Ferris sang "Twist And Shout"...and I will never, never look at the song "Danke Shane" the same way. Ferris reminds me of youth in general with lots of his comments. Listen to what he says in the beginning..that's all classic stuff. 9 outta 10

Review title: it's his fault he didn't lock the garage
Review_body: this is the first non cartoon movie i remember watching as a child. and for some reason my favorite movie EVER. i realize that i am listing a john hughes movie as my favorite, but still it's a really fun movie. the soundtrack is fun, matthew broderick is fun, the fact that this movie includes an early drummer from sonic youth is fun, alan rucks creepily blue eyes are fun. don't take it too seriously of course though if you can have this much fun skipping in one day (it's  a stretch but i think i've come close) you've got it made.

Ferris Bueller is one of those characters who you can instantly relate to. The guy is a genius and we would all love to be able to do what he did and does throughout this simply sensational film!My favourite part has to be the teacher (who is similar to one we have all been taught by) calling out "Buelleur, Bueller, Beuullleeerrr...."A fantastic film which I have watched over and over again and will continue to do so again and again!!

Review title: A film everyone who was young once needs to see
Review_body: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is how everyone wishes their High School Days were. The sun always shone, the girls were pretty and you always had one over the teachers. A plot line which under close examination could be considered far fetched is always believable, possibly because we wanted it to be true. The first time I saw this film I couldn't stop laughing, the same applies for the second and third and so on. This film like Stand By Me makes me yearn for the chance to go back so I could live my teenage years as they should have been.

Review title: No other movie embodies the 80's like this one.
Review_body: If I were to pick ONE  movie that embodied the 80's, it would be "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".  Ferris' asides to the camera add to his charm and wit, the soundtrack is right on key, the casting dead on, and the entire movie flows with the pace of someone who got up 1/2 hour late for school in the morning.  Ferris' ability to get away with it all is kept very much alive throughout the film.John Hughes has crafted a delightful film that's funny all over, touching where it needs to be, and has the many signature elements that Hughes films are known for (the impending doom at the front door, teen angst, a number of great cameos, but, alas, no Molly Ringwald).  This film also gave us a number of the sound bytes that you hear so often today (Ben Stein's "Bueller...Bueller" and the spoken-in-one-breath update on Ferris' condition by then not-quite-known Kristy Swanson).This film is Hughes at his best, and Broderick in probably his biggest, best role (or at least his most memorable).  How they could try to follow this with a sitcom was beyond me.  This is definitely not a movie that could be sequelized - Let this one stand alone.  It's fine the way it is.  If it ain't broke, don't fix it.
An incredibly boring film. Literally nothing happens, very weak limited story. Don't get why this is considered a classic

I have seen many, many films in my time but this has to be my Very Fav. film of all time.This is a must film to watch for the hole family, I have seen it hundreds of times myself and also all my kids love it and they are 6 years old and under.The film is all about a boy, Ferris, who decides to "bunk off" school and have some fun by "borrowing" his best friends dad's car and having a lot of fun with his best friend and his girlfriend around town and other place's. He nearly get's caught "bunking off" school but somehow always manages to get away with it. I could say a lot more about this great film, but I don't want to spoil it for everyone else that has not yet been lucky enough to see this great film, but once you have seen it you won't forget it.
Just watch the movie please it's amazing.Its extremely funny, self aware and has really good likeable characters.

An absolutely enjoyable movie. no unnecessary characters that add nothing to the story, very clear plot, makes you rethink the way you live your lifeps: i wish it was a bit longer so that we could at least witness the cameron confronting his dad.

Review title: Don't let school get in the way of your education!!!!
Review_body:
This is a great, great film. Most everyone who grew up in the 80's remembers it as a teenage comedy classic. However it is more than that. It is a tribute to Mark Twain's quote, "Don't schooling get in the way of your education." Ferris and his friends experience food, sports, architecture, art, music and life in their "day off" and they learned more that day than anything they could have learned in a month at school. I try to show this to my kids every year as reminder of this. Well its my daughter Bryn's 14th birthday and every year I run a scavenger hunt for her. Well, I can't be with her because of the quarantine, so I am running a virtual scavenger hunt. Happy Birthday Bryn. I love you. And I miss you!!!! Here is your next clue.A shallow pool game we played oh, so long ago
You had me to sneak by, going fast or slow
But then I would shout at the top of my voice
My method to stop you, to prevent your rejoice.This is your last clue so you're now on your own
Yes, I am serious there is no need to moan
As long as the phrase is entered exactly right
You will be lead to the correct site.

Review title: What a great Film, sums up youth culture perfecctly
Review_body: I love this film I remember when I was about 8 and the film had just been released onto sattelite tv. I watched it and it instantly became one of my fave films of all time. The spin off tv series sucked and noone can play ferris like Matthew Broderick, I hope to see the spin off Ferris Bueller is Dead soon

Every once in a while we all need a day off...sometimes even nine.  But the movie is an excellent review of how this classic teen chose to spend his day.  Everyone can learn a good lesson from it, I think!  Anyway not every movie needs a lesson behind it, just cut lose and make the most of it, and try not to miss too much of it!

This is by far one of the best movies, if you haven't seen I highly recommend it!  I'd give it a 10 of 10 *'s!  Mathew Broderick and Alan Ruck make an awesome team!  And Mr. Rooney...typical geek principal, with one hilarious secretary!  Even if you've already seen it, why aren't you watching it again now?????? SAVE FERRIS!

A must have for any DVD collection! It's great stuff and a lot more fun than nowadays 'comedys'My personal experience with Ferris Bueller: about 20 years ago, I used to be like 10 years old, my brother had a copy on VHS. I must've watched it between 15 to 20 times and never got bored with it.On the forum I see suggestions for a remake, but this movie doesn't need a remake. The original still stands tough as a rock. My favourite moment: when Ferris'sister and mr. Rooney meet in the house. This had had me rolling over the floor. Go look on the internet for a copy. If you're unfamilliar with it, look up a preview on the tube or something.

Review title: Get a Life,go take a DAY-OFF
Review_body: I went about watching this flick after a lot of persuasion from one of my friends,and boy,did I enjoy it! I generally don't write Comments and just rate them,but for this flick,well it was different.This movie isn't your run of the mill teenage comedy stuff like the American Pie series, but actually makes you believe that this genre can also be entertaining without the raunchy humor that typifies such flicks.Ferris is the kind of person that makes it impossible for you not to desire to be his friend. He's fun to hang out with,he can make you get rid of your problems,and if not,take the blame on his shoulder,just as Cameron discovers. If you had a friend like Ferris during your high school years, you should definitely consider yourself very fortunate.Ferris,in his fun trip around Chicago,takes his girlfriend and best friend along and tries to make it special for Cameron,who leads a very mundane life. He tries to relieve him of his fears and as we see towards the end,Cameron learns to stand up for himself.A thoroughly enjoyable movie,and a must see when you get your day off.My Rating, 4 n a 1/2 out of 5.
Just perfect in every way possible in the way of acting, directing, writing and comedy.

This movie simply cannot be subjected to being graded by the same criteria as any other movie. It is completely original. To attempt to assess the acting in this movie is just stupid and pretentious. I have yet to see a movie that stands out in my collection (which is considerably large) as does this. Whether you are looking for depth or just comedy, which i think this movie achieves with class. Aimed at a younger generation of the time, it's truly surprising how much credit this movie gives to its audience; the esoteric conversations, the humor-in-dialogue-form, and the lack of crudeness is significantly above meant-for-the-average. This movie delivers any message a viewer may wish to find with class such that the movie/characters establish(es) an almost intimate relationship with the audience which must feel flattered by the highly intelligent work of art this movie is. It's a compliment to its viewer. Ten out of ten.

Not exactly the greatest movie ever made and not the funniest movie ever made. Those would be the Godfather and Airplane!, respectively. It's just a feel good movie about a likeable and heroic kid. I know most of this movie by heart and have made some of my friends fans. One of the best things to come out of the 80s and an indespensible(?) classic.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of my all time favorites. It is an Excellent movie about seeing your own personal value and realizing your potential. I think a little bit of every character lives inside us and it is that constant struggle that makes this life fun. At times we are much like Cameron; conservative, unhappy, and insecure. Other times we are like Ferris; uninhibited, fun-loving, and relaxed. We all need to realize that we control our lives and determine our future. I think Cameron put it best when he said, "I am not going to sit on my ass as the events that affect me unfold to determine the course of my life. I'm going to take a stand. I'm going to defend it. Right or wrong, I'm going to defend it." We should all strive to be memorable in this life, to take some advice from Ferris. "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it."I think John Hughes knew what he was doing when he made this movie and I'm grateful to him for it.I give it a 10 out of 10

I've watched this movie countless times and find it greatly entertaining every time, many of the scenes are real classics.  One of my favourite comedies of all time in fact.  But has anyone picked up one flaw - surely if Ferris and his father's group were leaving the restaurant at the same time, they would have seen each other while eating in the restaurant?  (any comments on this?)Generally a very well put together movie with some truly comic moments and good acting (especially from some of the supporting actors such as Edie McClurg as the school secretary, Del Close as the English teacher and Jonathan Schmock as the maitre'd)Has appeal for all ages, not only teens! Since the movie is a comedy, it's possible to overlook certain small flaws in the timing / storyline that may seem unlikely.The movie is now 16 years old and destined to be one of those timeless classics of the 80's.

I enjoyed this film as a young kid and still enjoy this film.  Matthew Broderick did an excellent job in this film. Very funny movie. I especially like the actions of Ferris.  My favorite part of this movie was the prank phone call to the restraunt.  10 out of 10!

Of all movies made by John Hughes, many are well done.  This is the best one, and i live my life by this movie. If this movie isn't your type of humor, at least you have to appreciate the innocence of its idea, that life should be taken the way you wish to.  The philosophy built by this character is that of the greats, like Locke..well not quite..I just wish there was more dialogue of just Ferris on his views on life.  Great fun, best movie.

Review title: Age is just a number-not a limit to the imagination!
Review_body: Such a feel good film! This masterpiece is absolutely brilliant! It encapsulates perfectly the feelings of thousands of teens who can only dream of ditching a whole day of school-simply because they don't 'feel' like learning today...I definitely know how it feels: you've had to get up at some silly time in the morning just to attend registration, (*cough* scare small children as you look like a Shaun of the dead extra *cough*); you end up sitting next to some poor child who has an unfortunate bodily odour beast of a problem, and the plan of attempting suicide with a ruler or launching yourself out the window gradually becomes more appealing when your teacher is about as exciting as a pile of mud. Ferris Bueller is a role model to those who's only wish is to live on the edge and take every opportunity that is thrown your way! Everyone should act like Ferris Bueller in some way or another-just to make life that bit more interesting. This film has made me promise myself that I will NEVER become a boring adult with a monotone voice, and that, no matter how old I am, if there's a chance for me to sing whilst on a parade float, I will definitely take that chance! :D

Review title: The movie was not only unrealistic but had a bad message I feel
Review_body: I did not enjoy the movie at all. There's nothing in this film that is worth appreciation. I have been teen once upon a time but I feel I surely would not have liked it even then. The teen in this movie seems to get away with anything and everything bad and the grown ups are shown as a bunch of idiots who can never catch him. His parents don't even get a hint of what he is up to!! The movie is a dark spot for parental/kids relationship. I feel sorry for those who liked such a movie but I would never want my kids to see such a movie. I did not like anybody's acting either! If there was a lower rating than one (1) star for this I would have definitely gone for that.

Review title: Best movie I've seen this year
Review_body: Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) just can't take it and needs a ninth day off from school--so after tricking his parents into thinking he was sick, forcing help from his hypochondriac best friend, Cameron (Alan Ruck), and sneaking his girlfriend (Mia Sara) out of school, Ferris is ready to wreak havoc in Chicago. But, of course, it's all fun and games until someone puts a Ferrari in danger.I'm from the generation of High School Musical and Hannah Montana, so seeing a movie with this kind of quality was a big surprise. My friend made me watch it with her, but I ended up being the one who forced her to wait and watch the end because I loved it so much. It has real, good, clean comedy that doesn't need to use dirty or offensive jokes to make people laugh. This is real entertainment.

I cannot explain to you how great this movie is. It is my favorite movie of all time, I watched it when I was 3, and it has been my favorite movie since. I plan to show it to my son as soon as possible, so I can share the joy. Ferris Bueller reminds me of my brother when we were kids, running around, ditching school. This was the first, and best movie I have ever seen. I would recommend this to EVERYONE. It is hilarious. The part where he was in the parade cracked me up, especially Twist and Shout, aka the #1 Beatles song. Obviously John Hughes (the director and co-producer) think alike. All I can say is that this movie is the single greatest movie I have ever watched and probably will be forever.

Broderick banked off that boyish charm that made him so popular on the Broadway stage (Brighton Beach Memoirs) and brought it to this witty laugh ride about a high schooler who one day, just didn't want to go to school and puts himself and his friends in constant mayhem and jeopardy. Broderick is perfect, but it is Jeffrey Jones who gives a searing comic potryal of Ed Rooney, a Mr. Weatherbee-like principal wanting to catch Ferris in only act of treachery; holding him back for one more year of high school. John Hughes is at his best here. The dialogue for this film has received such a following that it has even been printed on shirts and recited at parties by true fans of the film. I don't blame them. It's a classic!

Ferris Bueller was either loved or hated by his peers for always getting away with anything he'd do. Some would want him expelled, others want him for Class President. On this extremely eventful day, the audience is invited to follow Ferris, his best pal and his girlfriend from morning to afternoon (when they all should have been in school), enjoying a holiday declared by the resourceful Ferris Bueller.They get to speed on the freeway in a Ferrari, sing "Danke Schoen" on an Octoberfest Float, eat at the most exclusive restaurant in town and always keep just one step ahead of a furious principal in hot pursuit. With fake computer grade and attendance records, Ferris has it made.The scene where the principal hitches a ride on a school bus after having been "torn up" by Doberman watch dogs is worth the ticket price (Oh Yeah!). This is one of the funniest "high school prankster movies" ever! Has it been 20 years already? This is a definite Cult Classic! Right up there with Animal House and Caddy Shack.

Having watched the recent Honda commercial send-up of Matthew Broderick, I watched this movie again.This will always be a great teen coming of age movie, or at least a movie for people under the age of 30 who were recently in high school. It's premise is based on the human urge to go against the system and buck the rules and just have a good time. Practically every kid that feels stuck in the walls of an institution such as high school is going to get these urges, and for all of those kids, Ferris Bueller is their hero.Matthew Broderick brings a warm, innocent charm to the title role as a young man who has luck on his side. Everything goes his way, from worming his best friend (Alan Ruck) into taking his father's rare Ferrari, to warding off the high school principal (Jeffrey Jones) to getting his girlfriend (Mia Sara) out of school as well.Writer/director John Hughes takes his love for teenagers and school situations and gives us a story that deals with life outside school and the freedoms and privileges of being a kid. What Ferris does is, as they say, getting away with murder, but it is such a joy to watch him get into predicaments and wonder how can he possibly get out of this one. Broderick is a delight, as are the supporting cast, especially Jennifer Grey as his envious sister. This movie is about luck and what that power can do for you. It is also about enjoying life and the power that can do. It is the ultimate skipping school movie and is one of Hughes' best efforts as a writer and director. See it for the story, the funnies or the plain joy of skipping school and catching a glimpse of life as it was back then.

Review_body: the movie does gave me a genuine laugh in couple of scenes but all those was involved the Character "Ed.Rooney" played by Jeffrey Jones , i also liked the appearance of Charlie Sheen it does added some aroma.i was OK with the movie even when it does displayed every cast as dump as possible excluding Ferris of course , but the real issue i have that this movie tries to leave a message of liberation for teenagers and look at Ferris as perfect example and all what he does is cool and even right, it was obvious?! , i mean literary Farris's actions was lie and conjob , i just don't want to clarify to avoid any spoilers. even when i least recommend this movie.

"Ferris Bueller's Day Off" was one of the greatest comedies from the 80's. It still holds up great to this day. The comedy was great, I love all the characters and they are all relate-able (the guy who gets off scott free, the neurotic, the asshole teacher, etc.), and this is the third Matthew Broderick film that I enjoyed him in (The Lion King & Bee Movie are the other two)! But I think the teachers were too mean spirited and there were some parts in the movie that could have been cut out. For what it is though, it was a great film. If you happen to find a copy of "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," pick it up and give it a try.Also Ben Steins sandpaper emotions are funnier here than they were in Casper and Son of the Mask.

Review title: This will be one of your favourite films, plain & simple!!
Review_body: From start to finish this film was utterly amazing. There may not be lots of action, but contrary to belief a great film does not need to be full of action. The simplicity of this film is it's genius, Ferris is a rule breaker. But he is certainly a very likeable character & along with the growth of his best friend during the film Cameron. The relationship between these characters & the constant chase from the head teacher Rooney, give this film a real depth. I can guarantee this film will bring a smile to anyone's face. No matter what mood you may be in, this is a film that will always lighten your mood. It is one of those films that everyone needs to make sure they see at least once in there life.
Must see if you're born in the 90s & 2000s. Most movies from the 80s lose their appeal as we age. This one has held its entertainment value through the years. Best movie of the 80s.

Review title: highly entertaining film, definitely one of the greatest teen films ever made
Review_body: Ferris Buellers' Day Off follows three adolescent teens who decide to take the day off school. Ferris Bueller, the executor of the plan, decides to fake an illness in order to trick his parents into taking the day off. Ferris convinces his sick friend, Cameron to also take the day off and bring his fathers Ferrari. As soon as the two unite they form a plan to bail Ferris' girlfriend Sloane out of school. The principal, Ed Rooney, is aware of Ferris' rebellious manner and is hot on Ferris' tail to expose him for wagging school. Fortunately Ferris is always a step ahead of Rooney as he gallivants around the city. Ferris' sister Jeanie, jealous that Ferris is able to get away with ditching school on a regular basis, decides to catch Ferris in the act when she finds out the entire school thinks Ferris has come down with a serious illness. Ferris and his friends throughout the day manage to dine at a prestigious restaurant, attend an art gallery, view a baseball match, and sing at a street parade and other escapades in which he almost encounters his father. Cameron, Ferris' friend, is a neurotic individual who is eventually set over the top after the miles on his fathers Ferrari are raised significantly by the hoodlums in charge of taking care of it throughout the day. Eventually he is set into a catatonic state of mind before the entire car is destroyed set off by his mental angst. Cameron learns a valuable lesson in life following these incidents. Following the days events, it's eventually time to head home. Ferris' sister Jeanie learns not to stick her nose where it doesn't belong and Ed Rooney is in the end outsmarted by Ferris and Jeanie. Ferris achieves his goal of having an enjoyable and fulfilling day. Many genres of music are featured in the film, notable songs are Twist and Shout by The Beatles (lip synched by Ferris at the parade), Oh Yeah by Yellow which is played throughout the film, Star Wars is parodied with the main theme song when the men in charge of the Ferrari accelerate it into the air.Interesting camera shots include: a long shot of Ferris on the top of the float singing at the parade, a mid shot approximately 24 minutes into the film of Ferris and Cameron's feet right before they gaze upon the Ferrari, mid shots of the dull looks on the children's faces in school at the beginning of the film. Hughes took his time when editing. Edited scenes such as Jeanie triple kicking Rooney came out nicely. There is also another scene where Ferris has disguised himself and he kisses Sloane while Rooney is watching. The kiss was in fact brief and because of the editing which switches back to shots of Rooney and the kiss, it is made to appear longer then it is. Other interesting production elements are the fake 1960 Ferrari which in actual fact was worth $350,000 at the time. Insurance for the car to stand still most of the time on a movie set would cost a fortune. Instead they had three cars with fiberglass bodies using the framework of a mustang. One for the stunt was a higher powered vehicle, one which was driven by Ferris and his friends, and one which was just a shell to be driven through the window towards the end of the film. Acting is the film is outstanding at times the characters express more through actions and expressions rather than dialogue. Alan Ruck is able to project his voice in an amusing manner for one particular prank call scene which is exceptional, Mathew Broderick is fantastic in his portrayal of a confident and charismatic young teen and Mia Sara is also strong on performance. Jeffery Jones plays a convincing principal who seems to be more of a villain. Jennifer Grey accurately portrays the jealous and spiteful sister. Overall the acting is excellent and the supporting casts are great. Charlie Sheen's brief cameo appearance as a drug addict is even brilliant.My favorite part of the film would have to be where Ferris takes Sloane and Cameron to the street parade and jumps on board the float and dedicates a lip synched solo to Cameron: "a young boy who thinks he hasn't seen anything good today". Ferris gets everybody dancing in a lively performance of Twist and Shout by the Beatles, with the band. This is my favorite scene because it's quite entertaining and shows just how much Ferris is able to influence those around him. There is a choreographed scene of the crowd dancing which is also quite good. My overall opinion of the film is that it is a highly entertaining film and definitely one of the greatest teen films ever made. Overall the scenes are well put together showing us what one can accomplish in one day with the right mind. The humor in the film works on a scale of different ages which makes this one suitable for the entire family. The acting and shots are definitely strong aspects making the film a highly enjoyable one. I give this film four stars and highly recommend it to anyone who wishes to get into films of the teen genre.

I believe this movie to be very entertaining and for pure enjoyment.The thrill of escaping your regular boring high-school and venturing off into the busy streets of downtown Chicago compiles together one hilarious film. Meanwhile, Ferris and his gang try to do everything there is to do in Chicago while evading the constant interruptions of his annoying principal who tries to catch Ferris skipping school. The movie also consists of well done chemistry between Ferris and his girlfriend Sloan. Tagging along with the two is Ferris's best friend, Cameron. Despite Cameron's constant worrying of being caught, the gang lets loose in 2 extremely entertaining hours. It isn't an Oscar winner by any means however it was made to be a box-office hit, not a drama. In all, it is an extremely entertaining, funny, and enjoyable film (directed towards ages 11-25).

What a self-indulgent piece of crap. Yes, it has its humorous parts. Most not to do with Broderick.Here is a guy who killed two people in a road accident in Ireland (Northern Ireland), got off lightly, offers no recompense to the two victims' families, because he is Hollywood, that means spoiled and he offers no remorse, but just "does not remember what happened", sort of like the BS that Ferris thinks he can get away with. Spoiled little Hollywood brat who destroyed a family and offered no remorse on his part. Do you really like this guy?

Review title: On the face of it, a hilarious comedy but something deeper is what makes this a classic
Review_body: While there are many hilarious scenes within this film such as prank calling the head of the school, singing in a chicago parade or the constant references to ferris dying and the entire city rooting for him, the real stand out factor of this film is the relationship between the main trio and what it presents.Cameroon fry is a depressed high school kid who's father neglects him compared to a car. He is not interested in anything and doesn't believe he is capable of anything. Compared to this, Ferris Bueller is the kid that always gets everything right and to people like Cameroon, it seems they can never get anything wrong. While we may not all have faced neglect by our parents, at some point we can all say that we related to Cameroon feeling down and out with no prospects and wanted to be like Ferris, the guy with the gorgeous girlfriend, supporting and loving parents and loads of popularity and confidence.Whats so great about the chemistry between the trio, apart from the great acting by all three actors, is that Sloane and Ferris are not arrogant in their popularity. They have a loyal and loving relationship together and are supportive and caring for Cameroon even in his strangest or lowest moments (the pool scene). Their main concern towards the last 20 minutes of the film is about Cameroon and if he's truly going to be ok without them.The triumphant ending for all three is a great one and the museam scene is absolutely iconic.
I know I could look back at this movie and find plenty wrong with it, but for what it is, it's pretty good. An essential 80's film.

Ferris Bueller's Day off is by far the greatest movie of all time. I loved watching it as a teen and I love watching it as an adult. Every time I watch the movie my wife has to make sure that I stay at work the next day (ha,ha).From time to time i find myself quoting Buellerisms such as, "You killed the car" , "Where's your brain?" , "I did not achieve this position in life by having some snot-nosed punk leave my cheese out in the wind." and my all time favorite "You guys got nothing to worry about, I'm a professional." All I can say is thanks to this movie I was able to stop and look around once in a while and not get caught doing it.

Am I the only woman out there who thinks that Ferris is the hottest guy EVER? Well, maybe I'm a little biased because I grew up in the Chicago area where the movie was filmed. Most of the scenes in the movie were shot in Winnetka and Northbrook and as you can tell those towns are absolutely beautiful. I unfortunately grew up in a neighboring town called Evanston and often longed of going to the famous New Trier HS in Winnetka and living the life of Ferris' girl friend Sloan. You see my Ferris, we'll call him Mr. E to protect the innocent grew up in the area and went to New Trier. He was so cute and was totally like Ferris. I used to sit in class and write his name over and over in my notes, Emma + Erik, oops I let it slip. Oh well, I can't help it, he's just so dreamy!! As Cameron famously says after Ferris saves him from the pool "Ferris Bueller, you're my hero" Erik ....., is my hero. I often used to drive by his parents house and pretended that I was going to meet him for a date, then it was back to boring old Evanston. He talked to me once, and said "can I have some napkins" when he was ordering some food at this restaurant Buffalo Joe's in my town where I used to work. I touched his hand, it was the greatest day of my life. Unfortunately I'm a plump old housewife now living on the west coast, but at least I always have this movie to remind me of the good old days. Oh did I mention, Erik, I mean Ferris, is totally hot. So, like yeah see the movie. It is way rad!!
Looking back at high school, I see how pointless and what a joke it was.  I just wish I had used Ferris' attitude when the time was right...

Review title: When teen movies were funny, not just stupid
Review_body: I have an ongoing discussion with my friends and family about what movie defines your generation, and for me, this is it!  Ferris' commentary throughout the movie is hilarious and irreverent, giving a voice to those on the borderline between Generations X and Y.  It's Office Space, the teenage years!  This movie is witty and fast-paced, not relying on the bathroom humor and physical comedy that most teenage and college comedies do these days.  Yes it is dated, but that's part of what makes it great.  I love it!

Watchable and infinitely re-watchable. Loved it when it first came out nearly (gulp) 20 years ago and whenever airing on television (unexpurgated version, please). Great journey into the day of the life of a high school anti-hero and his escapades throughout Chicago. Entire cast shines (especially Broderick, Jeffrey Jones--as his belabored principal, Jennifer Grey as Ferris' hissy-fit sister, the pencil-headed Edie McClurg, and Charlie Sheen as a young hoodlum). John Hughes' best film, hands down. One of the best comedies of the 1980s and still fresh as ever. A great DVD rental, too, particularly when double-billed with ELECTION, Alexander Payne's dark comedy in which Broderick, now cast as a high school teacher, meets his match with a conniving student--a much darker Ferris.

I loved this movie, of course.  Hilarious.  But has anyone else noticed how Cameron Frye(Alan Ruck) is the only character who undergoes any change in character of any sort?  Without him, the film would consist of one really clever guy to be jealous of, and that's it.  We can relate to Cameron(him and that girl in the Seurat painting).  We understand his pain.  Let's face it: we love him.  He makes the movie what it is.  Way to go, Cameron!

Review title: The feel-good film of all time
Review_body: Ferris is my hero.  He lives life the way it should be lived, and the world is a better place for it.  Occasionally profound, always likeable and funny, this is a film that everyone should see.  Especially on a wet Wednesday afternoon, because it will cheer you up - guaranteed.The performances by the lead actors are superb, and Broderick gives his lifetime best portrayal.  The direction is spot on, although quintessentially a Hughes 1980s film.  The editing is also good, as short set piece scenes give the film an upbeat  rhythm.A friend of mine compared this film to Wayne's World.  But Ferris' talks to camera are infinitely more assured than Wayne, and Cameron is a believable character.  Minor criticisms are the overdose of slapstick and the fact that the day seems to last for ever.  But we want it to last forever.Make everyone you know see this film.

Review_body: This movie is a modern day classic. My childhood, and the 80's, would not have been the same without it. I never get sick of watching this movie. We all wish we could pack as much into one day as Ferris, Cameron and Sloane do. I love Ferris - we all love Ferris - save Ferris!

Review title: A teenage feel-good movie that could've held more
Review_body: "Ferris Bueller's day off" is an overall feel-good feature film that easily relates and reaches the teenage audience. It's capable of brightening anyone's day, but struggles to keep the viewers attention throughout the entirety of the film.The overarching plot line is about a high school senior, played by Matthew Broderick, who decides to fake an illness and skip school when he hears about the very promising weather forecast. He then lures his reluctant best friends, Cameron (Alan Ruck), and his very willing girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara), into his fun-filled day off from school, all while he's trying to avoid being caught by, his parents, his sister, and the principal all at the same time.Matthew Broderick has to play Hughes' attempt at what an essential teen, might be, hoping to create the perfect teen movie, after not quite getting there from "The Breakfast Club" or "Sixteen Candles". Yet, Broderick does quite a good job depicting a feel good teen who isn't caring about the past or the future. This directly appeals to teens because most of them can relate to the theme of not knowing about the future, and essentially not caring.Where the film lacks is in the plot line, catching the audience's attention on this fun ride through Chicago narrowly avoiding trouble. After less than an hour though, not much really changes and it can get repetitive, failing to keep the viewers attention through the whole movie. It lacks movement as pretty much the same things are repeating without much intensity growing throughout. Just about the only thing attempting at keeping the intensity up is the music, which hosts some feel good, and upbeat songs.The most important theme in the movie is actually quite striking, that being Cameron's abusive relationship with his father. While his father is never seen in the movie, he is represented through his expensive car that he owns. It's a good theme a good amount of the audience can actually relate to. We can see this specific theme portrayed in one of the scenes where Cameron is fixated on an oil painting in a museum specifically looking at a kid in the painting. Cameron seemingly learns more from this experience than he ever did in school, and we can see him change in his thoughts and behavior after this scene. Another important key theme is the fear of what's next. It's shared between all three teen characters in the movie that they don't know what's next in their life, where Ferris fears what's going to happen when he's goes off to college, and Cameron claiming he's not interested in anything. This key theme is about the most relatable to teenage viewers and is what allows them to grip on to the movie."Ferris Bueller's day off" is a feel good movie depicting teens that just want to have fun without a care in the world, yet it struggles to grip the attention of most viewers, really only relating to teens with a few important key themes. Overall, it is a fun watch that won't necessarily strike as an important movie that must be seen.

I'm sure by now you've heard of this wildly popular John Hughes film. Yeah, you know the one. The one with the teenagers who do a bunch of funny teenager things that every other teen wishes they were doing. Oh, you don't know the one I'm talking about? That's because he's made movies with this plot more times than teenage-you actually did any of these things. But guess what? He did it again with Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986).
I've seen many a teen movie in my lifetime, so by now I've seen plenty of these plot-lines belly flop harder than my chubby Mexican cousin. This time around it's Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick), the popular class clown type, and his partners in crime. He easily gets his girlfriend, Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara), to go along with his latest scheme, but his best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) is a different story. He is informed by Ferris that they will be taking his father's prized possession: a 1961 Ferrari 250 GT. Ferris easily convinced his clueless parents he was on the brink of death to stay home "sick" from school, but not his younger sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey). Along with her being out to get him, Principal Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is also on his tail, fed up with his antics. Headed to downtown Chicago for the day, what could possibly go wrong?
Any movie aimed at a younger audience needs that one special ingredient to keep their attention, or they will undoubtedly lose interest. You know what I'm talking about, right? Ok, say it with me now: comedy! This film is chock full of one-liners, sarcasm, and witty remarks. There is no way anyone could watch it without laughing at least once. At times the delivery is a bit much, (*cough cough* Principal Rooney -a grown man- growling many times throughout the movie), but in general the script does a good job of keeping the audience entertained.
One of the most memorable features of the movie is the setting. The film is set in Chicago, and it was actually mostly shot there. Their whole adventure through Chicago was all shot in Chicago, at such famous locations like Wrigley Field, the Art Institute of Chicago, and Willis Tower. Seeing that the setting in the film is true to the shooting location is refreshing to see and gives viewers a sense of authenticity.
Adding to authenticity, the acting was all there. Not counting how Cameron started out very sick and somehow just... magically got better? The interactions between the characters were extremely convincing. If I were to ever meet Matthew Broderick in person, I would expect him to be the eccentric extrovert I saw in the film. And Jennifer Grey? She would roll her eyes and walk away. Even though at the time of filming, none of these "high school students" were really in high school, they managed to make it feel like we were ditching school right along with them.
All in all, I did truly enjoy this movie. It didn't feel like just another one of those cheesy teen movies that keep getting pushed out to make money. Compared to other movies John Hughes has done, like Sixteen Candles, this appeals to a much wider audience and was overall more impactful. I recommend this movie to anyone for a good time. Even if it's not your type you might as well watch it because after all, "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it".

This movie is a true classic. I believe it withstands the test of time. Remember when all you wanted was a day off from school? I sat down with my 15-year-old son and it was incredible watching his reactions to the movie. Except for the outdated technology in the film, it's all the same things kids are still trying to get away with today and still wish they could pull off. This movie takes you back to relive those days of carefree fun. Kids growing up in any time period can relate to this. I recommend any parent to be present the first time your kids watches this. Sit back and watch as they enjoy the same scenes you enjoyed at that age.

Definitely one of the funniest films i have ever seen, i would highly recommend this to anyone with a sense of humor. Everyone wishes they had behaved like this at school, it would have made life much more interesting!

Review title: The greatest movie to ever be created by humankind.
Review_body: This movie, in many ways, has shaped my life.I can't watch this movie enough times. Ever since I was a young boy I would watch it over and again. Even now I will watch it and laugh out loud. It never gets old. I could probably quote this movie verbatim.The main thing that I have gleaned from this amazing film is that no matter what is happening around you, you control the outcome of your actions. You determine whether or not life is wonderful. That is something Cameron had to learn the hard way.FBDO has also taught me that if you set your mind to something then you will live in your own mind set. Ferris was not only an optimist, but he also took steps to live out his dreams. It did not matter how impossible these steps seemed to be, he still executed every step until his dreams were in the now.Cameron, on the other hand, did the same thing but moving in the opposite direction. He also was living his mind set but was not happy with his life. Cameron had to be shown how to change his thinking in order to live without fear. Ferris in many ways represents a savior while Cameron represents the saved.

Review title: My favourite movie of all times
Review_body: This is not a sophisticated movie, it's light at first glance but contains a few nuggets of wisdom. The characters are endearing: the bitter sister, the foolish school principal, the uptight teenager filled with angst, etc.I love Ferris, he's fun and wacky. He knows how to take risks to enjoy life, some would say too much risk, at the expense of his friend. But he knows how to a day off to appreciate life.I own very few movies. But I have this one on an old VHS tape. When I feel blue about life, I plug it in and remember to "stop and look around". That is what I take from this movie. A philosophy. "Ferris Bueller, you're my hero!"

Review title: A MUST SEE!!!! Classic 80's "feel good" movie!!!
Review_body: If they could only make more movies like this.  The plot is simple as it is about what happens when the slick "know-it-all" high school senior takes a day off school to hang with his best friend and girlfriend.  My only criticism of the movie was the way the characters had to analyze themselves ( a John Hughes staple ala "Breakfast Club", "Sixteen Candles", "Weird Science") and look deep within themselves to come to some sort of realization about who they really are. The few moments this happens you stop laughing, though only for a minute.There is no doubt that the casting for this movie was outstanding.  The secretary and Ed Rooney are absolutely hilarious.  The mother, father, and sister "Jeannie/Shawna" were great selections.  Cameron plays the cynical/pessimistic best friend part beautifully, and what is not to like about Mia Sara.This is nothing but a good, funny movie that you don't need to think about, just sit back and enjoy.

Review title: A man who hasn't seen ferris bueller is not a man, merely a boy with hair on his face!
Review_body: This film is sheer genius. It's one of those films like High Fedelity or the Breakfast Club; they seem to have a plot that can only go so far and then get boring. Somehow they all end up being the most amazing films i have ever, or will ever see.The plot of 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off' is simple, our young Ferris decides to take a day off school...From this simple start ferris shows his friends one of the most memorable days they will have for a long time. Whilst dodging detection from his parents and his jealous sister Jeanie, whom you may remember from 'Dirty Dancing' (he said with a pained smile on his face) Ferris tries to show his girlfriend Slone (huba huba) and best friend Cameron all that the city has to offer.Amidst all this confusion one man makes it his personal mission to catch Ferris and bring him to justice...Ed Runey, the dean. And throughout the film you will want him to fail at every turn.Two things make this film so great, one, the best 80's soundtracks on the planet, and two being the way Ferris talks to the camera. You may be familiar with this technique being used in the popular hit TV series 'Saved by the Bell' and if it worked for them i can tell you it worked for Ferris. Big time =]

I don't believe many perfect movies have ever been made but this is surely one. Bueller... has barely dated since it's release which, for a film about young people and city/suburban life, is an astonishing achievement. What it has in spades is sincerity and authenticity - qualities that set many of John Hughes' movies apart - combined with a ripping script. What I like most about this movie is that it is entirely devoid of sex and violence and can be enjoyed by "everyone in the family" (not that I don't enjoy sex and violence in movies but many of the best movies - Casino being a case in point - are not really suitable in the same way). I would honestly recommend this move to absolutely anyone.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a worthwhile movie. High school senior Ferris Bueller (Matthew Roderick) brings his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) and his girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) on a trip around Chicago when they're supposed to be in school.My main problem with that movie is the title character, Ferris. He is super popular for some reason, but he doesn't seem to care about how what he does affects other people. However, you just can't help but like him more and more as the movie progresses, probably because of Roderick's acting.What saved this movie for me was Alan Ruck as Cameron. He did a terrific job, and I never would've guessed that he was in his late 20's. I just love the way Cameron and Sloane get along; while Ferris is off singing on a parade float, they are content to stand there chatting without seeming awkward at all.This might not be the best movie in the world, but it is still quality entertainment and in my top 20 favorite movies. Just rent it and see what you think.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off Movie Review"Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it." Though life may move pretty fast, Director John Hughes's Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one film you don't want to miss. Though this film is nearly 25 years old, it is considered to be a classic amongst teens and enthusiasts of 1980's culture everywhere. A well-developed story, believable acting, and the unique directing insight of John Hughes make this film worthy of a Golden Globe nomination, and a must see for anyone looking for an entertaining blast to the past. The premise of Ferris Bueller's Day Off is simple but something everyone can relate to. Ferris Bueller, played by Matthew Broderick, (War Games, The Producers) is an 18-year old High School Senior just weeks from graduating who fakes sick to enjoy one of his last days of spring with his best friend, Cameron (Alan Ruck, Spin City) and his girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara, Birds of Prey) to explore the metropolis of Chicago, IL. Ferris and his friends take a grand tour of Chicago in Cameron's father's extremely rare vintage Ferrari sports car, making appearances at Wrigley Field, The Art Institute of Chicago, and the Sears Tower. While "the sportos, the motorheads, geeks, sluts, bloods, wastoids, dweebies, and dickheads" (who all adore Bueller) rally support to fight Ferris' rumored life-threatening condition, Principal Rooney, (Jeffery Jones, Amadeus) and his sister, Jeanie, (Jennifer Grey, Red Dawn) do everything in their power to catch Ferris in the act of skipping school. Though Ferris uses his charm, wit, and improvised acting to slip through the grasp of pursuers, the care-free joyride the trio takes turns out to be more than they bargained for. The climax of the film kept me on the edge of my seat, constantly wondering if Ferris would make it through the day without being caught. By the end of the film viewers will feel satisfied with the conclusion, but hungry to hear more about the characters and their futures. Matthew Broderick's portrayal of Ferris Bueller is outstanding. Broderick spent many years sharpening his skills in formal acting training focusing mainly on theater, and his performance reflects that. Ferris is a smart-mouthed, cocky, and daring teenager willing to do anything to encourage others to laugh and have a good time. Like many teenagers, his hobbies include skipping school, killing time with his friends, and praying that one day he will have a car of his own. The iconic "Parade" and "French Restaurant" scenes show off Broderick's ability to be charismatic and commanding in a lead role, separating him from many of the cheesy, over-the-top actors of the 1980's. Though War Games is considered to be Broderick's breakout role, Ferris Bueller's Day Off will be easily remembered as his greatest work. Alan Ruck plays the role of Cameron Frye, Ferris's sickly best friend who worries that a reckless cruise in his father's Ferrari will end in complete disaster. Cameron is arguably the most complex character of the film, as he struggles with depression, conflict with his parents, and disillusionment with the world around him, like many teenagers in the 1980's. Though Ruck was nearly 30 years old when he joined the cast as Cameron, he convincingly plays a teen that is not in control of his own life. As the film progresses, the viewer sympathizes with Cameron, and secretly crosses their fingers that he will recover from the problems he faces. Ruck secured his place in this classic because of his goofy sidekick role, quality acting skills, and his ability to evoke emotion from the actors on screen as well as the viewers. Mia Sara plays the role of Sloane Peterson, Ferris's popular girlfriend. After the boys impersonate Sloane's father to have her released from school, she joins the pair in their adventure around Chicago. Unlike Broderick and Ruck, Sara had little experience in Hollywood, but it hardly shows in Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Like Ferris, Sloane loves fun and adventure, and wants to have one last good day with her boyfriend before he graduates. Sara's performance is emotionally genuine and authentic to the mentality of a 1980's teenager, as she was one at the time of the film's production. Though many actresses were auditioned to play the role of Sloane, I feel that Mia Sara was complementary to Broderick and Ruck, making her perfect for the part. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is known as one John Hughes's best films. Hughes wrote and directed this film, as well as the "Brat Pack" classics, Sixteen Candles, Pretty in Pink, and The Breakfast Club. Unlike many movies of that era, Hughes wrote characters that were complex, with desires and problems that many teens to this day can still relate with. The camera style as scene in the rest of his films returns; unique and visually appealing. The sound track features many classic songs of the 1980's, including Bueller's own rendition of The Beatles' "Twist and Shout". As long as there are high school students who are eager to get more out of life than learning from a monotonous economics teacher and gym class this film will remain relevant. Without the unique vision and clever writing skills of John Hughes however, this film may have flopped. Though the era of the 1980's is slowly fading from the conscious of our culture, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is likely to remain as popular as always. The stellar writing and directing of Hughes, a unique story, and a perfectly selected cast make this film a rare gem. I urge everyone who needs a good laugh to skip school and watch Ferris Bueller's Day Off, you won't be disappointed.

After seeing this film as many times as I have (too many to count), you may think that maybe i would get bored of it. Never going to happen. I believe that this film is not only the best teen movie that has ever been made, but also the defining movie of the 1980's. Although essentially a comedy, the film shows the essence of life as a teenager through brilliant performances by Matthew Broderick and Alan Ruck. Broderick's Ferris is a wonderful character neither stereotype nor overbearing persona, and John Hughes yet again creates genius through the character of Cameron, played by Alan Ruck - who was 30 at the time!Many may disagree, but for me the best lines in the whole film are Camerons - 'When Cameron walked in Egypt land...... Let my Cameron go' wonderfully delivered to convey the characters stifled existence in his home life and the pressures of being the best friend of such a man as Ferris. In all, teen comedies don't get better than this. 10/10

Review title: This movie is the template for my life
Review_body: There are no errors in this movie. Sheer perfection.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of those movies that sticks in your mind for a long time. I first watched this movie back in 2002 when I was 17 so I guess at the time I could relate to the characters in the script who were based on a similar age to me. I enjoyed this so much that I watched it over and over and then 9 years later I stumbled across it again, you don't realisze when your a teenager how important things are and how good some memories are, but once you get older you begin to appreciate life and realize how much fun you had watching this. All the characters play good roles in the movie, Matthew Broderick really does a good job as the lead role Ferris.To sum it up, 9 years down the road and this movie is still definitely enjoyable but not as much as when I was a teen, however if you are a teenager then this is a great film to watch especially with a bunch of friends.

Review title: Less a film, more something to aspire to
Review_body: I can't see myself *ever* being tired of this film.  Shame Broderick never really did much else of note... even worse I heard they made a series - just plain wrong.  One day I hope to be randomly involved in a parade where all the people start spontaneously dancing to the Beatles.

I loved this film in its entirety! I liked how fresh an outlook Ferris's character had, he really makes you feel excited about life. I like how the film was more about the people in Ferris's life growing and developing for themselves, in healthier if not better ways than they were already. Apart from the poor prick of a principle/headmaster, every character had a 'happy ending.' It isn't just a film, it's an encouragement for anyone who watches it. For me it says that people can be crazy happy and have their own spontaneous fun in life, not everything needs to be planned out and 'safe by the books'. I loved this film and I loved how it makes me, (and my friends), feel. A definite MUST watch. :)

Review title: Bueller! Next time you are sick, call me up.
Review_body: This is a perfect movie to watch when you yourself are pulling a sicky. A popular High School boy decides to skip school and make the most of his day with his friend and girlfriend, while the principle as well as Ferris' sister try to blow his cover. It has enough believability for you to love the characters, and enough heart for you to sympathize with them. The comedy is sometimes subtle and crispy, sometimes so quirky and over the top that you just let it slide and enjoy it. I love the clueless parents and the whole late 80's vibe. Plus a cool soundtrack. Still not sure of Broderick, tho he is rather fabulous in this him, but good god do i not forgive you for Godzilla 1998!!! Looking for an enjoyable comedy, try this breaking-the-fourth-wall rebellious riot.

This is one of the best comedy movie i have ever seen.Right from the start movie engages the audience and builds the character of Ferris Bueller played by Matthew Broderick,who is a fun loving,full of life and very clever fella liked by everyone. The movie also makes you realize how important it is that you enjoy life as it comes and conquer your fears. The acting by all the characters is excellent and dialogues are also good. at the end i would quote from the movie that " Life moves pretty fast,and if you don't stop and look around once in a while,you could miss it".

This is a movie that you get or you don't. It's heavily saturated with satire & parody of how life really is, versus how any teenage joe schmoe sees this movie as the epitome of his dreams. "Bueller?... Bueller?... Bueller?" Every teenager dreams of skipping school and Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) does just that. In this 1986 teenage comedy, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, a not so innocent teenager nearing the end of his high school career, ditches school and, with best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) and girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara), embark on an adventure to the "Windy City" of Chicago. With the upcoming obstacles of college, Bueller plans a day of shenanigans in hopes of saving Cameron. Little does Bueller know that his sister, Jeanie Bueller (Jennifer Grey), and principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) would do everything in their power to make sure that the so called "perfect" child would be caught red-handed.Jeanie Bueller and Principal Ed Rooney didn't expect that catching the famous Ferris Bueller was going to be easier said than done. Along the way, they themselves dig into deeper trouble, even with the law! Running through neighbor's yards, encountering a gruesome rottweiler, and maybe even a little romance with a young, troubled teen (Charlie Sheen). What else could possibly go wrong? Throughout this movie, it is hard for anyone to despise Ferris. His young, seemingly childish attitude that never gets him in trouble appeals to everyone. He never ceases to address the audience with a sarcastic, funny side note as if we are apart of his scheme. By the end of this movie, the audience will see Ferris develop on so many levels. He even goes as far as taking the blame for something he didn't do, even if that means being caught. Matthew Broderick comes through with his best performance to date.Although Cameron, much more reserved than Bueller, is a bit skeptical of Bueller's mischief, he slowly warms up to the idea of fun and even does the unexpected. Yet throughout this movie he never seems to wear more than three expressions. It's not until the end that the audience sees the true Cameron that has been bottled up. Will his father ever open his heart to his son? Sloane Peterson plays the perfect girl for the wild and unpredictable Ferris Bueller. She's able to keep Ferris in check and temporarily out of trouble, yet she still plays along with his shenanigans. Together they balance out to the perfect high school relationship.John Hughes, director of the famous "16 Candles" and "The Breakfast Club," adds another memorable and comedic piece to his repertoire. Through the cultivation of every teenager's dream and the development of these characters, John Hughes certainly delivers. Anyone looking for countless laughs should indulge in this one of a kind teenage comedy.

In the 1986 film, "Farris Bueller's Day Off", one determined teenager pushes every limit to the max, with his sites set on the goal of having the day off from his own form of prison, high school. Farris is the ultimate wise guy. He outsmarts everyone who may potentially get in his way of skipping school. And, while doing so, creates many laughs for the audience along the way. This film incorporates great acting along with an entertaining plot that makes for a great comedy, just maybe not one for all ages. It seems as though every character was hand picked to perfectly fill their part. Matthew Broderick has the complete package for his role as the main character, Farris Bueller. His performance captures the essence of the crazy, free-spirited teenager who just wants to live life to the fullest. Starring alongside Broderick is Alan Ruck, or better known as Ferris's best friend, Cameron Frye. Ruck's drone voice and tense facial expressions mimic the characteristics of the up-tight personality his character is supposed to represent. Together the two actor's juxtaposition and spectacular performances make for a hilarious comedy of pranks and lies. Though the film will produce many laughs, my hope would be that those laughs are produced only from the mouths of those 14 and up. The plot is centered around lies that snowball throughout the storyline. At first it's one little lie, and then one more, until it seems as though it is the only dialogue being used. Younger children may process the message of this film to be finding it acceptable behavior to skip school, lie to their parents and authority figures, and steal a car with ultimately no consequences. But, these over-the-top lies and inflated situations are what make for such an amusing plot. With that being said, the film is rated PG-13 mostly for its language. Swear words flow loosely from the lips of some of the young characters. But, then again, the dialogue is part of what makes the movie so funny. The smarta** kids, the monotone teacher, and the naïve parents are all needed to add cohesion to the piece. Director John Hughes seems to stay in his line of fire with this movie, filming the different perspectives of life viewed from the rebellious, love stricken teenagers, as he does in his other timeless films, "The Breakfast Club" (1985) and "Sixteen Candles" (1984). Though Hughes doesn't incorporate any flashy special effects or amazing scenery in the film, it isn't needed. It allows the audience to focus on, and enjoy, the classic story of the young man who fakes sick to skip school and, in turn, makes the best out of his "free" day. If you are looking for a good laugh from a classic movie, it should be a must see on your list.
