Review title: My Favorite Movie Of All Time!
Review_body: I think it is only fitting that I dedicate my first movie review to my favorite movie, Ferris Beuler's Day Off.This movie got me through High School.. and much of my adult life as well. That is, until Office Space came along, but that is another review.Ferris Beuller (Matthew Broderick) was the kid in High School who never got caught, had fun doing whatever it was and was popular with everybody. On this particular day in the movie, Ferris decides he is taking the day off. After all, "How can anyone be expected to handle school on a day like this?" Ferris calls his best friend, Cameron Frye (a young Alan Ruck), who is always sick, and tells him to pick him up. After all, Ferris does not have a car. He wants to show Cameron a good time before High School is all over and wants him to have something good to remember about it. Also, Cameron is Ferris's phony caller voice. Whenever Ferris needs a call made, such as from a police officer or another parent, Cameron is the man.Eventually, Ferris and Cameron gets Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) excused, by using the dead grandmother excuse. Ferris is always one step ahead of his adversary, Principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones). Rooney is portrayed as a hard ass principal who does not let anything get by him. He sets off to catch Beuller in the act and put a permanent mark in his record and hold him back another year, so as not to have other Ferris Beuller wannabes for years after Ferris's departure. Jones was perfect for his role as Rooney and I do not think that role will ever be surpassed for him.Most of the movie is spent with Rooney looking for Ferris and, as mentioned earlier, is about one or two steps behind him. He comes very close to catching him but never gets the job done. Rooney is the stooge in the movie that every teen and even the adults enjoy seeing him beaten and outsmarted by his young student. I don't think anyone has expected otherwise.All throughout the movie, it pokes fun at the boring and tedious high school classroom. Ferris will say something like, "If we played by the rules right now, we'd be in gym class" and then it cuts to an exaggerated look at a gym class, which more resembles a boot camp. Ben Stein will forever be remembered here as the extremely boring economics teacher.There are many more characters to this movie that make it great. There is Grace (Rooney's secretary), Jeanie and the rest of Ferris's family, the parking garage guys, the snooty waiter, Charlie Sheen and others. My friends and I still quote randomly from the movie in our everyday situations. That is how much of an impact this movie has made on many lives.There are so many great parts and quotes from this movie, they are too numerous to list in a review, nor would I want to ruin it for anybody who has not seen it, although I can not fathom why you haven't. If not, it is a must see.

Considering this movie's plot, and looking beyond the surface of the story into John Hughes' direction of the cinematography and the actors' portrayals, one can see the motives behind this movie and why it is so important to today's culture and to the lives of people of all ages. Beginning with just the opening scenes, where Ferris is shown waking up and performing his way out of going to school, he already breaks the fourth wall by addressing the audience and looking straight into the camera as a sort of confession time for him to state his true motives and plans. The audience almost becomes his confidant in this way and the only person Ferris is ever truly honest with, seeing as he can easily lie to other characters such as his girlfriend and his parents. It is also important to note that Ferris is the only character to do this for the rest of the movie, and this is intentional to imply that Ferris is the narrator of the whole story. As the narrator, although the story is told from Ferris' perspective, now the focus is shifted away from making Ferris the protagonist and more towards highlighting the other people he talks about. Considering that outlook, it is easier to recognize Cameron as the main character, and how the story being told truly revolves around him while Ferris simply keeps the wheels turning. In his efforts to drive the plot of the story, Ferris whisks Cameron and Sloane out of their boring, everyday lives onto an adventure to visit major must-sees in Chicago. The movie features many famous Chicago landmarks including the then Sears Tower and the Art Institute of Chicago, and as Hughes puts it, the film was his love letter to the city: "I really wanted to capture as much of Chicago as I could. Not just in the architecture and landscape, but the spirit." Some argue that the places Ferris and his gang visit and the things they do are touristy and not a good representation of things a Chicago native would choose to do, however Hughes purposefully aimed to make the setting recognizable and well-known to emphasize how unbelievable Ferris' day truly was (Siegel). The film would not have captured the same feeling without the foul ball catch at the Cubs game, or Ferris' solo in the parade, or the crew's peaceful admiration of the artwork in the Chicago Art Institute.Further analyzing their Chicago Art Institute excursion, this scene stands out for its slower pace and more serious mood than the rest of the movie. This feeling is instilled by having only music playing the entirety of the scene without any spoken words, as well as the scene's positioning right after a humorous, slapstick scene of Rooney breaking in to Ferris' house and encountering his dog, and right before the upbeat spectacle of Ferris in the parade. In fact, the original layout of this scene was much different, but in response to critic's reactions, Hughes changed the background music and the placement of the scene to assure its impact (Watkins). This scene is crucial to the plot of the movie as well, as Cameron is found splitting off from his friends and standing transfixed before Seurat's A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte for nearly a full minute, looking deep into the pointillism of a mother and her child, which come to symbolize his life, and how the closer he gets, the less sense it makes. And while Cameron ponders his existence in a teen-angst-y way, Sloane and Ferris enjoy in a moment alone drowned in blue light from Marc Chagall's America Windows, suggesting how Ferris embodies freedom and the notion of America being able to "save" people and offer them a better life. After all Ferris' goal is to "save," and although he appears to simply be wanting to save himself from a boring day at school, looking deeper could reveal that in reality Ferris is saving Cameron. Cameron finds his redemption in the end, as this crazy, whirlwind of a movie eventually builds up to the Ferrari scene, and the whole story comes together to reveal the purpose of all the madness. Cameron stops being the victim and ultimately proves to be the hero that the story revolves around. He states his authority and prepares to stand up to his dad saying, "I'm going to defend it. Right or wrong I'm going to defend it. ... When Morris comes home, he and I will just have a little chat" (Ferris Bueller's Day Off). By this point, the story has come full circle, and has amounted to a classic Hughes coming-of-age tale based around the vulnerability and truth behind being a teenager, as displayed by Cameron (Ebert). Although designed to trick audiences into assuming that this movie is all about Ferris (I mean just look at the title), in truth there's more to be taken away from the story than a laugh at Ferris' good luck. But don't get me wrong, this movie is exceptionally crafted and I would advise you to allow it to encourage you to take life a little less seriously. After all, "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it" (Ferris Bueller's Day Off).

Review title: Live your best life on an ordinary day
Review_body: Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is a defiant teenager who goes to great lengths take a day off school. He convinces his "down on his luck friend" Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) to raise out of his depressed state and come join him on his day off using his dads prized and precious car. Together, Ferris and Cameron, conspire to get Ferris' girlfriend Sloan Peterson (Mia Sara), out of school for the day by imitating her father, calling the school regarding the death of her grandmother. Once Sloan is released from school, the three take off for a day freedom and fun. Well not so much for Cameron who is constantly worried about the wrath of his dad if something should happen to the car. Little do they know Mr. Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is on a quest to catch Ferris in his deceitful lie of really being sick, and finding it a challenge to do so. The theme that comes to mind after viewing this film is to live it up and make the best out of an ordinary day. Ferris was the "push" Cameron needed to find the confidence to even think about confronting his dad about the disrespect and lack of love he has been shown over the years. Ferris is determined to make his fun where there is none. This is reminiscent of "Catch Me If You Can" by being the bad guy (Leo Dicaprio) that is chased by an authority looking to bury him, all the while silently being cheered for as he gets away with his violations. Even though we didn't see it play out on the screen, Cameron leads us to another theme of standing up for yourself. As we seen his confidence grow, we see him gaining freedom within himself. We seen Cameron's rendition of a breaking point in "Me, Myself, and Irene". In the film Jim Cary is bullied and disrespected by his peers. One technique used is flash cuts and panning, showing the beautiful day Ferris is planning to embark upon and the other is of the city. Both are the two important points of Ferris' day; make the best of the beautiful day by getting out and enjoying the city. Ferris was not the only one with the idea of "living it up" and taking advantage of the day, the parking attendants also shared the same motto.

The film Ferris Bueller's Day Off is believed to be an iconic film by many. In this film Ferris Bueller, played by Matthew Broderick , is a high school student who has a knack for playing hooky. Knowing that this may be his last time he can skip school he develops an elaborate plan to pull it off. Ferris, along with his friend Cameron Frye, played by Alan Ruck, and his girlfriend Sloane Peterson, played by Mia Sara, head to Chicago for the day. As they ditch school they have to stay one step ahead of their principle Ed Rooney, played by Jeffrey Jones, and Ferris' sister Jeanie Bueller, played by Jennifer Grey.The theme from this film has to be to live life to the fullest and make the most of everyday. Ferris Bueller is a character who makes the best of everything and encourages his friends to do the same. If not for Ferris Bueller, Cameron may not have worked up the courage to confront his father about their relationship and Jeanie Bueller may not have found a new respect for Ferris and discover she needs to start focusing more on herself. In a way, this film reminds me of the film The Breakfast Club. Both films are about high school students dealing with a villainous principle who in the end, discover more about themselves than they ever knew before.Dialog and music are two important techniques used in this film. The music selected heightens the suspenseful moments well and aids the quick cutting speed found throughout the film. The dialog of the film is an under-appreciated aspect. Ferris' sharp and outlandish reasoning is something that can only be appreciated. There are many great techniques used throughout this film but the dialog and music proved to be key. Both of these techniques play into the theme of the film, which is live it up to the fullest. The music selected was always boisterous and lightened and the dialog throughout the film is constantly about loosening up and having fun. In all, this is a great film and one that can be viewed over and over again.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a 80's movie that many people still enjoy today. This funny and eventful movie is perfect for all ages disregarding the foul language. This movie is about a rebellious, free-hearted senior in high school who wants to take the day off from school because "how could he possibly be expected to go to school on a day like this" and tricking your parents is a little "childish and stupid but so is high school." He convinces his friend Cameron to come with him on his adventure because a) he was already home due to his mental illness and b) he has a car. Cameron and Ferris call the school to get Ferris's girlfriend, Sloan, out of class by using the excuse that her grandma passed away. The principal, Mr. Rooney, is suspicious of Ferris now that he has missed nine days of school and throughout the movie is trying to catch Ferris ditching school. During the movie the three friends take Cameron's dad's precious Ferrari, which he has taken years to restore, to many different locations. The director of this movie, John Hughes, has filmed many iconic movies such as: The Breakfast Club, Mr. Mom, Sixteen Candles, Pretty in Pink, National Lampoon's Vacation, all before Ferris Bueller's Day Off. He has directed many other popular movies after filming Ferris Bueller's Day Off such as: Home Alone, Beethoven, National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation, Planes, Trains, and Automobiles, Miracle on 34th Street, etc... You can tell he takes pride in his other films because he has hidden "easter eggs" in the movie Ferris Bueller's Day Off, on each license plate that shows up, there are references to an older films that Hughes have filmed. For example on Ferris's father's license plate it says MMOM which refers to the film Mr. Mom. Also in the hallways of Ferris's high school there is a poster that says "Go Shermer" and on the outside of the high school in The Breakfast Club the school name is Shermer High School which can imply that Ferris and the kids in the movie The Breakfast Club go to the same school. The actor who plays Ferris, Matthew Broderick, adds so much to the character Ferris Bueller; Broderick, although he was 23 years old, perfectly describes how most teenagers act and feel. Broderick made Ferris have swagger, he was the guy you would want to be friends with. In the movie this is obvious that everyone cared about Ferris since they were trying to raise money for his "sickness" and many people were concerned about him, but Broderick really shows off how popular Ferris truly is with the attitude he has when talking to Mr. Rooney and other classmates over the phone. Broderick was even nominated for the Golden Globe Award, Best Actor in Motion Picture Musical or Comedy, in 1986 for in role in Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Although Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a funny and eventful movie some of the jokes that are told may be inappropriate or confusing to a younger audience. Even though I found the movie amazing and flawless, some of plot has minor hole in it, but gets masked over due to the fast paced theme in the movie. In conclusion, this funny, eventful movie is timeless and will stay an iconic movie forever.

A typical movie about a rule breaking high schooler, his skeptical best friend, and his beautiful girlfriend. On paper, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, may seem like a stereotypical teen comedy that young people can relate to. However there is, like many other movies, an important hidden message. Ferris Bueller's Day Off, illustrates the message through the changing storyline, critical character development, and through the ending of the film. Receiving 7.8/10 stars on IMDb, the movie was liked by many and hated by some. This movie can be categorized as one of the greatest of all time because of the lessons preached and the characters that today's world, young and old, can recall and share a laugh about. Whether you watched the film when it originally came out in 1986 or you just watched it for the first time last night on Netflix, this movie appeals to all generations. Although Ferris Bueller's Day Off appears to be a story about a rule breaking high schooler, it gets the viewer to think about the idea of living life and the experiences/ adventures that can be made by taking risks through the storyline, character development, and ending.The film's storyline consisting of Ferris' adventure to ditch school, his experiences with his friends, and his adventure back home before his parents get there all add to the idea of risk and reward that is the big picture throughout the film. The overall film with Ferris speaking directly to the audience and it being mainly revolved around three characters all together is a meaningful way to pull the viewer into it, an example of show don't tell. The storyline was clear, effective, and meaningful. The storyline was nothing without the exciting and feel good ending and it brought a closure to one of the best movies of all time. Characters in movies all have the same turning point when something bad occurs and they must learn to fix it and learn from it. In Ferris Bueller's Day Off, the two most developed characters are the main character, Ferris Bueller, and his best friend, Cameron. He's his parents' favorite so it's easier for him to play hooky and get away with it. Ferris' development throughout the story from a naive and immature high schooler to a more loving, and self aware teenager about to enter the real world is very moving to see. His best friend, Cameron, faces obstacles that result in maturity as seen by his experience with lending his father's' car. The prized car ends of getting wrecked as a result from Ferris' idea that if a car is in reverse then the odometer number will reduce. He learns to face his fears, in this case his father, and matures throughout the adventures in the movie. Another character who develops throughout the film if Ferris' sister, Jeanie. She begins the movie as a typical jealous sister who just wants her parents to catch Ferris' out of the house but eventually turns into the person who saves his cover. The character development is probably the best part of this movie but none of that would happen if the storyline wasn't the way it came out to be.The ending of the film tied together all the loose ends throughout the movie and it brought together all the important lessons and messages throughout the movie together. Ferris' adventure back home was a race against his parents. His sister, originally wanting to bust Ferris, ends up saving his cover. Principal Rooney, the main obstacle and "villain" of the movie, ends up catching Ferris but it blackmailed into letting him go since Ferris' sister picked up his wallet while he trespassed into their house. The exciting. The exciting and humor-filled ending brought the movie to a close and emphasized the importance of family and other lessons brought up throughout the movie. Ferris Bueller's Day Off, brings a comedy movie that all age groups can find appealing. It emphasizes lessons such as: risk taking, family, and facing your fears. This movie is the type that will never get old, a classic. This, along with the lessons and iconic characters, makes this one of the greatest movies of all time and one that will always be one of my favorites until I die.

Review title: Amazing, funny, and full of heart. 80's classic.
Review_body: I don't know why this is my favorite movie but it is. Yes, I mean favorite movie of all time. What does this movie do that others don't? Not much. But it gives you that warm-fuzzy feeling John Hughes movies usually do. The dialogue is witty and funny and Ferris's view of life is uplifting. This movie has so many quotes and is incredibly charming. I'll end this quick review with some words from Bueller himself. "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."

In 1987, while on vacation in Ireland with "Dirty Dancing" star Jennifer Grey (not pictured), a car driven by Broderick collided head-on with a Volvo. Broderick and Grey survived, but the two passengers in the other vehicle died. Broderick was faced with serving up to 10 years in prison for causing "death by dangerous driving." However, the actor was later fined just $175 and convicted of the lesser charge of "careless driving."

I'm 30 and this is the first time I've seen this flick. I have no nostalgia whatsoever, though I think I have seen parts of the movie some time before when I was a kid.FBDO has such a huge status even today (the running scene in Spider-man: Homecoming is proof of this) and I thought I was going to be way, waaaaay more entertained by this movie. The film has a lot of charm and it is a well made movie that uses lots of music and scores to its advantage as well as having lots of well-filmed scenes etc.Part of the humor comes from how unrealistic Bueller's tricks and plans are and the insane amount of effort it must go into to pull certain technological stunts off (e.g. all the tapes) - wouldn't it been easier to just go to school? The message of the movie that we all should take a day off and experience life is also a very nice one and deserves to be lived out once in a while (though in FBDO comes from a place of privilegie and the rich main characters shouldn't have much to complain about...)But honestly, at least 60% of the movie is boring. So many of the "good jokes" (the ones from the Ferris/Sloane/Cameron-parts) didn't make me laugh or even smile. Then the movie has a lot of pure garbage-scenes involving the principal that tries to get back at Bueller but is forced to endure some incredibly boring and unoriginal slapstick. The scenes with Jeannie aren't that great either, which is too bad because the first scenes we see her in she seems like a real funny, badass character, a perfect contrast to Ferris - but no, there is not much payoff with that character at all.The sidestory with Cameron didn't resonate with me at all. When Cameron decides to confront his dad instead of being angry at Ferris it comes more off like the script is giving Ferris an easy way out. Though I like the multiple personality theory that some fans have (but it doesn't work because two people are calling the principal in the beginning...)Anyway, I can admit that hype probably plays some part in my disappointment with this movie. But if a movie is this hyped up and it doesn't deliver, then I think it deserves to be taken down a notch. 4/10
This movie was one of my favorites!! A classic that I highly recommend you to watch!!!!

Yes, I am going to review this movie but, first of all, I need to say I am doing this just to complete the checklist in my IMDb profile!Well, who's coolest than Mr. Bueller, Ferris Bueller? None of us I think. I mean, it's too much cool stuff to do for just one person, in only one day. But he did, and in the end, we liked it.The characters are perfectly defined: the bad sister, the condescending parents, the evil principal, the shy friend, the pretty girlfriend.They make their roles in a straight line, then in the end, we see Cameron, the best friend, stand up and have a different vision of his life. Maybe the movie is about Cameron and how much he need to work to be a free minded one. Sometimes you need some help from friends to make different things and have a different view of your life. Cameron noticed that, and had the biggest character change.The music, the photography, the sounds and edition were great and flawless. Chicago, the director's city, was well explored and showed on the screen, and how beautiful sunny days Chicago has!I think Ferris took a lot of time to elaborate his plan. Maybe it's really possible for one person to make all that stuff in one day. You just need to exercise (he had 9 absent days!) and put yourself in risk. So, have a good plan, have good friends, improvise when needed and never give up your ideals.

Review title: A movie to see more than once
Review_body:
This is the kind of movie we always remember in some life situations. Although they make a caricature of reality as in class and the reactions of children, it is almost a perfect description of many real situations for example.
The script was well assembled so as not to leave future actions so explicit. It was recorded in an engaging way with some narratives directed to the viewer made by the main actor himself without making it seem strange.
The roles put in the film are common characters for students and make them identify real people from their lives. A great movie to see again from time to time.

Review title: One of the Best 80's Movies EVER!
Review_body: I have watched this movie so many times I can't even count! Why? Because it is possibly one of the best movies ever that came out of the 80's (comedies, of course). The cast was a superb ensemble of both young and veteran talent (Matthew Broderick, Ben Stein, Jefferey Jones, to name but just a few). The music that was played through out the movie, while relatively unknown, was perfectly placed. John Hughes did a wonderful job with this movie. The cast, the music, the location (Chicago); everything was perfect. I would have liked to see a sequel develop where Ferris and Sloan (Mia Sara) get married or something. Anyway, this is a movie well worth watching - over and over and over...

Review title: How is this not in the top 250 all time?
Review_body: I believe Bueller has so infiltrated society that the powers that be are trying to keep it out of the top 250. The current rating of 7.8 is places 225 through 250. Ferris Bueller's day off is better than:226. 7.8 The Thing (1982), 240. 7.8 Planet of the Apes (1968), 241. 7.8 Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003), 249. 7.8 Mulholland Dr. (2001).The rest I either cannot make the comparison because I have not seen them, or comparing and contrasting yields relatively equal amounts of strengths and weaknesses.John Hughes also wrote The Breakfast Club which is bubbling under the top 250. John Hughes also wrote series, though purely schlock, which became juggernauts: National Lampoons ... Home Alone ... Beethoven.I say let's get all of the fans of John Candy, Anthony Michael Hall, and Molly Ringwald to help this deserving man, and this film, up into the top 250. How many times did this three gain shine off his lines? It's no The Bridge on the River Kwai, but the camp belonged in the film.The true test of film is not direction or production, but writing. Pierre Boulle's writing is the only thing that got Planet of the Apes into the top 250 and Impressionist production is all that got Mulholland Dr. there. I can't explain how The Thing became so highly rated, it only is there due to cult status and the John Carpenter effect.Where would the Black Pearl be without Johnny Depp? Johnny Depp's in three other rated films: Finding Neverland, Ed Wood, and Platoon, but tell me how the Black Pearl is better than Blow, Chocolat, Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas, Donnie Brasco, Dead Man, and What's Eating Gilbert Grape let alone Bueller? I think that in this particular case It's the yellow mouse cult.oh well, opinions only here and mine says 8 of 10 for Bueller.

A definition of a good movie is one that impacts people generation after generation. That never gets old to no matter who is watching. Like a good series over years, Star Wars for example Continue to be popular years after they come out. A movie that isn't apart of a series that has done this for many years and will continue to do so for many years is Ferris Bueller's Day Off. 
 It has become one of the most classic comedy movies of all time and the main reason we all love it is because we all wish we could be Ferris Bueller for a little bit. For most of high school there are moments when I dream of not having to worry about the homework and absences of school. Ferris bueller has the guts to not care about all this and make the most of his time and live to the fullest unlike his buddy Cameron. Although for this one day Ferris gets rid of all doubt and fear and takes of course big risks. Although being caught almost everyday Ferris still risks it for the biscuit and gets bolder and bolder as the day goes on. Absolutely forgetting the fact Ferris could not graduate if he gets caught he still goes on and has a blast per usual. With Cameron leading their day it would have only lasted an hour or so but with Ferris they get the opportunity to go to a baseball game and lead a parade in Chicago and much much more while celebrating his life with his girlfriend and best friend and continue to live life with Ferris's crazy sister and very oblivious parents running around and living life while they can to the most of their ability and living by his own quote "life moves pretty fast, if you don't slow down every once in a while, you might miss it."
 Matthew Broderick (Ferris) is extremely comical and very smooth throughout The Whole movie. He even connects with the audience on a whole new level when he directly talks to them at the beginning of the movie and multiple times throughout. This allows us to see in what Ferris sees and how he plans things and what he wants to happen and helps you better comprehend the movie. It shows him better that a lot of time and thought are put into his plans and that he is not just a big lazy bum and slacker throughout school and life but rather very smart and hardworking when he wants to be. Ferris throughout the movie seems to be the person that everyone is jealous of and wants to be who Ferris is. Even his sister who plots against him The Whole movie but when it becomes the middle of the movie and towards the end you come to realize that almost everyone who conspires against Ferris is actually jealous and respects what he has accomplished and almost envy him.
 Another thing that was really impactful throughout this film was the music and sounds. For example during the parade in downtown Chicago they used the song "Twist and Shout" by the Beatles and shows how cheerful and what a great time they are all having. The thing about songs and music is it can emphasize the mood of the movie and how the characters are feeling during certain scenes. Like when it would show his sister it would be a kinda darker slower music because she was always trying to catch him. Also the sounds emphasize where you are for example when the dean of students, Mr. Rooney is in the arcade it is a lot of noise and random objects emphasizing chaos and lots of confusion for him making him make mistakes and mistake a girl for Ferris. Sounds can change entire aspects of a movie making it fearful or joyful and throughout this movie the majority of the sounds are cheerful and show joy for Ferris and Cameron, whereas for Mr. Rooney and Ferris's sister are negative and dull. The sounds in this movie really help emphasize the mood and do a really good job making it the movie it is to be.
 One thing about this movie that could have been better I believe is the plot. I couldn't seem to find a point as to what the whole point is. I thought they could have shortened up the scene with Ferris's sister because I didn't understand really where she came in at the end and tried giving her more apart of the movie but I didn't think she really had a meaning or a purpose in the moving rather than trying to get Ferris in trouble. I think John Hughes the director should have cut that scene and maybe focused more on Ferris and almost getting caught by Edward Rooney the Dean of students. Although this is just a monitor flaw in this movie all in all I think it is a class act film.
 John Hughes who directs this movie does a wonderful job emphasizing that kids should live your life to the fullest and have fun while you are young. He shows don't care what other people think just do what you think is right and have fun while your doing it even if getting out of school is what is right. This movie is so good it will continue to be a gem for years to come as it has been since it left the box office.

Review title: What could possibly be wrong with this movie?
Review_body: I honestly don't understand how anyone that had actually watched this movie could think it was bad! Despite others' belief, Ferris, Sloan, and Cameron are NOT spoiled, especially Cameron. His dad acts like he doesn't exist and only cares about his precious Ferrari. I have watched the movie a few times, and yes, some people may have enjoyed the movie more having watched it in their teen years. Ferris is simply looking for a bit of freedom from school before he graduates. Many high schoolers these days, it seems, would love to leave an impression on their school after leaving it by doing something that everyone would remember, such as what Ferris did. He's not really spoiled, he's parents just aren't the brightest out there, and it's a movie! It's Hollywood! Things are exaggerated! It's meant to be a movie for teens, about teens; it's the kind of thing young people like. I thought it was a hilarious watch with a bit of everything for someone.

What more I can I say but this movie rocks! A cult classic that will never die! Of course, how anyone could get away with what he gets away with is a little outrageous but that's what makes the movie all the more timeless. It's what everyone (or a lot of people anyway) dreams about at one time or another in their life. Matthew Broderick was an excellent choice for playing the role of Ferris Bueller. One of his best movies in my estimation. Sure he went on to do moves like Glory but he will always be known as Ferris Bueller. It's kind of like Indiana Jones. I can't see anyone but Harrison Ford as Indiana Jones. The other characters were all cast very well. Alan Ruck does a very good job as Cameron. He and Ferris combine to make an individual that a lot of people can identify with. The free spirit and the uptight friend. Then of course there is Sloane. She's hot. THat's really all I need to say there. However, I will say this. She too was cast well. She fit in and the trio just worked really well. I love to just turn on this movie and have it running in the background as I do other things. All in all I give this movie a fifteen out of ten!
